 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The pacparser Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pacparser is a library to parse proxy auto-config (PAC) files. Proxy auto-config files are a vastly used proxy configuration method these days. Web browsers can use a PAC file to determine  which proxy server to use or whether to go direct for a given URL. PAC files are written in JavaScript and can be programmed to return different proxy methods (e.g. &quot;PROXY proxy1:port; DIRECT&quot;) depending upon URL, source IP address, protocol, time of the day etc. PAC files introduce a lot of possibilities. Look at the wikipedia link above to find out more about them. </p>

<p>Needless to say, PAC files are now a widely accepted method for proxy configuration management and companies all over are using them in corporate environment. Almost all popular web browsers support PAC files. The idea behind pacparser is to make it easy to add this PAC file parsing capability to any program (C and python supported right now). It comes as a shared C library and a python module which can be used to make any C or python program PAC scripts intelligent. Some very useful targets could be popular web software like wget, curl and python-urllib. </p>

<p>Please look at the README and other links for more information. </p>

<p>Usage ExamplesUsing it with python: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; import pacparser
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; pacparser.init()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; pacparser.parse_pac(&#39;examples/wpad.dat&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; pacparser.find_proxy(&#39;http://www.google.com&#39;, &#39;www.google.com&#39;)
<br/>&#39;PROXY proxy1.manugarg.com:3128; PROXY proxy2.manugarg.com:3128; DIRECT&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; pacparser.find_proxy(&#39;http://www2.manugarg.com&#39;, &#39;www2.manugarg.com&#39;)
<br/>&#39;DIRECT&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; pacparser.cleanup()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt;Using it in C: </p>

<p>manugarg@hobbiton:~$ cat pactest.c
<br/>#include </p>

<p>int pacparser_init();
<br/>int pacparser_parse_pac(char* pacfile);
<br/>char *pacparser_find_proxy(char *url, char *host);
<br/>void pacparser_cleanup();</p>

<p>int main(int argc, char* argv[])
<br/>{
<br/>  char *proxy;
<br/>  pacparser_init();
<br/>  pacparser_parse_pac(argv[1]);
<br/>  proxy = pacparser_find_proxy(argv[2], argv[3]);
<br/>  printf(&quot;%s\n&quot;, proxy);
<br/>  pacparser_cleanup();
<br/>}</p>

<p>manugarg@hobbiton:~$ gcc -o pactest pactest.c -lpacparser
<br/>manugarg@hobbiton:~$ ./pactest wpad.dat http://www.google.com www.google.com
<br/>PROXY proxy1.manugarg.com:3128; PROXY proxy2.manugarg.com:3128; DIRECT</p>
 summary : <p>PACS is system, that allows to set up and maintain algorithm contests, like Top Coder, ACMs, and so. User needs only web browser to use it.</p>

<p>PACS is written in Python, using Django (0.95) framework. It is in early stage of development, but is nearly usable. It contains solution tester (with saferun), user interface, and primitive admin system.</p>
 title : The pacs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Pactester is a tool to test Proxy Auto Configuration (PAC) files. PAC files are used by browsers to determine the &#39;right&#39; proxy for a URL. Since the PAC file evaluation mechanism is generated inside the browser and cannot be accessed from outside, the only way to tell which proxy your browser will use for a specific URL is manual inspection of the  PAC file. But manual inspection doesn&#39;t really scale very well. Pactester resolves this problem. It makes use of JavaScript interpreter and Netscape/Mozilla APIs to evaluate the PAC files and automates the whole process. </p>

<p>Pactester reads a PAC file, evaluates it in a JavaScript context and uses this PAC file&#39;s logic to determine the proxy for a specific URL. </p>

<p>Usage:  ./pactester   [-h host] [-c client_ip]
<br/>        ./pactester   [-c client_ip]</p>

<p>Options:
<br/>  -p pacfile: PAC file to test
<br/>  -u url: URL to test
<br/>  -h host: Host part of the URL
<br/>  -c client_ip: client IP address (defaults to IP address of the machine on which script is running)
<br/>  -f urlslist: a file containing list of URLs to be tested.</p>

<p>Example:
<br/>  ./pactester -p wpad.dat -u http://www.google.com
<br/>  ./pactester -p wpad.dat -u http://www.google.com -c 192.168.1.105
<br/>  ./pactester -p wpad.dat -f url_listFor more information check the latest README file at: http://pactester.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/README</p>

 title : The pagingappfuse Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Demonstrate Display Tag External Paging and Sorting via paging queries to an RDBMS.  Implemented using Hibernate Criteria generated from calls in the web interface by Display Tag.  This is an Appfuse java project.  Solution uses Display Tags Paginated List extension. </p>

<p>OverviewDisplay Tag allows paging and sorting, if you click on a column header to sort ascending or descending. Note that it only sorts the records that are on the page - all the other records are excluded from this &#39;internal&#39; Display Tag sort. Similarly when the page was generated every single record was retrieved, but only 25 were shown. With big datasets this is going to slow your web app down, (a lot), and the inconsistent sorting will confuse your users. This is what we are going to fix using Appfuse, Hibernate and Display Tag. </p>

<p>Implementation stepsSee this wiki page for details of how the implementation was achieved: PagingSorting </p>

<p>Sample CodeAll the code is in http://code.google.com/p/pagingappfuse  go to http://code.google.com/p/pagingappfuse/source/checkout for instructions on checking out the whole project, or you can browse the source from http://code.google.com/p/pagingappfuse/source/browse </p>

<p>ProjectsAppfuse:  http://www.appfuse.org Hibernate: http://www.hibernate.org Display Tag: http://displaytag.sourceforge.net/11 Display Tag External Paging and Sorting: http://displaytag.sourceforge.net/11/tut_externalSortAndPage.html</p>

PanoSalado is based atop a Papervision3D core, accessible to both the Flash IDE and Flex developer alike, and hugely extensible. </p>

 title : The panosalado Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Paoding Analysis摘要Paoding&#39;s Knives 中文分词具有极 高效率 和 高扩展性 。引入隐喻，采用完全的面向对象设计，构思先进。 </p>

<p>高效率：在PIII 1G内存个人机器上，1秒 可准确分词 100万 汉字。 </p>

<p>采用基于 不限制个数 的词典文件对文章进行有效切分，使能够将对词汇分类定义。 </p>

<p>能够对未知的词汇进行合理解析 </p>

<p>欢迎如果对该项目您有任何建议，欢迎您在http://code.google.com/p/paoding/issues/list 中提出各种issues. </p>

<p>2010-01-20 庖丁 Lucene 3.0 升级说明 </p>

<p>(代码已提交svn，下载包稍后稍推迟下) </p>

<p>这次升级的主要目的是支持Lucene 3.0，具体改动如下： </p>

<p>（1）支持Lucene 3.0，对Lucene 3.0以下的版本，请使用 http://paoding.googlecode.com/svn/branches/paoding-for-lucene-2.4/ 中的代码编译。 </p>

<p>（2）使用Java 5.0编译，不再支持Java 1.4，以后的新功能将会在Java 5上开发。 </p>

<p>（3）PaodingAnalyzer的调用接口没有改动，但在使用上需要适应Lucene 3.0的API，分词示例如下：      </p>

<p>//生成analyzer实例  
<br/>Analyzer analyzer = new PaodingAnalyzer(properties);

<br/>TokenStream stream = analyzer.tokenStream(&quot;&quot;, reader);

 title : The paperworld3d Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>For the Flash on Tap attendees who are checking out the code after my session....when you check out the source make sure you check out the &#39;branches&#39; directory - in there is a branch called &#39;reorganisation&#39; - that&#39;s the source you want - it hasn&#39;t been merged with the trunk yet and it&#39;s a bit of a mess still.... if you drop me an email at trevor at infrared5 dot com i&#39;ll let you know when it&#39;s ready for use.The aim of the Paperworld project is to provide developers and designers with the tools to create realtime Multiplayer Games using Flash, Unity3D or the iPhone.... or all 3! </p>

<p>Current release target is 0.7 and is due June &#39;09Paperworld can be used as a complete framework with which to build large games and applications or you can just use the individual libraries you need for your specific purpose without the overhead and learning curve of becoming familiar with yet another framework.  </p>

<p>The Paperworld server runs as a service in any existing Red5 installation. By default Paperworld uses jMonkey as the 3D engine for running its simulations, but if you prefer you can create your own adaptor for any java-based 3D engine. If you need an adaptor for a particular 3D engine please get in touch, i&#39;d be happy to help put one together for you. </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>A complete message-based connection API for Flash allows for easy customisation of handshake procedures and creating custom functionality just by creating a new type of message. Connect to Red5 from Unity3D or iPhone via UDP. Support more fast-twitch models than Flash can handle using datagrams instead of all that AMF overhead. Game AI - Steering Behaviours, Decision Making etc. etc. allow you to create complex behaviours for NPCs. Multiple controller support. More than just mouse and keys - use the wiimote, a custom joystick - even your iPhone! Connect it all together. Provide specific clients for each platform for the same game. Use each platform for its strengths.</p>

 title : The paralleljobs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ParallelJobs LibraryParallelJobs is a library that provide a easy way to create a parallel process on your application. </p>

<p>Works like a simple Win32 API call, as you can see below: </p>

<p>begin
<br/>  ParallelJob(@MyProcess);
<br/>end;This will create a parallel process that will execute MyProcess function. </p>

<p>All controls and utilities are being implemented and still on development </p>

<p>Why use paralleljobs? </p>

<p>ParallelJobs on the current stage provide a very easy way to create a parallel process, like you can create using TThread, but without writing a lots of code. </p>

<p>Detailsversion 2009.0.1.12 </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/peebles/</p>

 title : The parsetree-pattern-matching Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A pattern matcher and an embedded Ruby DSL for specifying patterns.  </p>

<p>The patterns are used for matching ASTs produced by ParseTree (http://www.zenspider.com/ZSS/Products/ParseTree/index.html), which are representations of Ruby ASTs as s-expressions. Eg. &quot;1+1&quot; is represented as [:lit, 1,:+,1]. </p>

<p>Analyzing ParseTree expressions with patterns is much more readable than having to use a visitor based approach.</p>
 title : The partfunc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Tools for molecular computation: </p>

<p>1. vibAna: calculate vibrational frequencies, force constants, IR intensity, ...  2. classGeo: classifying molecules according to topologies. 3. partfunc: Compute partition function and derive thermodynamic properties by superposition method. 4. genStruct: generation random structures from crystal structures. </p>

<p>If you ever happen to want to link against installed libraries in a given directory, LIBDIR, you must either use libtool, and specify the full pathname of the library, or use the `-LLIBDIR&#39; flag during linking and do at least one of the following: </p>

<p>- add LIBDIR to the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH&#39; environment variable 
<br/>during execution 
<br/>- add LIBDIR to the `LD_RUN_PATH&#39; environment variable 
<br/>during linking 
<br/>- use the `-Wl,--rpath -Wl,LIBDIR&#39; linker flag 
<br/>- have your system administrator add LIBDIR to `/etc/ld.so.conf&#39;</p>

 title : The passport08 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionPassword Securicor allows you to store user names and passwords to all of your sites securely. All you need is to remember the password to unlock the data. The application uses 256 bits Rijndael encryption (also called AES) which is enough for U.S. Government TOP SECRET data: </p>

<p>The design and strength of all key lengths of the AES algorithm (i.e., 128, 192 and 256) are sufficient to protect classified information up to the SECRET level. TOP SECRET information will require use of either the 192 or 256 key lengths. The implementation of AES in products intended to protect national security systems and/or information must be reviewed and certified by NSA prior to their acquisition and use. (Source) 
<br/>Password Securicor allows you to create groups and sites so that you can organize your data in the way you want. </p>

 title : The pasteor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A pastebin written in ruby</p>
 summary : <p>The pastiche software framework brings a variety of technologies together, like semantic web, multi-agent and distributed systems. It is designed for ease of use and fun. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>This is a continuation of previous work done on Spyse. </p>

<p>Still thinking about a number of ideas. </p>

<p>#!/usr/bin/env python</p>

<p>&quot;&quot;&quot;Hello World example program from the Spyse tutorial&quot;&quot;&quot;</p>

<p>from spyse.core.agents.agent import Agent
<br/>from spyse.core.behaviours.behaviours import Behaviour
<br/>from spyse.app.app import App</p>

<p># Define a custom behaviour class
<br/>class HelloBehaviour(Behaviour):
<br/>    # Customize the Behaviour class by overriding action()
<br/>    def action(self):
<br/>        # The action:
<br/>        print &quot;Hello, world&quot;
<br/>        # Mark this behaviour as finished so that it will be removed
<br/>        # from the agent&#39;s behaviour list.
<br/>        self.set_done()</p>

<p># Define a custom agent class
<br/>class HelloAgent(Agent):
<br/>    # Customize the Agent class by overriding setup()
<br/>    def setup(self):
<br/>        # Add the custom behaviour for the agent to perform.
<br/>        # An agent will die as soon as all its behaviours are complete.
<br/>        self.add_behaviour(HelloBehaviour())</p>

<p># Define a custom application class
<br/>class MyApp(App):
<br/>    # Customize it by overriding run()
<br/>    def run(self, args):
<br/>        self.start_agent(HelloAgent)</p>

<p># Instantiate and run MyApp
<br/>if __name__ == &quot;__main__&quot;:
<br/>    MyApp()</p>

 title : The pathtools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Update Sitehttp://pathtools.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/PathToolsUpdateSite/site.xml </p>

<p>Rate this plug-inRate this plugin @ Eclipse Plugin Central </p>

<p>Path Tools Eclipse Plug-inThis plug-in adds the following actions to Eclipse. </p>

<p>Copy Paths - this action copies the fully qualified paths of selected folders and files into the Clipboard. Copy Paths action is now a drop down and allows you to copy paths in all different formats. The last used format is remembered and used. The workspace resource paths, fully qualified name of a Java files, and some well known locations e.g. workspace location, can also be copied.  Explore - this action opens the selected folder or the folder containing the selected file in the OS file explorer.  The user can configure the exact command that is used to launch the file explorer.  The Explore drop down has actions to go to well known places or user specified location. Open Command Line Shell - this action opens a command line shell window at the selected folder or the folder containing the selected file. Open in external editor... - this action opens the selected folder or file using the selected external editor.  The user can configure the exact command that is used to launch the external editor. Custom actions pull down menu. These custom actions can be defined in Path Tools preferences page. Clicking on the Custom actions buttons shows the Path Tools preferences page. Here are some examples of custom commands: Open terminal Ubuntu - /usr/bin/gnome-terminal --working-directory=&quot;{path}&quot; Windows - cmd /K &quot;cd {path}&quot; The actions are also enabled when an editor with file editor input is active. </p>

<p>The actions have been grouped into a Path Tools sub menu in pop-up menus as the pop-up menus were getting too long. </p>

<p>Toobar </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Preferences Page</p>

 title : The paypalphp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Implementation of simple Paypal Express Checkout in PHP. </p>

<p>PayPal allows their users to implement checkout functions using their API. But implementing the full API is not a piece of cake. There are some libraries on the web, but the most of them are paid, closed or too complex. </p>

<p>If you wanna implement simple and single-item payments (i.e. &quot;pay for service&quot; or &quot;pay for source code&quot;), you can use my, free and open, library described here. </p>

<p>This library was written as a part of my framework, but it&#39;s usable standalone too, I hope. ;) </p>

<p>Using is as easy as </p>

<p>$r = new PayPal();
<br/>$r-&gt;doExpressCheckout(10, &#39;Da Greatest Library You Ever Seen&#39;);and  </p>

<p>$final = $r-&gt;doPayment();</p>

<p>if ($final[&#39;ACK&#39;] == &#39;Success&#39;) {
<br/>	echo &#39;Succeed!&#39;;
<br/>} else {
<br/>	echo &#39;Error!&#39;;
<br/>}More information and step-by-step manual at PHP Suit</p>

 title : pdf2djvu : pdf2djvu - Open Hub
 title : The pdfetch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pdfetch is a small web app that automagically fetches the PDF reprint of a PubMed article given its PMID.  If pdfetch cannot find a local copy of the reprint, then it downloads the reprint from the publisher&#39;s website to the local repository (of course only if the reprint is free or if you have authorized access to it, e.g., via your university library). </p>

<p>pdfetch can also be used for the creation of a shared local repository of PDF reprints  designed for small trusted groups, e.g. science labs, by having every member of the group point to the same local server running pdfetch. </p>

<p>If you use the &quot;ferret&quot; branch version of pdfetch, PDF reprints in the local repository can be easily searched using any web browser. </p>

<p>pdfetch is best used from PubMed using a bookmarklet (for any modern web browser) or a greasemonkey script (for Firefox only). Both assume that the pdfetch server is listening on localhost:3301 and that Javascript is enabled in your web browser. </p>

<p>To install the bookmarklet just drag the link in the list to your right onto your Links/Bookmarks toolbar/menu. To use the bookmarklet, just click it when using PubMed (of course the pdfetch server needs to be running too!). </p>

<p>To install the greasemonkey script just make sure you are using Firefox + Greasemonkey and click on this link. It adds a &#39;Fetch&#39; link to the article display page in PubMed for easy access to pdfetch. </p>

<p>pdfetch requires Camping and Mechanize. </p>

<p>To install pdfetch follow these easy steps: </p>

<p>install Ruby +  RubyGems install camping, mechanize, and mongrel by executing the following command gem install camping mechanize mongrel --include-dependencies save pdfetch.rb in the directory where you want the PDF reprints to reside. launch the pdfetch server by executing the following command camping pdfetch.rb or (for better security) camping -h 127.0.0.1 pdfetch.rb. You can change the port that the pdfetch server listens to (default is 3301) by executing the following command camping -p  pdfetch.rb. If you have any problem, add -s mongrel to any of the above commands. you are ready to go!!! You can fetch the PDF reprint of a PubMed article with PMID &#39;123456&#39; by going to http://localhost:3301/fetch/123456 in your web browser, or by using the bookmarklet/greasemonkey script directly from PubMed.</p>
 summary : <p>PdfToRuby consists of a command line utility that will take a pdf file and create ruby class that generates the pdf file via Pdf::Writer. </p>

<p>The resultant class can be used standalone at the commandline, in your ruby app, or inside of rails </p>

<p>Requires: Pdf::Writer Pdf::Reader</p>

 title : The peeweecms Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The pegtl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Parsing Expression Grammar Template Library (PEGTL) is a C++0x library for creating parsers according to a Parsing Expression Grammar (PEG). Grammars are embedded as regular C++ code, created with template programming (not template meta programming). These hierarchies naturally correspond to the inductive definition of PEGs. The library extends on the subject of PEGs with new expression types, actions that can be attached to grammar rules, and mechanisms to ensure helpful diagnostics in case of parsing errors. PEGs are superficially similar to Context-Free Grammars (CFGs); for a description see Wikipedia page on PEGs or this paper on PEGs by Bryan Ford.</p>
 title : The pekechis Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Google Code para la Tesis de Juan Diego Pérez Jiménez </p>

<p>Dirigida por Amador Durán Toro</p>
 title : The pelisys Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pelisys is a simple and easy way to organize your private and public library of books, music, movies, receipts, photos and so much more. All stored in one place and accessible with any device and at any time over the Internet. It also offers a great way to synchronize your data with others and allows other services to import or be imported to pelisys. You can then build a network of friends or people with the same stuff and trade your library items. </p>

<p>Features </p>

<p>Fully Open Source - Every line of source code will be free for everyone. Simple API - Build your own tools on top of pelisys with the simple, yet powerful API. No matter if you want to use PHP, Ruby, Perl or any other programming language Extensible - Add your own library item-type. Or ask for an implementation. Import - Powerful import of your current items, like del.icio.us bookmarks, Amazon details, Flickr photos and many more. Export - It is your data! You can export it in a variety of formats and use it your way.</p>
 title : The pencil-code Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Pencil Code is primarily designed to deal with weakly compressible turbulent flows, which is why we use high-order first and second derivatives. To achieve good parallelization, we use explicit (as opposed to compact) finite differences. Typical scientific targets include driven MHD turbulence in a periodic box, convection in a slab with non-periodic upper and lower boundaries, a convective star embedded in a fully nonperiodic box, accretion disc turbulence in the shearing sheet approximation, self-gravity, non-local radiation transfer, dust particle evolution with feedback on the gas, etc. A range of artificial viscosity and diffusion schemes can be invoked to deal with supersonic flows. For direct simulations regular viscosity and diffusion is being used. </p>

<p>The code is written in well-commented Fortran90. </p>

<p>For a more detailed description and a full introduction see the manual.pdf file (see under links on the right). </p>

<p>Remember to sign up for the Pencil Code User Meeting (see link on the right)!</p>

 title : The perfsonar-ps Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>perfSONAR-PS is a set of independent software services that implement the perfSONAR protocols for network performance monitoring.  As with other implementations of the perfSONAR standard, all services offer protocol compatibility.  The key feature of this software is the ability to federate between deployments, particularly those that span multiple domains, making the job of solving end-to-end performance problems on paths crossing several networks much easier to address. </p>

<p>The perfSONAR-PS services provide Web Services (WS) based interfaces into already deployed network monitoring infrastructures and act as an intermediate layer, between the performance measurement tools and the diagnostic or visualization applications. The targeted audience for these services is network Network Operation Centers (NOCs) at Universities and Regional networks, however these services are broadly useful to the general public at large. </p>

<p>The perfSONAR-PS software suite is developed entirely in the Perl programming language, taking full advantage of numerous language features and benefits including the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network (CPAN) distribution system. This software manager makes perfSONAR-PS the ideal choice for integration into typical NOC environments. </p>

<p>For more information on this software and our activities please start with our Wiki.</p>

 title : The perl-appengine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GoalsThe goal of the Perl-AppEngine project is </p>

<p>to get Perl implemented on Google App Engine </p>

<p>Get InvolvedAnyone who is interested in following the discussion should sign up on the mailing lists. Please sign up on the Perl-AppEngine mailing list Please also sign up on the more general Cloud Perl mailing list, regarding anything having to do with Cloud Computing in Perl. Start discussing your ideas of how to move this project forward. Ideas can be floated on the mailing list. However, to make meaningful progress on an idea, it should be documented on the wiki. Discussion on the mailing list will be centered around updating those documented ideas. When ideas mature, they should definitely be documented on the wiki on this project site. Getting Started with the CodeGettingStarted - describes how to check out the code and get started Project Status2009-07-01 - The project is live again. We are in a code sprint in July to get it functional. (Of course, it may take longer than a month, but the mailing list is waking up and the developers are active.) 2009-05-28 - Status from David Sansome prior to a proposed July 2009 code sprint 2008-07-26 - PerlAppEngineProgress200807 reported by Brad after OSCON 2008 2008-07-22 - Some Googlers are now working on this project too 2008-07-22 - The related project Sys::Protect has started. 2008-06-20 - This project is just starting up. Help us get the word out. Active Developersi.e. People involved in writing doc, writing test cases, or writing code. </p>

<p>SA - Stephen Adkins (spadkins) BF - Brad Fitzpatrick (brad) - Google employee, Protobuf-Perl AB - Artur Bergman (abergman) - Perl Core, Sys::Protect JL - Jonathan Leto (jaleto) - Sys::Protect CK - Chia-liang Kao (clkao) - Sys::Protect RU - Reini Urban (reini.urban) - Sys::Protect YK - Yuval Kogman (nothingmuch) - Catalyst JR - Jon Rockway (jon) - Catalyst DA - Dean Arnold (renodino) - porting Google App Engine API&#39;s Componentssys-protect - Create a protected/hardened/restricted Perl language runtime where Perl opcodes which would not be allowed in the Google compute farm are also not allowed protobuf-perl - Enable the serialization of API input and output arguments according to the &quot;protocol buffers&quot; standard, which is in use at Google. Arguments encoded in protocol buffers can be passed through an API to invoke services provided by Google. perl-appengine - The dev kit for Perl applications which will run in the Google compute farm. BackgroundPerl is not currently supported by Google App Engine (only Python). Google wants to (eventually) support other languages on App Engine. &quot;Although Python is currently the only language supported by Google App Engine, we look forward to supporting more languages in the future.&quot; Google knows that there is a significant community that would like Perl to be supported on App Engine (including a variety of Google employees, some of which I know). If you would like to communicate your support for Perl on App Engine to Google, go to the issues list and click the star next to &quot;Issue 34: Add Perl Support&quot;. (You must logged in to Google in order to see the star and select it.) NOTE: Do not post a general message to the list. Simply click on the star. There are a variety of PerlAppEngineDiscussions around the web. Support for Perl on App Engine will require modifications to the Perl language itself, a task which the Perl community would most likely need to get involved in. (see the Language discussion under General Questions) Support for Perl on App Engine will obviously never occur before the Google App Engine team gets involved. The Google App Engine team is currently very busy with things besides Perl support. A variety of overtures have been made to the App Engine team to organize the community support to do the work. (an example) Neither Google nor the Google App Engine Team initiated this project. This is a community-sponsored project to do all of the work necessary to make it easy for the Google App Engine team to embrace and support Perl.  Edit:  some Googlers have now joined but it&#39;s still not a Google-official project. Because there is no guarantee that Google will pick up on the assistance that we are offering, another project has been created called Cloud Perl. This other project is devoted to the use of Perl in all kinds of cloud computing environments. LinksApiProxy PerlAppEngine PerlAppEngineDiscussions PerlAppEngineDesign GettingStarted</p>

 title : The Qt4 Bindings for Perl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Perl bindings for Qt4.  This project aims to have a production-ready module that is similar in syntax to the PerlQt 3 binding. </p>

<p>There is currently no official release, but you can check out the source from svn and compile them yourself.  See the INSTALL file for instructions on how to do this. </p>

<p>Once the bindings are built, there are many examples in the example directory that are direct ports to Perl of the C++ examples that ship with the Qt library.</p>

<p>Based on the Smoke library, so the final version will support any method that Smoke supports. Create Perl packages that subclass, extend, and override their C++ parents Create signals and slots: connect Qt defined signals to Perl subroutines, and Perl defined signals to Qt slots Signals and slots defined in parent packag</p>
 title : The permissionable-attributes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Permissionable Attributes allows you to declare which attributes of a model have permissions associated with them and what those permissions are. </p>

<p>The best example of where you would use this plugin is for a community site where you have certain attributes on a user model that are only viewable to certain people.  For example, some attributes might be viewable to the entire public, while others might only  be available to that user&#39;s friends. The plugin only supports mutually exclusive permissions.  Meaning, an attribute is either just  viewable by the public or just viewable by friends but not both.  However, if an attribute is viewable by the public your helpers should probably be smart enough to that friends should also be able to view them.     See the README for more info: </p>

<p>http://permissionable-attributes.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/README</p>
 title : The perrygeo Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A repository for personal projects and random scripts. mostly related to GIS data and mapping. Most code is written in bash, javascript, python, c++, php or java. All projects in this repository are personal hobbies and vary greatly in their fitness for use.</p>
 summary : <p>Persephone is a data abstraction mechanism. Its purpose is to remove all the tedious parts of working with databases and lets you focus on real code. Standard searching, loading, and saving of data to/from databases is handled automatically -- along with protection for data types and incorrect operations. Beyond persistence Persephone can also generate HTML listings and Forms for your data. </p>

<p>	 Unlike ActiveRecord style systems, Persephone assumes you have a lot of existing code and/or and existing database and have no ability, nor desire, to completely replace it. Thus Persephone operates in a miminally invasive manner, by being very clear about what it is doing, and operating happily alongside alternate solutions. There are no method assumptions, no prescriptive behaviours, and basically nothing that will make curse the solution. 	 </p>

<p>Currently Persephone supports PHP code generation.  Other targets are possible, the source schema language is not PHP specific.</p>
 title : The perseph Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The persevere-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Persevere is an open source set of tools for persistence and distributed computing using an intuitive standards-based JSON interfaces of HTTP REST, JSON-RPC, JSONPath, and REST Channels. The core of the Persevere project is the Persevere Server. The Persevere server includes a Persevere JavaScript client, but the standards-based interface is intended to be used with any framework or client. </p>

<p>The Persevere Server is an object storage engine and application server (running on Java/Rhino) that provides persistent data storage of dynamic JSON data in an interactive server side JavaScript environment with the following key features: </p>

<p>Create, read, update, and delete access to persistent data through a standard JSON HTTP/REST web interface Dynamic object persistence - expando objects, arrays, and JavaScript functions can be stored, for extensive JavaScript persistence support Remote execution of JavaScript methods on the server through JSON-RPC for a consistent client/server language platform Flexible and fast indexed query capability through JSONQuery Comet-based data monitoring capabilities through REST Channels with Bayeux transport plugin/negotiation support Data-centric capability-based object level security with user management, Persevere is designed to be accessed securely through Ajax with public-facing sites Comprehensive referencing capabilities using JSON referencing, including circular, multiple, lazy, non-lazy, cross-data source, and cross-site referencing for a wide variety of object structures Data integrity and validation through JSON Schema Class-based data hierarchy - typed objects can have methods, inheritance, class-based querying Pluggable data source architectures - SQL tables, XML files, remote web services can be used as data stores Service discovery through Service Mapping Description Persevere JavaScript Client is a persistent object mapping framework for JavaScript in the browser, which allows programmers to access, traverse, and manipulate persisted objects  graphs easily with standard JavaScript syntax and intuitive Persistent JavaScript (PJS) API. Persevere implements the PJS API and maps JavaScript objects  to persistent storage objects remotely through JSON based RESTful web services following the JSPON (JavaScript Persistent Object Notation) data  interchange specification. Persevere accesses persisted  object graphs provided through  RESTful JSON data sources which can represent various underlying sources such as database tables,  XML files, web services, and object repositories, and such persisted graphs can even span domains.  Persevere allows application code to be persisted and exist within these object graphs, to facilitate  improved object oriented design and organization. Persevere can provide orthogonal persistence and lazy loading support with standard JavaScript property access and modification through JavaScript pre-processing, or it can provide these capabilities natively with JavaScript 1.7. Note that the Persevere JavaScript Client is released under the MPL 1.1/GPL 2.0/LGPL 2.1 license.</p>
 summary : <p>It&#39;s a simple and easy to use time tracking tool.  </p>

<p>Main window </p>

 title : The petrolpricetracker Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Scan local petrol prices from your desk before filling your next tank with this easy-to-use petrol price tracker mapplet. Motormouth.com.au report prices by observing prices on priceboards outside service stations in Brisbane, Gold and Sunshine Coasts, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Hobart and these prices are progressively updated twice-daily. Prices in Perth are updated each morning and are fixed for each 24 hour period. Whilst every effort is made to ensure the prices are accurate at the time of collection, there can be numerous price movements in each 24-hour period in cities other than Perth. For more information on price collection methods, view the Motormouth FAQs here: http://motormouth.com.au/siteinfo/faq.aspx. Please provide any feedback to: feedback@motormouth.com.au</p>
 title : The petsc4py Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PETSc is a suite of data structures and routines for the scalable (parallel) solution of scientific applications modeled by partial differential equations.  It employs the MPI standard for all message-passing communication. </p>

<p>petsc4py are Python bindings for PETSc, the Portable, Extensible Toolkit for Scientific Computation. </p>

<p>A good friend of petsc4py is: </p>

<p>mpi4py: Python bindings for MPI, the Message Passing Interface. Other two projects depend on petsc4py: </p>

<p>slepc4py: Python bindings for SLEPc, the Scalable Library for Eigenvalue Problem Computations. tao4py: Python bindings for TAO, the Toolkit for Advanced Optimization.</p>

 title : The pha Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The phantom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Phantom protocol is a system for decentralized anonymization of generic network traffic. It has been designed with the following main goals in mind: </p>

<p>1. Completely decentralized. </p>

<p>- No critical or weak points to attack or put (il)legal pressure on. </p>

<p>2. Maximum resistance against all kinds of DoS attacks. </p>

<p>- Direct technical destructive attacks will practically be the only possible way to even attempt to stop it. </p>

<p>3. Theoretically secure anonymization. </p>

<p>- Probabilistic methods (contrary to deterministic methods) must be used in a completely decentralized design like this, where no other peer can be trusted, so focus is put on optimizing these methods. </p>

<p>4. Theoretically secure end-to-end transport encryption. </p>

<p>- This is simple in itself, but still important in the context of anonymization. </p>

<p>5. Completely (virtually) isolated from the &quot;normal&quot; Internet. </p>

<p>- No one should have to worry about crimes being perpetrated from their own IP address. </p>

<p>6. Maximum protection against identification of protocol usage through traffic analysis. </p>

<p>- You never know what the next draconian law might be. </p>

<p>7. Capable of handling larger data volumes, with acceptable throughput. </p>

<p>- Most existing anonymization solutions are practically unusable for (or even prohibit) larger data volumes. </p>

<p>8. Generic and well-abstracted design, compatible with all new and existing network enabled software. </p>

<p>- Software application developer participation should not be needed, it should be easy to apply the anonymization to both new and already existing products like e.g. web browsers and file transfer software.</p>

 title : The phcpatches Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The main use of this interface is to lower the core voltage of a Laptop’s CPU (”undervolt”) </p>

<p>The goal is to reduce the laptop’s temperature so the cooling fan can safely run at a slower speed. Another goal of undervolting is to reduce the power consumption of a laptop and thus extend its battery lifetime.</p>
 title : The phctool Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Linux Processor Hardware Control is a patch for the Linux kernel that provides a userspace interface to control the core voltage of a computer processor(s). </p>

<p>The main use of this interface is to lower the core voltage of a laptop&#39;s CPU (&quot;undervolt&quot;) </p>

<p>The goal is to reduce the laptop&#39;s temperature so the cooling fan can safely run at a slower speed. Another goal of undervolting is to reduce the power consumption of a laptop and thus extend its battery lifetime. </p>

<p>Linux-PHC-0.2x also adds additional built-in frequency/voltage tables to the Linux kernel for some Pentium-M CPU models. This is particularly usefull for laptops with broken ACPI that can&#39;t use the speedstep-centrino cpufreq driver at all. Linux-PHC 0.3 does not. There will be a new driver named phc-est to fix the problem with broken tables.</p>
 summary : <p>Data, code, papers from phd research. Bits and pieces. Not really an open source project.</p>

 summary : <p>PhD thesis on the creation, study, and optimisation of Digital Ecosystems., </p>

<p>Restored compatibility with python 2.4 </p>

<p>May 30, 2008Release 0.4.0 </p>

<p>Improved device discovery, takes less time Improved file transfer with obex-data-server Import contacts from file Send message to multiple contacts Scanning for devices no longer hangs when no bluetooth device is present Option to store sent messages on the phone </p>

<p>Mar 30, 2008Release 0.3.1 </p>

<p>Made code work with python 2.4 (no longer requires 2.5) </p>

<p>Mar 29, 2008Release 0.3.0 </p>

<p>Allow connection through serial device Contacts can be exported to csv Support for unicode text messages Support for multi-part messages Delivery report option added Auto-detect port for file transfer </p>

<p>Mar 20, 2008Release 0.2.2 </p>

<p>Fixed bug in UTF-8 detection </p>

<p>Mar 19, 2008Release 0.2.1 </p>

<p>gettext support Dutch translations Set UTF-8 character set on phone if available Character count updates on paste and drag </p>

<p>Mar 15, 2008Release 0.2.0 </p>

<p>Support for sending messages in PDU mode (some devices don&#39;t support text mode) Added python gammu as backend (should increase number of supported devices) New config file layout </p>

<p>Mar 09, 2008Release 0.1.2 </p>

<p>Fixed bug in device selection dialog, bottom device was always selected </p>

<p>Mar 09, 2008Release 0.1.1 </p>

<p>Device discovery is less strict, should find more devices (~/.phonetooth directory must be deleted or application will crash) </p>

<p>Mar 05, 2008Release 0.1.0 </p>

<p>Initial release of phonetooth</p>

 title : The php-class-and-test-generator Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PHP-based class generatorGiven a simple text-based description of a class, code generator will produce the following : </p>

<p>PHP class fileUser comments on class, property, and method level, suitable for use with PHPDocumentor Generated properties and methods with appropriate access access and class/instance type PHPUnit2 test case fileProvides stubs for testing all public methods of class Includes debug support Runs test cases as-is PHP class runner fileUse this to instantiate and experiment with classes Simple example file showing how to instantiate class and run all public methods </p>

<p>Sample input file </p>

<p>Uses mixture of Ruby-style notation for class members and UML accessor notation : </p>

<p>Simple case : </p>

<p>class MyClass
<br/>@+myPublicInstanceProperty
<br/>@@-myPrivateClassProperty
<br/>#=myProtectedInstanceMethod
<br/>##+myPublicClassMethodMore complete case : </p>

<p>class FirstTestClass
<br/>First  comment line for class myTestClass
<br/>Second comment line for class myTestClass</p>

<p>@defaultProtectedInstanceProperty
<br/>First line of comments for defaultProtectedInstanceProperty
<br/>Second line of comments for defaultProtectedInstanceProperty</p>

<p>@-privateInstanceProperty
<br/>One line of comments</p>

<p>@=protectedInstanceProperty</p>

<p>@+publicInstanceProperty
<br/>First  line of comments for publicInstanceProperty
<br/>Second line of comments for publicInstanceProperty</p>

<p>@@defaultProtectedClassProperty
<br/>First  line of comments for defaultProtectedClassProperty
<br/>Second line of comments for defaultProtectedClassProperty</p>

<p>@@-privateClassProperty
<br/>One line of comments</p>

<p>@@=protectedClassProperty</p>

<p>@@+publicClassProperty
<br/>First  line of comments for publicClassProperty
<br/>Second line of comments for publicClassProperty</p>

<p>#defaultProtectedInstanceMethod
<br/>First  line of comments for defaultProtectedInstanceMethod
<br/>Second line of comments for defaultProtectedInstanceMethod</p>

<p>#-privateInstanceMethod
<br/>One line of comments</p>

<p>#=protectedInstanceMethod</p>

<p>#+publicInstanceMethod
<br/>First  line of comments for publicInstanceMethod
<br/>Second line of comments for publicInstanceMethod</p>

<p>#defaultProtectedClassMethod
<br/>First  line of comments for defaultProtectedClassMethod
<br/>Second line of comments for defaultProtectedClassMethod</p>

<p>#-privateClassMethod
<br/>One line of comments</p>

<p>#=protectedClassMethod</p>

<p>#+publicClassMethod
<br/>First  line of comments for publicClassMethod

 title : The php-csv-utils Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PHP CSV Utilities has a new home!For future updates, please refer to my new blog: http://lukevisinoni.com/ </p>

<p>Several of the recent projects I’ve been working on have required an “import from csv file” feature. PHP comes with a few functions for reading and writing csv files right out of the box: fgetcsv and fputcsv. While these are good functions and they get the job done I find they just aren’t enough in many cases. It would be nice if PHP had an interface like python’s csv module. Enter PHP Csv Utilities. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>It has been months since there was any kind of update on this poor little library. I released the last version (0.2) prematurely, which resulted in a poor release, confusing file structure, and a lot of bugs. I&#39;d like to let anybody interested in the library know that I am working on version 0.3 right now as well as a much improved (and more transparent) build / release process. If there are any bugs or issues you have with the library please leave a comment or shoot me an email and I&#39;ll do my best to make sure it&#39;s addressed. </p>

<p>Please, if you have any feature requests, suggestions, questions, anything... drop me an email. </p>

<p>luke d0t visinoni {at} gmail (d0t) com </p>

<p>Documentation - Wiki</p>

 title : The php-django-like-db-abstraction Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The php-email-address-validation Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThis email address validation function was originally released on AddedBytes.com in June 2004, and was updated following many comments and suggestions from readers. </p>

<p>In July 2008, ICANN announced that the TLD system would be opened up to allow the creation of many many more TLDs, making it more important than ever that email addresses are properly validated according to the standards that define them. </p>

<p>Thus, the script was moved to Google Code (blog post), to enable easier maintenance and hopefully more people to contribute code. It was originally released under a Creative Commons License, but that has been changed to a BSD license which, among others things, allows commercial use. </p>

<p>AimsThe aim of this project is to create an email address validation class (or function) that checks for technical validity1 in email addresses, the idea being then that a site can send an email to that address to verify ownership. </p>

<p>1) Certain parts of the standards could be considered security risks and are not in widespread use, so at the time of writing folding white space, control characters and comments are not considered valid by this script. </p>

<p>Join!The main reason this code has been released under an open source license is to allow others to improve it. Best place to start is probably the Google Group.</p>

 title : The php-fsapi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This library provides a PHP proxy client for the FamilySearch API which anyone may use to interface with the FamilySearch API. This proxy class will return the raw XML result from the FamilySearch API. </p>

<p>This code also provides a library for parsing and working with the data returned from the FamilySearch API.  The FamilySearch API returns data in an XML format. This library parses that XML into an object model which client code can work with to display and manipulate the data.  This library can also be used to convert the parsed data into a GEDCOM format. </p>

<p>This library may also be used to integrate the same client with a PhpGedView site. </p>

<p>This code was created by students from Neumont University. Neumont University is a revolutionary school which provides a hands-on, project-based environment for teaching computer science students.  In addition to classes in computer science theory, the students work on real projects such as this one which truly prepare them to enter the work force. </p>

<p>Access to the web service API requires agreements to be signed. Developers may obtain access to the &quot;ref&quot; system which provides a limited data set and exists solely for development purposes. Please see http://devnet.familysearch.org for more details. </p>

<p>FamilySearch and the FamilySearch Logo are trademarks licensed to the Genealogical Society of Utah and are registered in the United States of America and other countries.</p>
 title : The php-liquid Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Liquid is a PHP port of the Liquid template engine for Ruby, which was
<br/>written by Tobias Lutke. Although there are many other templating engines
<br/>for PHP, including Smarty (from which Liquid was partially inspired), Liquid
<br/>had some advantages that made porting worthwhile:</p>

<p>* Default syntax that is usable in any type of document, not just html,
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;without need for escaping.
<br/>* 100% secure, no possibility of embedding PHP code.
<br/>* Clean OO design, rather than the mix of OO and procedural found
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;in other templating engines.
<br/>* Seperate compiling and rendering stages for impreoved performance.
<br/>* 100% Markup compatibility with a Ruby templating engine, making templates
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;usable for either.
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;
<br/>For more information on Liquid, visit: http://home.leetsoft.com/liquid/wiki</p>

 title : The php-mysql-like-ror Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a library coded by PHP for MySQL manipulation, and use it like Ruby on Rails.Example:require &#39;php_mysql_like_ror.php&#39;;
<br/>$mysql = new MySQL(&quot;localhost&quot;, &quot;cfc&quot;, &quot;cfc&quot;, &quot;wtf&quot;); // Default encoding is UTF-8
<br/>$mysql-&gt;Conn();
<br/>$mysql-&gt;Exec(find_all_by_field(&quot;id&quot;, 10, &quot;users&quot;)); // Same as: mysql_query(&quot;SELECT * FROM `users` WHERE id = 10&quot;);
<br/>// Same as: mysql_fetch_assoc(mysql_query(&quot;SELECT * FROM `users` WHERE id BETWEEN 10 AND 20 LIMIT 5&quot;));
<br/>$mysql-&gt;fetch_assoc(find_all(&quot;users&quot;, array(&quot;conditions&quot; =&gt; &quot;id BETWEEN 10 AND 20&quot;, &quot;limit&quot; =&gt; 5)));
<br/>$mysql-&gt;getCount(find_all(&quot;users&quot;, array(&quot;select&quot; =&gt; &quot;id&quot;))); // Same as: mysql_num_rows(mysql_query(&quot;SELECT id FROM `users`&quot;));
<br/>$mysql-&gt;Close();
<br/>$mysql = null;</p>

 title : The php-text-statistics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThe PHP Text Statistics class will help you to indentify issues with your website content, especially with readability.  </p>

<p>It allows you to measure the readability of text using common scoring systems, including:  </p>

<p>Flesch Kincaid Reading Ease Flesch Kincaid Grade Level Gunning Fog Score Coleman Liau Index SMOG Index Automated Reability Index </p>

<p>This code was originally released on AddedBytes.com (formerly ILoveJackDaniels.com) in July 2004.  </p>

<p>What&#39;s New?In July 2008, I rewrote the code into a more up-to-date format (it was a mess before ... no structure, no validation ... awful). There are versions for both PHP5 and PHP4. The code was turned into this open source project and released under a New BSD License in August 2008. </p>

<p>The code that generates the statistics is in a simple class structure. There are also several unit test classes to ensure that changes made don&#39;t break existing functionality. There is also a live version of this tool. </p>

<p>One of the biggest challenges with measuring text readability is the counting of syllables, which can be tricky to work out. There are rules in the statistics file for working out the syllable count of words, and a large list of words to test these rules against. </p>

<p>Please feel free to add to the test word list, especially if you can find words whose syllable count is not correctly calculated (even more especially if you can also add code to the class so your word is correctly handled!). </p>

<p>Homographs are going to be impossible to calculate as they depend on context (i.e., &quot;he moped around the house&quot;, &quot;she rode her moped to school), but there are few enough of these not to be a concern. </p>

<p>Join!The main reason this code has been released under an open source license is to allow others to improve it. Best places to start are probably the Google Group for discussions and the commit list to be notified of changes to the code and issues.</p>
 title : The php-tinymvc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to TinyMVC Framework Project PageTinyMVC is written in object PHP5, simple and lightweight framework which use MVC (Model-View-Controller) architectural design pattern aproach to easy and fast PHP web application developement. It focused on easy implementation of MVC core elements (Front Controller, Action Controllers) and not covers as many aspects as most modern PHP frameworks does. Bear it in mind! If you&#39;re looking for comprehensive framework solution to help making a big and fancy PHP application, definitely TinyMVC isn&#39;t for you. </p>

<p>for more information, visit TinyMVC Framework Homepage</p>

 summary : <p>PHP XHTML tableThis class for PHP 5 easily creates XHTML valid tables with a simple and easy to remember syntax. </p>

<p>Download and installDownload the file, unzip it and read the INSTALL file. </p>

<p>Example$table = new table(&#39;border=&quot;1&quot;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;caption(&#39;People&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;part(&#39;head&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;headers(&#39;Name&#39;,array(&#39;Age&#39;=&gt;&#39;title=&quot;in years&quot;&#39;),&#39;Country&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;part(&#39;body&#39;,&#39;style=&quot;color:Blue;&quot;&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;row(&#39;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cells(&#39;John&#39;,23,&#39;USA&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;row(&#39;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;Jack&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;42&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;Mexico&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;row(&#39;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;Philip J. Fry&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;23&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&#39;India&#39;);</p>

<p>$table-&gt;part(&#39;foot&#39;,&#39;style=&quot;color:Violet;&quot;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(&quot;Total :&quot;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cell(23+42+23);
<br/># empty cell
<br/>$table-&gt;cell();</p>

<p># reopen a closed part, and add a row
<br/># won&#39;t increment the total, it&#39;s only an example
<br/>$table-&gt;part(&#39;body&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;row(&#39;style=&quot;color:Green;&quot;&#39;);
<br/>$table-&gt;cells(&#39;Igor&#39;,43,&#39;Russia&#39;);</p>

<p>echo($table);XHTML Output
<br/>People</p>

<p>Name
<br/>Age
<br/>Country</p>

<br/>88
<br/>&amp;nbsp;</p>

 title : The phpaspect Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This web application allows every body without any particular knowledge required in webmastering to create his own website. </p>

<p>It requires a web server with a remote access. Then you install, configure and use it with your web browser. </p>

<p>It&#39;s composed by a kernel and modules which can use the little PHPBoost development framework. The structure is like a personal computer&#39;s one, with operating system which corresponds to PHPBoost&#39;s kernel and different software using the kernel that are modules. It works with a database. Now MySQL is required but we wish that we will be able to implement it also for SQLite, PostGreSQL and other DBMS. </p>

<p>PHPBoost can also be very useful to developers who don&#39;t want to program a full structure for their website. They can install PHPBoost kernel, maybe with modules already existing and if they don&#39;t find the module they need they can easily build their own module using PHPBoost&#39;s framework which contains many functions to make easier the development of modules. </p>

<p>To sum up, to build your website with PHPBoost you need a web server with Apache and a DataBase Managing System.</p>

<p>About the AuthorHi, my name is Andrés Otárola, and I&#39;m from Chile. </p>

 title : The phpep Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PHP File ListA PHP application that can be used to upload and share files on a web server. The idea is to keep it as simple as possible yet with a fresh and intuitive look. </p>

<p>HistoryThis project started when me and my IRC friends needed a place where we could share images and small files easily. I wrote a PHP script that let users upload files and display them in a simple list; PHP File List was born. </p>

<p>I have been adding features to the application every now and then for the last few years. I still intend for it to be as simple as possible, however the interface is stylish and security is an important factor. I created this Google Code project to finalize and share this application with the world. </p>

<p>Latest changesVersion 0.1 is released! </p>

<p>DocumentationInstallationDownload the latest release from the Downloads tab. Unzip the file and upload the contents to your web server. Open the index.php file and look for the Configuration block (near the top). Make sure you set the correct URL to where the application is installed ($FileListURL). Create the files/ directory and make it world writable.</p>

 title : The phpmlcom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>You can make mailinglist and more functions with php and cron job. required pear, smarty source files</p>
 summary : <p>Multithreaded DaemonMultiThreaded Daemon (MTD) is a kind of framework written in PHP5 that provide simple procedures to run background tasks in a multithreaded environnement. </p>

<p>Juste to be clear, I talk about multithreading in PHP but concurrent process should be more appropriate terms, because of the fork function used. </p>

<p>More precisely the framework is an abstract class that contains two abstract functions :  </p>

<p>abstract public function getNext($slot); abstract public function run($next, $slot); and lots of others functions which deal with the inter-process synchronization. </p>

<p>getNext($slot)This function will return the next element to process, or null if there is currently no job and the daemon should wait. </p>

<p>run($next, $slot)This second function is run in a separated thread (after forking) and take as argument the element to process (given by getNext). </p>

<p>Both function get an additionnal parameter slot which indicates where the thread will be executed </p>

<p>Stable release2007-09-20 : multithreaded daemon v.0.1</p>

 title : The phpvideotoolkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This class is a wrapper around the FFmpeg, FLVTools2 and Mencoder programs to allow PHP developers to manipulate and convert video files in any easy to use object oriented way. It also currently provides FFmpeg-PHP emulation in pure PHP so you wouldn&#39;t need to compile and install the module. Note, it isn&#39;t intended as a FFmpeg-PHP replacement, only an alternative solution and it is recommended that if you make heavy use of the FFmpeg-PHP functionality you should install the module as it is more efficient. </p>

<p>PHPVideoToolkit is pretty much the only video/audio class that you will need from now on. It performs several types of manipulation operations that include video format conversion, extract video frames into separate image files, assemble a video stream from a set of separate video images, extract audio from video, watermark videos and extracted frames. Several parameters can also be configured like the output video file format (which can be Flash video or any other supported by ffmpeg), video and audio bit rate and sample rate, video dimensions and aspect ratio. It can also retrieve information about the media file, such as duration, bitrate, framerate, format, dimensions, display aspect ratio, pixel aspect ratio, audio stereo, audio frequency and audio format, without any other additional library such as ffmpeg-php.</p>

 summary : <p>Portlets are web components--like servlets--specifically designed to be aggregated in the context of a composite page. Usually, many portlets are invoked to in the single request of a portal page.  title : The phylowidget Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The phyml Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PhyML is a software that estimates maximum likelihood phylogenies from alignments of nucleotide or amino acid sequences. It provides a wide range of options that were designed to facilitate standard phylogenetic analyses. The main strengths of PhyML lies in the large number of substitution models coupled to various options to search the space  of phylogenetic tree topologies, going from very fast and efficient methods to slower but  generally more accurate approaches. It also implements two methods to evaluate branch supports in a sound statistical framework (the non-parametric bootstrap and the approximate likelihood ratio test).   PhyML was designed to process moderate to large data sets. In theory, alignments with up to 4,000 sequences 2,000,000 character-long can analyzed. In practice however, the amount of memory required to process a data set is proportional of the product of  the number of sequences by their length. Hence, a large number of sequences can only be processed provided that they are short. Also, PhyML can handle long sequences provided  that they are not numerous. With most standard personal computers, the “comfort zone” for PhyML generally lies around 3 to 500 sequences less than 2,000 character long. </p>

<p>NEWS! </p>

<p>The PhyML package now provides a tool called PhyTime that estimates divergence times using a fast Bayesian approach. PhyTime implements the methods described in the following article: </p>

<p>Guindon S., ``Bayesian estimation of divergence times from large sequence alignments&#39;&#39;, Molecular Biology and  Evolution, 2010.  </p>

<p>In order to use PhyTime, please download the development version of PhyML sources. A compressed archive of these files can be found on the righthand side of this page  by clicking on the phyml_dev_XXXX.tar.gz link.</p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The physaxe Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Physaxe is a 2D Rigid Body Library written in haXe. It&#39;s been highly optimized for the Flash 9 Player, with the best optimizations available. </p>

<p>Physaxe is based on several existing physics engines, mainly : </p>

<p>Box2D, the reference open source physics engine Glaze, an AS3 engine which is a port of Chipmunk, itself based on Box2D </p>

<p>Physaxe features are : </p>

<p>rigid body consisting in several shapes shapes supported are circles, segments (with rounded edges) and arbitrary convex polygons customizable broadphase (currently bruteforce and y-sorted list are available) island resolution and sleeping (allow ~0 CPU to be spent when groups are sleeping) constraint solver based on Box2D sequential impulses customizable body properties, such as linear/angular friction and maximized motion </p>

<p>What to give it a try ? Read the Tutorial </p>

<p>And watch the Demo</p>
 title : The physics2d Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Physics2D.Net is 2 dimensional rigid body physics engine written in C#. To work with XNA, Silverlight and .Net. </p>

<p>It is a complete rewrite of my original physics 2D found on source forge.    It is CLS compliant. Currently it has only one collision solver. The narrow phase collision detector is considered to be part of the solver.  The Solver is Sequential impulses with a distance grid used for narrow phase detection. There are 4 Broad phase detectors to choose from.  
<br/>Features: </p>

<p>Uses the split impulses solver from Box2D. This 2D Physics Engine is written entirely in C# and is optimized for C#. It has a wide range of Shapes and supports concave and convex polygons.  It has a large number of Methods to manipulate Polygons such as generating a polygon from a bitmap (sprite). The math library it uses (AdvanceMath) is written entirely in C# and is optimized for C#.  It uses a class called PhysicsLogic to implement a wide Range of effects from gravity to Maximum velocities.  Joints allow bodies to be tied together to make complex systems like ropes and rag dolls.  A large amount of parameter checking is done to reduce buggy implementations. Has a simple and elegant design.  It is Renderer independent, so it can be used with either Managed Direct X (MDX), XNA, OpenGl, WPF, SilverLight or another Renderer of your choice. (The Demo uses OpenGl) A very unrestrictive license (MIT) so you can use it for any kind of project. The code is well commented using C#’s XML comments.</p>

 title : The picasaflashapi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Picasa Flash API (PFA) is a simple ActionScript 3.0 library for the Google&#39;s Picasaweb Data API. With PFA you can access Picasaweb feeds within the Flash Player or Adobe AIR. </p>

<p>PFA handles the feed loading and parsing, so on the end of the &quot;feed reading process&quot;, you have your Picasaweb data ready in a &quot;value objects&quot;. Take it please for now as experimental (changes are reguraly commited). </p>

<p>Because of security restrictions (see GoogleAccountsAuthentication) Picasa Flash API is read-only and you cannot be authenticated yet to Google Accounts via Flash Player. You can only read public albums, photos, comments, tags, search for community pictures etc. Authentication framework code is in progress. </p>

<p>Any suggestions? Feel free to contact me (michal.gron@gmail.com).</p>

<p>Status2008-09-06: Added picasafs to the download list. Currently packaging PicasaPush. 2008-01-04: With the gdata.photos module out of the way, it&#39;s time for a license change from Apache to GPL 2007-12-22: Finally, the focus is wholly on PicasaPush, and the quest to make it a super-lean PicasaWeb client resumes. 2007-12-22: The gdata.photos modules in this tree are officially deprecated, since they are included in the 1.0.10 release of gdata  2007-11-30: A couple of rounds later, the work is starting to add gdata.photos to the official gdata tree. 2007-10-18: After some code kicking and screaming, the gdata.photos module is ready for scrutiny (hopefully, it will end up in the official gdata tree eventually) 2007-07-20: PicasaFS serves up your picasa images as a local file system 2007-07-19: PicasaPush can delete images and albums As of 2007-07-18, the program can create new albums and upload pictures.  title : The piggyfinance Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The pihipi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PiHiPi is a simple object-oriented scripting language based on and compatible with PHP http://www.php.net. PiHiPi compiler is able to translate most of php code and also adds some new features to the language. The goal of PiHiPi project is to create simpler and more consistent php parser. </p>

<p>usagePiHiPi compiler is a standalone command line utility that translates PiHiPi into valid php5 code. The resulting code can be executed or deployed directly, no additional libraries or extensions are required. </p>

<p>phicc -o source.ph ... source.phtranslates given PiHiPi (.ph) files into one single php script. If -o option is omitted, phicc prints generated code to standard output, so that you can pipe it with php: </p>

<p>phicc source.ph | phpThere&#39;s also a shell script, called phi, that does essentially the same: </p>

<p>phi source.phcompiles and then executes source.ph </p>

<p>installationwindows binariesDownload and unzip windows package. Put phicc.exe somewhere in your path, and phrtl.php in your php include_path. Run tests to make sure everything is ok: </p>

<p>php test.phpAfter running tests, it&#39;s safe to remove installation directory, phicc.exe and phrtl.php are only two files you need to use PiHiPi. </p>

<p>building from sourceYou will need lemon http://www.hwaci.com/sw/lemon and re2c http://re2c.org </p>

<p>svn checkout http://pihipi.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ pihipi
<br/>cd pihipi
<br/>make &amp;&amp; make testFor Windows MinGW is preferred, .sln file for Microsoft toolchain is included, but not &#39;officially supported&#39;. ;) </p>

<p>language extensionsWith some exceptions, PiHiPi understands any valid php syntax. The following describes features of PiHiPi not found in standard php. For more details and examples look at the files in test and examples directories. </p>

<p>layoutCode is enclosed in . Like ?&gt;, closing comment symbol */ can be omitted (assumed at the end of file). </p>

<p> is not the same as echo, it&#39;s translated into the call to the function web::_print(), which defaults to htmlspecialchars(), but can be redefined: </p>

<p>map(str::upper)-&gt;join(&#39; &#39;);
<br/>}
<br/>?&gt;
<br/> (outputs: HI THERE)primitivesString interpolation is performed for arbitrary complex references starting with $ and for arbitrary expressions enclosed in {}: </p>

<p>echo &quot;hello $foo-&gt;bar-&gt;baz[10+20]&quot;;
<br/>echo &quot;hello {10 + someFunc() + $blah}&quot;;There are also two new string delimiters: &quot;&quot;&quot; and &#39;&#39;&#39; (triple-double and triple-single quotes). </p>

<p>echo &quot;&quot;&quot; double &quot;quotes&quot; are ok  &quot;&quot;&quot;;
<br/>echo &#39;&#39;&#39; single &#39;quotes&#39; are ok  &#39;&#39;&#39;;Regular expressions are first class primitives. Regexp literals are enclosed in backticks: </p>

<p>$regexp = `[a-z_][a-z0-9_]+`si;arraysAdded shortcut syntax for array literals: </p>

<p>$ary = [10, 20, &#39;foo&#39; =&gt; &#39;bar&#39;];Arrays are objects: </p>

<p>echo [1, 2, 3]-&gt;join(&#39;|&#39;); // 1|2|3operatorsAdded ruby-alike match =~, not match !~ and compare  operators. </p>

<p>echo &#39;ABC&#39; =~ `[A-Z]+`; // true
<br/>echo &#39;ABC&#39; !~ `[0-9]+`; // true
<br/>echo 10  20; // -1Index operator []  can accept two arguments. This form is only allowed on the right and returns substring/subarray: </p>

<p>echo &#39;012345&#39;[2, 4];  // &#39;234&#39;
<br/>echo &#39;012345&#39;[2, -1]; // &#39;2345&#39;Perl semantics for boolean || and &amp;&amp;: </p>

<p>echo 5 &amp;&amp; 25; // 25
<br/>echo 0 || 25; // 25isset and unset are true operators and can be used without parentheses </p>

<p>if(isset $a) echo $a;
<br/>unset $b;
<br/>echo isset $b;Added new is and in operators. in tests if the value is in array or is a substring of the argument: </p>

<p>if(10 in [1, 5, 10, 20]) echo &quot;yes!&quot;;
<br/>if(&#39;bar&#39; in &#39;foobarbaz&#39;) echo &quot;yes!&quot;;is acts like a wrapper around php is_a... family of functions: </p>

<p>if($var is number) echo &quot;number&quot;;
<br/>if($var is string) echo &quot;string&quot;;</p>

<p>class Foo {}</p>

<p>if($var is Foo)
<br/>	echo &quot;var is an object of class Foo&quot;;assignmentsAdded support for multiple assignment: </p>

<p>$a,$b    = 10,20;    // a=10,b=20
<br/>$a,,$c   = 10,20,30; // a=10,c=30
<br/>$a,$b,$c = 10,20;    // a=10,b=20,c=20expressionsAs a general rule, expression is allowed everywhere a variable can be used, e.g.: </p>

<p>echo func()[10];
<br/>echo $(get_var_name());
<br/>echo $obj-&gt;(&#39;pro&#39; . &#39;perty&#39;);
<br/>echo (new Foo)-&gt;bar;
<br/>echo (&#39;func&#39; . &#39;name&#39;)($arg);
<br/>$a = new (get_class_name())($args);statementsthrow can throw any object or string: </p>

<p>if(!open_foo_bar())
<br/>	throw &#39;panic!&#39;;catch argument can be arbitrary lvalue, even complex: </p>

<p>try { ... }
<br/>catch($myObj-&gt;myErr) { ... }Includes are statements and resolved at compile time  i.e. include(expression) is not allowed. Resulting script is monolithic. </p>

<p>echo and print are statements, not functions. Also added puts: </p>

<p>puts &#39;Hello&#39;;functionsCurly brackets can be omitted if function body is a single statement. Added support for named call arguments, the syntax is the same as for array literals: </p>

<p>function velocity($dist, $time) return $dist / $time;</p>

<p>echo velocity(100, 4); // 25
<br/>echo velocity(&#39;time&#39; =&gt; 4, &#39;dist&#39; =&gt; 100); // 25Along with traditional callbacks (string and array), there&#39;s also direct reference form (Class-&gt;method or Namespace::method): </p>

<p>echo [1, 2, 3]-&gt;map(&#39;someFunc&#39;); // as in php
<br/>echo [1, 2, 3]-&gt;map([$someObj, &#39;someMethod&#39;]); // as in php</p>

<p>class SomeClass {
<br/>	function staticFunc($z) return $z * 10;
<br/>}</p>

<p>echo [1, 2, 3]-&gt;map(SomeClass-&gt;staticFunc); // 10,20,30Function parameters are stored in arguments array: </p>

<p>function baz()
<br/>	echo arguments-&gt;reverse()-&gt;join();</p>

<p>baz(&#39;a&#39;, &#39;b&#39;, &#39;c&#39;); // cbacall and call_array invoke given function (like call_user_func...): </p>

<p>function bar() return &#39;hi&#39;;
<br/>call(&#39;bar&#39;);apply($func, $obj) and apply_array($func, $obj) call a function in context of object $obj, i.e. $obj temporary becomes $this in the function: </p>

<p>class A {
<br/>	function info()
<br/>		puts &#39;***&#39; . $this-&gt;whoami();
<br/>	function whoami()
<br/>		return &quot;object A&quot;;
<br/>}</p>

<p>class B {
<br/>	var $bar = &#39;123&#39;;
<br/>	function whoami()
<br/>		return &quot;object B, bar={@bar}&quot;;
<br/>}</p>

<p>$a = new A;
<br/>$a-&gt;info(); // calls A-&gt;whoami</p>

<p>$b = new B;
<br/>apply($a-&gt;info, $b); // calls B-&gt;whoaminamespacesnamespace Foo { body }Namespace body can contain constant, function and class declarations. Qualified name is looked for in that namespace: </p>

<p>echo Foo::bar();Unqualified name is looked for in current namespace and then globally. global is a namespace and can be referred as such: </p>

<p>echo global::foo;import 
<br/>import  from imports another namespace in the scope of current. </p>

<p>classes@ is a shortcut for $this-&gt; </p>

<p>class A {
<br/>	function __construct($t) @wow = $t + 1;
<br/>}</p>

<p>echo (new A(125))-&gt;wow; // 126In general, -&gt; refers to a class or object, and :: is used for namespaces. For php compatibility, it&#39;s also possible to use :: with global classes. </p>

<p>class GlobClass {
<br/>	var $foo = 10;
<br/>}</p>

<p>echo GlobClass::foo;
<br/>echo GlobClass-&gt;foo; // the same</p>

<p>namespace Foo {
<br/>	class Bar {
<br/>		static $prop;
<br/>		...
<br/>	}
<br/>}</p>

<p>echo Foo::Bar-&gt;prop;extends accepts qualified class names: </p>

<p>class Foo extends OtherNamespace::BarConstants are resolved at run-time, that is, arbitrary expressions are allowed on the right: </p>

<p>const X = foo() + bar();Getters and setters: </p>

<p>class Circle {
<br/>	var $r;</p>

<p>	function __construct($radius)
<br/>		@r = $radius;</p>

<p>	function get area()
<br/>		return 3.1459 * @r * @r;
<br/>	function set area()
<br/>		throw &#39;cannot set area directly&#39;;
<br/>}</p>

<p>$c = new Circle(10);
<br/>echo $c-&gt;area;
<br/>$c-&gt;area = 111;__construct can return a value. If a non-null is returned, it will be taken as the value of &quot;new&quot;. </p>

<p>class GoodFella {}</p>

<p>class Person {
<br/>	function __construct($name) {
<br/>		if($name == &#39;Joe&#39;)
<br/>			return new GoodFella($name);
<br/>	}
<br/>}</p>

<p>echo new Person(&#39;Tom&#39;); // (object Person)
<br/>echo new Person(&#39;Joe&#39;); // (object GoodFella)php interactionAll php functions (system and user) are automatically available to PiHiPi. PiHiPi identifiers take precedence over php ones, to use php function in any case prepend its name with php:: </p>

<p>puts htmlspecialchars($var); // call php function</p>

<p>function mysql_connect() {...}</p>

<p>mysql_connect();       // call my function
<br/>php::mysql_connect();  // call php functionYou can also embed &#39;raw&#39; php code using &#39;unparsed input&#39; brackets {&lt; ... &gt;}: </p>

<p>{&lt;
<br/>	# php code
<br/>	$html = strip_tags($_GET[&#39;msg&#39;]);
<br/>&gt;}standard librarySome of php standard library functions are rewritten in PiHiPi style: each function group is either moved to its own namespace or becomes object-oriented: </p>

<p>// in php: echo strlen...
<br/>echo str::len(&#39;ABC&#39;);</p>

<p>// in php: preg_replace...
<br/>$text = str::replace($html, ``, &#39;&#39;);</p>

<p>// in php: fopen/fread
<br/>$f = new File(&#39;foo&#39;);
<br/>$first_10 = $f-&gt;read(10);</p>

<p>// in php: strtotime/date
<br/>echo (new Date(&#39;+10 days&#39;))-&gt;string(&#39;d M Y&#39;);Here&#39;s a brief example that should give you a better idea on what PiHiPi programming looks like. </p>

<p> MAX_LEN)
<br/>			throw &quot;text is too long&quot;;</p>

<p>		echo &quot;text statistics {new Date}&quot;;</p>

<p>		$chars = [];
<br/>		$words = [];</p>

<p>		foreach(str::split($text) as $chr) {
<br/>			if($chr =~ `[A-Z]`i) {
<br/>				$chr = str::upper($chr);
<br/>				$chars[$chr] = isset $chars[$chr] ? $chars[$chr] + 1 : 1;
<br/>			}
<br/>		}</p>

<p>		if(!$chars-&gt;count())
<br/>			throw &quot;no letters in text&quot;;</p>

<p>		echo &quot;
<br/>Letters by frequency: &quot;;
<br/>		echo $chars-&gt;arsort()-&gt;keys()-&gt;join();</p>

<p>		foreach(str::match($text, `[A-Z]+`i) as $w) {
<br/>			$w = str::upper($w);
<br/>			if(isset $words[$w])
<br/>				$words[$w][1]++;
<br/>			else
<br/>				$words[$w] =  [$w, 1];
<br/>		}</p>

<p>		function sort_words($a, $b)
<br/>			return $b[1]  $a[1] || $a[0]  $b[0];</p>

<p>		echo &quot;
<br/>Words by frequency: &quot;;
<br/>		foreach($words-&gt;sort(&#39;sort_words&#39;) as $w)
<br/>			echo $w-&gt;join (&#39;=&#39;), &#39; &#39;;</p>

<p>	} catch($e)
<br/>	{
<br/>		puts &quot;Error: $e&quot;;
<br/>	}
<br/>}
<br/>echo &quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>	
<br/>		I Love You Love Me Love
<br/>		
<br/>	
<br/>&quot;&quot;&quot;;
<br/>?&gt;missing php featuresgoing to be implemented: </p>

<p>eval and dynamic includes binary arithmetic php5 OOP extensions (public, abstract, interface and friends) references (syntax only) going to be dropped from the language: </p>

<p>${...} syntax backticks as shell_exec &#39;alternative syntax&#39; &#39;declare&#39;</p>

 title : The pixeltoaster Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PixelToaster is a library for C++ programmers who want to write their own software rendering routines, reading and writing to an array of pixels. </p>

<p>You choose between high dynamic range floating point color or 32 bit truecolor and pixeltoaster converts to the native display format automatically. You also get basic keyboard and mouse input and a high resolution timer. </p>

<p>PixelToaster is designed by Glenn Fiedler, author of the PTC, OpenPTC and TinyPTC libraries. </p>

<p>If you liked PTC, you&#39;ll love PixelToaster!</p>
