 title : The pjblog Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PJBlog3 2.8 终于于2008-7-12 发布第一个beta版本。这里要感谢广大Blogger们一直以来对PJBlog的支持。同时还得特别感谢 snail.rison 戒聊 wukangrui 开发协助 以及 论坛所有协助测试的斑斑们、特别感谢 bug Center Team 进行的代码安全检查。 </p>

<p>这里 PJ 话就不多说了，一起来看看PJBlog3更新了什么内容吧。同时也欢迎大家把在安装和升级过程中遇到的问题到论坛反馈， 多谢。 </p>

<p>PJBlog3 系统配置服务器：Windows 2000及IIS5.0以上，需要ADO数据库、FSO、XMLDOM、Adobe.stream、VBScript 5.6以上脚本解释器等系统组件支持，具体请查询网络服务商或查看本机配置。  客户端：支持IE6.0、Mozilla FireFox 1.0、Opear 8、Safari。客户端需要JavaScript脚本支持。    </p>

<p>PJBlog3 版权申明PJBlog3程序版权归作者  陈子舜(PuterJam) 所有。  使用者必须遵循 创作共用（Creative Commons） 协议  你可以免费: 拷贝、分发、呈现和表演当前作品,制作派生作品,但是不得移除 PJBlog2 标识。  非商业用途。 你不可将当前作品用于商业目的。 </p>

<p>主要功能全静态化支持 多浏览器兼容,能够很好得兼容Mozilla,IE等浏览器 功能强大的文章编辑器,同时兼容两种编辑方式.在线编辑器采用FckEditor.  PJBlog3采用的UBB编辑器由Blog作者独立开发.支持自定义面板和CSS.自带HTML转换UBB代码功能  自定义模块.可以自己修改页面上的的布局. 让不懂制作网页的用户也能自己增加和修改页面上的版块.  Skin功能,随时可以给自己的Blog换上新的CSS样式界面  自定义分类.可以同时定制外部连接分类和Blog内置分类.可以自定义分类显示的位置.由用户自己定义顶部导航条和侧边导航条  权限分组.管理员还可以对每个分组成员指定上传文件的权限等等  Blog数据采用缓存方式保存.减轻服务器负担和增加运行速度  用户密码用SHA1算法加密    更新历史★PJBlog3 2.8.5 更新内容★ </p>

<p>后台增加首页预览按钮后台静态化日志时默认选中安静模式 增加日志评论回复功能  增强私密日志功能 增加加密日志功能支持tab分类表现(在当前的分类中增加menuB样式)  增加样式规则，能够更好得区分 quote reply code这些UBB面板 优化缓存清理,让缓存清理更加干净 更新fck编辑器到最新版本 初始化安装的用户增加一个设置向导页面 为html标签增加代码另存为功能 </p>

<p>修正全静态模式更新缓存失败的bug 给UBBPanel增加特殊的 修正menuB失效的问题 修正const.asp里和pjblog2有关的信息 	 修正密码提示能够进行显示和隐藏不允许发表空的回复 修正后台分类管理类别图标选中失败的bug  修正一些bug 私密日志的上一篇下一篇的问题访问计数更新失败的bug ★PJBlog3 2.8 更新内容★ </p>

<p>增加RSD（Really Simple Discoverability）支持 全新的后台控制面板 增加一批新图标 增加静态化过程进度可视化 增加清理服务器缓存 功能 增加wap访问写日志功能 优化翻页的表现 减少ubb编辑器输出的html代码，从而减少代码量。 采用异步方式动态加载ubb编辑器 取消文章列表顶部的翻页 增加全静态化功能 后台增加 静态化可选项 静态页面的动态侧边栏支持304，提高打开速度 静态页面支持访问计数的统计 静态页面支持登录后对简单的权限进行判断 静态页面支持快速登陆评论 增加默认的robots.txt文件。禁止爬虫抓取搜索、注册、登陆等页面 增加document.getElementById的增强缩写形式$()。 为外部网址添加 rel=&quot;external&quot; 属性。 </p>

<p>修正safari无法看评论的问题 修正 feed atom sitemap 路径的问题 修复后台基本设置缺少判断是否为“全动态模式” 修正翻页只有一页的时候不显示页数 修正发表评论可以伪造身份的bug 修正静态页面侧边栏应为插件导致脚本错误的问题 静态页面支持隐藏日志 更新pjblog3的数据库字段 修正删除日志没有删除文件的bug 修正应插件问题导致获取评论和统计失败的bug 修正全动态下连接错误的问题 修正xmlrpc的错误 修复前台删除评论会员统计评论数不减的BUG 修复后台删除留言留言总数及会员统计不减的BUG 增加后台直接删除风格文件夹功能 发表评论时首字不允许为空格或回车 修复留言本验证码漏洞 修复其他的一些小细节 留言本无法使用高级过滤功能 后台取消“发表评论必须输入验证码”设置时，前台发表评论时提示验证码错误的问题 包含“/”符号的过滤规则,高级过滤无效的问题 修正后台模块过滤的bug 修正模板里的隐藏日志图标   </p>

<p>xmlrpc增加 mt.getPostCategories 支持 </p>

<p>特别感谢 snail.rison 戒聊 wukangrui 开发协助 以及 论坛所有协助测试的斑斑们 特别感谢 bug Center Team 进行的代码安全检查</p>
 summary : <p>Pkgman is used to maintain the desired software package state on all of your 
<br/>solaris hosts.  Add the package names to the configuration file and 
<br/>indicate what hosts the package applies to and whether it should be installed  
<br/>or removed.  Run pkgman on a host and point it to the configuration file 
<br/>and pkgman will determine which package records apply to the executing host. 
<br/>For further information please consult the http://pkgman.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/README 
<br/>file which currently contains all of the documentation. 
<br/>To download pkgman you can grab the gzipped tarball marked &quot;latest stable version&quot;  
<br/>from the download list http://code.google.com/p/pkgman/downloads/list.   Currently  
<br/>the name for the gzipped tarball ball is pkgman-.tar.gz.   When you 
<br/>gunzip/untar the archive you will end up with a directory called pkgman-.      
<br/>The README file included in the tar archive has a section titled &quot;INSTALLATION&quot; which   
<br/>covers the details of installing pkgman.   It basically says to execute the command  
<br/>&quot;ruby setup.rb&quot; while you are in the directory created after you unpacked the tarball. 
<br/>   </p>

<p>If you want to check out the source code using subversion you can run the following 
<br/>command. </p>

<p>svn checkout http://pkgman.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ pkgman 
<br/>I&#39;m using a stable trunk method for development.  All changes are made to a branch,  
<br/>tested and then merged  back into the trunk.</p>

 title : The planigle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Planigle is a Ruby on Rails based web application to help in planning Agile software development projects.  It uses Flex for its user interface. </p>

<p>To check out the most recent version, go to www.planigle.com/planigle/ and sign up for your own account.  To view the backlog and give feedback on prioritization, go here.  For any questions, issues or suggestions send email to Planigle Support. </p>

<p>Planigle currently has the following features: </p>

<p>Backlog creation / prioritization Release tracking / planning Iteration planning / tracking  Multi-tenancy (the ability to support multiple projects where project members can only see their own project) Support for multiple team projects</p>
 summary : <p>This tiny Objective-C library allows you to send and receive asynchronous messages between processes or threads akin to the Erlang concurrency approach. </p>

<p>Plankton is thus an actor oriented peer-to-peer platform for asynchronous share-nothing message passing. </p>

<p>Messages can be any Objective-C objects which represent property-lists. Plankton uses the Cocoa property-list encoding for the on-the-wire representation. Message reception is done via the NSPredicate facility of Coca which allows for sophisticated pattern specifications. </p>

<p>Usage of Plankton should be easy: </p>

<p>create a PLPlatform object and cling to it </p>

<p>PLPlatform *platform = [[PLPlatform alloc] init];create your own actor-id NSString *aid = [platform createAid];send a message to another actor (you need its aid for that) [platform send:message to:otherAid];prepare reception of  messages from other actors PLPattern *pattern = [[PLPattern patternWithPredicateFormat:@&quot;SELF in {&#39;quit&#39;, &#39;exit&#39;}&quot;] retain];
<br/>[pattern setMessageTarget:self action:@selector(onQuit:)];
<br/>[platform receive:pattern by:aid];receive messages - (void)onQuit:(id)messsage pattern:(PLPattern *)pattern
<br/>{...}Check out the PLDirectory class on how to use the above API. PLDirectory is a simple directory service actor which communicates with peer directories to look up directory entries. </p>

<p>The code is work in progress. Please check out the Source instead of using any of the outdated zip downloads.</p>
 title : The plankton-platform Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The planningalerts Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The plantae Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Plantae is a web-based database of ecological and evolutionary data for plants. The success and utility of web projects, such as Entrez and Treebase demonstrate the power of collaboration on the submission of and access to data. Our goal for Plantae is that it relieves evolutionary ecologists from the burden of collecting and maintaining private databases of relevant plant traits. Rather, as data is discovered it is submitted to the Plantae project and made available to all researchers. We all gain access to a growing collection of data that is easily searched, annotated, and updated.</p>

<p>Plantae’s creation was guided by three principles to ensure the scientific utility of the project:</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;1. Open access: We do not restrict access to the website for people who want to search or view the plants and their associated traits. Anyone with access to a web browser can benefit from the data within Plantae.
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;2. Collaboration: Plantae’s usefulness increases with researchers’ contributions. Consequently, we encourage people to add data to Plantae. Although we do ask that they register before doing so to track collaborations and provide some control over the database. We also welcome suggestions for the addition of new traits to Plantae. We began with traits that were relevant to our particular research goals, but hope to cover all relevant plant traits with help from the community. Finally, we provide links to other web-based projects (e.g., iSpecies) whenever appropriate to link Plantae’s data with other efforts.
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;3. Scholarship: To ensure that Plantae contains accurate data, we require that each submission be accompanied by a peer-reviewed citation. These citations are managed by Nature Magazine’s Connotea project which further encourages collaboration among the users of Plantae. This decision ensures that any data contained within Plantae is as accurate as the primary literature and the linked citations can be queried for additional information on the study’s design and implementation.</p>

<p>Plantae is written in the Ruby programming language and relies on the Ruby on Rails web framework and sqlite3 database. Consequently, Plantae is constructed with open-source software. Furthermore, the source code for Plantae itself is also governed by an open-source license and available from</p>

 title : The plists Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>plists is a drop-in replacement for the Erlang module lists, making most list operations parallel. It can operate on each element in parallel, for IO-bound operations, on sublists in parallel, for taking advantage of multi-core machines with CPU-bound operations, and across erlang nodes, for parallizing inside a cluster. It handles errors and node failures. It can be configured, tuned, and tweaked to get optimal performance while minimizing overhead. </p>

<p>Almost all the functions are identical to equivalent functions in lists, returning exactly the same result, and having both a form with an identical syntax that operates on each element in parallel and a form which takes an optional &quot;malt&quot;, a specification for how to parallize the operation. </p>

<p>fold is the one exception, parallel fold is different from linear fold. This module also include a simple mapreduce implementation, and the function runmany. All the other functions are implemented with runmany, which is as a generalization of parallel list operations. </p>

<p>Documentation is available at http://freeyourmind.googlepages.com/plists.html, and a blog post with some examples at http://plists.wordpress.com/2007/09/20/introducing-plists-an-erlang-module-for-doing-list-operations-in-parallel/.</p>
 summary : <p>Web proxy server using python and Lisp to support  Artificial Intelligence.</p>

 title : The pluralize-for-gettext Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PluralizeForGettextThis plugin inspects a single string to get pluralization with substitution. The reason I use a single string is to keep it recognizable for gettext or similar i12n plugins. </p>

<p>Although I created this plugin for gettext, it can be used whenever you like. If you&#39;re not using gettext, _(&quot;string&quot;).pluralize_for becomes &quot;string&quot;.pluralize_for... Simple enough... </p>

<p>Please visit http://infx.nl for more information and updates </p>

<p>Installation./script/plugin install http://pluralize-for-gettext.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/And then rename vendor/plugins/svn to vendor/plugins/pluralize_for_gettext </p>

<p>ExamplesA bit better looking: </p>

<p>  &lt;%=_(&#39;No posts ~~ Only one post ~~ You have {$N} posts!&#39;).pluralize_for(Post.count) %&gt;Clearer for the translator: </p>

<p>  &lt;%=_(&#39;~~$N==0: No posts ~~$N==1: Only one post ~~else: You have {$N} posts&#39;).pluralize_for(Post.count)%&gt;Note: The translator can change the logic for this, for languages with weird pluralization rules. ;) Caution: It&#39;s being eval&#39;ed, so always check language files (or ruby code) for any Ruby injections. </p>

<p>Substituting more variablesWhy not use the default sprintf-like function from rails? </p>

<p>  &lt;%_(&#39;You have %d posts, view %s&#39;) % [ Post.count, link_to(_(&#39;more&#39;), view_more_url)%&gt;You&#39;d get multiple entries in you .po file, and just &#39;more&#39; can&#39;t be translated differently according to the context. </p>

<p>More advanced, for entering links </p>

<p>  &lt;%=_(&#39;No posts, create one by clicking {1:here} ~~ Only one post ~~ You have {$N} posts ~~$N&gt;6: You have {$N} posts, view {2:more}&#39;).pluralize_for(Post.count) do |i|
<br/>    i[1] = link_to(i[1], create_post_url) if i[1]
<br/>    i[2] = link_to(i[2], view_more_url) if i[2]
<br/>  %&gt;In the .po file: </p>

<p>  #: app/controllers/some_controller.rb:102
<br/>  msgid &quot;No posts, create one by clicking {1:here} ~~ Only one post ~~ You have {$N} posts ~$N&gt;6~ You have {$N} posts, view {2:more}&quot;
<br/>  msgstr &quot;Geen artikelen, {1:plaats een artikel} ~~ Slechts een artikel ~~ Je hebt {$N} artikelen ~$N&gt;6~ Je hebt {$N} artikelen ({2:bekijk meer...})&quot;The numbers in {1:foo} are the keys for the array you&#39;re given. You can adjust it anyway you like. </p>

<p>Simple pluralizationsPerhaps you just want to specify a singular and plural for one word in the entire sentence: </p>

<p>  &lt;%=_(&#39;You have {$N} {post|posts}&#39;).pluralize_for(Post.count)%&gt;English is simpler than many other languages, so the translator could change it into the more elaborate version: </p>

<p>  #: app/controllers/some_controller.rb:102
<br/>  msgid &quot;You have {$N} {post|posts}&quot;
<br/>  msgstr &quot;~~$N==0: Helemaal geen artikelen ~~$N==1: U heeft een artikel ~~$N&gt;1: U heeft {$N} artikelen&quot;</p>
 title : The plurk4r Open Source Project on Open Hub

<br/>for plurk in p.getPlurks(your_userid):
<br/>    print plurk[&#39;content&#39;]Retrieving Karmap.login(nick_name, password)
<br/>user_info = p.uidToUserinfo(p.uid)
<br/>print &quot;%s has %1.1f karma.&quot; % (p.nickname, user_info[&#39;karma&#39;])And MoreSee the sample code in the sources... </p>

 summary : <p>PocketGuitar is an application which turns your iPhone or iPod touch into a virtual guitar. </p>

<p>ChangeLog0.3.1 (12 Apr 2008)Removed &quot;0th fret&quot; image that appeared on the fretboard 0.3 (10 Apr 2008)Firmware 1.1.3/1.1.4 support Visual refinement 0.2 (26 Jan 2008)Don&#39;t change system volume on startup Added left-handed option Made bass sounds a bit louder, especially for the higher frequency - it&#39;s still hard to hear on very small speakers though. Added &quot;Edit Fretboard&quot; setting where you can adjust the distance between frets, the size of the fretboard and the position of strings. The settings are now stored into disk. Re-implemented exctract_samples script in C so that it no longer requires BSD subsystem. 0.1 (19 Jan 2008)First release Roadmap1.0 (scheduled to be released in July 2008)Port to iPhone OS 2.0 and distribution through the App Store Alternative tunings Configurable distortion and delay effects Ukulele sound &quot;Always Hammer-on&quot; option, which enables you to play it without plucking 1.1Scrollable fretboard, to make higher frets available MIDI output via RTP - http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~lazzaro/rtpmidi/ DiscussionsYou can talk about PocketGuitar in following places: </p>

 title : The pocle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Latest version: Processor of OCL 2.0 expressions v1.3 </p>

<p>Our aim is to develop a tool that converts textual constraints written in the OCL 2.0 language into instances of the OCL 2.0 metamodel. To do this we base our design in the existent tool called Dresden OCL2 Toolkit, from the Dresden University. </p>

<p>By now, our implementation support almost all OCL 2.0 constructions, including the inverse conversion from metamodel instances to textual constraints. </p>

<p>We use as a conceptual modeling environment the EINA GMC tool, which can be found in http://guifre.lsi.upc.edu/eina_GMC/ </p>

<p>Such tool is developed by the GMC Research Group of the Technical University of Catalonia (UPC), from Spain. It provides the possibility of creating and storing metamodel instances into a MDR repository. </p>

<p>The steps of our processor are the followings: </p>

<p>Load an XMI file containing the description of a conceptual schema Write OCL constraints related to the previous schema Parse the OCL expressions Throw error messages if any problem is found during the parsing process If no errors, create instances for the previous constraints into the MDR repository Our project is developed in Java.</p>
 title : The pocogese Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Pocogeseis short for &quot;POST Commands and GET Selections&quot;. </p>

<p>Pocogese implements the concept of Commands and Selections applied to the remote invocation of Services from Adobe Flex applications. This design choice is based on the observation that most Services either read or manipulate Resources.  </p>

<p>Reading is realized by sending GET requests with Selections ; these should not change the state of the Resource requested. Selections return with a single Resource or a list of Resources based on some selection criteria. Manipulation is realized by sending POST requests with Commands ; these change the state of one or multiple Resources. Typical commands include create,update and delete, but any other modifying action can be modeled this way. Commands return with information about the status of the manipulation and may include one result and explanation messages. Current implementation uses POX (Plain Old XML) for data transport. AMF3 could be a future alternative. Take a look at the source </p>

<p>Subproject: Pocogese-RailsPocogese-Rails provides a Ruby on Rails plugin that extends ActiveController to dispatch both commands and selections. In addition, this plugin includes a Rake task to support the generation of Flex controller clients. </p>

<p>After RailsPluginInstall and FlexLibraryInstall, you start with SetupRailsService, then GenerateFlexFromRails and finally CallServiceFromFlex to make it work. </p>

<p>Subproject: Pocogese-JavaPocogese-Java provides a Servlet-based implementation of a controller dispatcher that can handle commands and selections. A Servlet receives invocations which are dispatched to registered !Controllers. In addition, this library includes a FlexGenerator to support the generation of Flex controller clients. </p>

<p>After JavaLibraryInstall and FlexLibraryInstall, you start with SetupJavaService, then GenerateFlexFromJava and finally CallServiceFromFlex to make it work. </p>

<p>Subproject: Pocogese-TestPocogese-Test provides FlexUnit testcases and a TestRunner to test components and classes from Pocogese. Unit tests for other subprojects (Rails and Java) are included in their own project structure. This project requires the flexunit library. </p>

<p>Related ProjectsDunelox - Flex library of application components Dunelox-Flexgen - Flex source generator of models,views,forms and grids from Rails ActiveRecord models. Currently there is no such generator that can process Java classes.</p>

 title : The popforge Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>import de.popforge.*Popforge is an Actionscript 3 code sandbox started by Andre Michelle and Joa Ebert. </p>

<p>PackagesThe Popforge library is the sum of several free time and research activities. Each piece in its own a project itself. </p>

<p>Not all of our projects made it to here. We have a lot in the pipe we want to share with the community but still want to assure high quality content. Currently you will find the audio library sources online. </p>

<p>import de.popforge.audio.*Popforge AS3 audio library allows you to create a valid flash.media.Sound object with your  own samples. This opens up new perspectives for sound design with the current Adobe Flash Player 9. You can create synthesizers, effects and sample-players of any kind. The supplied AudioBuffer class allows you to create endless audio playback. </p>

<p>Future projectsProjects that are not online yet but may be released within the next couple of months. </p>

<p>import de.popforge.imageprocessing.*The ImageProcessing library is mainly a set of filters that allows you to synthesize, modify and analyze images within Flash. There are more than 50 filters and several utilities included. Read more... </p>

<p>import de.popforge.cubicvr.*CubicVR 360° is a Flash 9 panorama viewer with pixel exact rendering which results in high quality pictures and no distortion. It is highly customizable and supports custom keymaps, hotspots, JavaScript interaction and motion blur to name just a few features.</p>
 summary : <p>Popitus is a very simple web jukebox implemented with Ruby on Rails. It doesn&#39;t use music metadata at all (yet) but instead relies on directory hierarchy. An Sqlite3 database is used for storing passwords for authentication. It currently streams mp3, ogg and m4a files.</p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The porte Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Porte has been design to save time and simplify the development of relational database applications written in PHP. </p>

<p>Tired of writting repetitive sql to persist your object in the database, Porte will greatly simplify your life. Porte can retrieve, search and save object without a single line of Sql. We worked hard to deliver a framework natural and easy to use without being over intrusive. </p>

<p>A design goal of Porte was to avoid any external configuration (being XML or others). In its simplest form, create your PHP classes which extends &quot;PorteBase&quot; class, defined the &quot;meta_fields&quot; array and your ready to go. Getter and setter methods as well as a lot more of goodies will be automatically derived from the &quot;meta_fields&quot; settings including associations (many-to-many,one-to-many,one-to-one), events, table migration, hierarchy (nested set model), ordering and validation. </p>

<p>To some extends, Porte is inspired by Martin Fowler concept of Active Records.</p>
 title : The portia-viewer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>portia-viewerThe project is called portia-viewer, and is pronounced &quot;POR-TEE-AH viewer&quot;.  </p>

<p>It is meant as a prototype viewer implementation that is a complement to OpenSimulator.org </p>

<p>Apache 2.0 licensed in order to be as broadly compatible as possible with both business and open source communities. It is compatible with BSD licenses, and with the GPL 3.0. Python-based framework, for prototyping ease, with c++ Ogre rendering engine and c++ networking for performance. PyGTK based GUI FeaturesWe currently have a Wishlist for collecting your ideas! </p>

<p>CommunicationThe mailing list is under Google Groups http://groups.google.com/group/portia-viewer </p>

<p>The IRC channel is on Freenode as #portia-viewer </p>

<p>CommunityWe would like to base our community governance using the example set by the GNOME and Fedora communities. </p>

<p>The GNOME Foundation charter can be found here </p>

<p>The Fedora Board wiki can be found here </p>

<p>We would like to model our development process based on the popular scrum project management method. </p>

<p>We invite you to join us and help make our project a reality. </p>

<p>Source CodeOur source is hosted under SVN, however we strongly recommend you use a distributed version control system that has a SVN gateway, such as git, as allows you to immediately get working on our code, and we may move to such a system in the future.</p>

 title : The postbits Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PostExperiments is a common place for my personal projects related to PostGIS (geographic objects to the PostgreSQL object-relational database). </p>

<p>You are welcomed to share your ideas, post your comments and patches to improve this functions, or send your suggestions directly to the PostGIS development mailing list. </p>

<p>These are just experiments, some things has been committed to the PostGIS trunk and others will be committed soon. </p>

<p>Materialized Views SupportThis is a project sponsored by Google for the Open Source Geospatial Foundation as part of the Summer of Code 2007. </p>

<p>BackgroundPostGIS geometry processing functions consume machine&#39;s CPU resources. This behavior can be avoided creating &#39;snapshots&#39; of data based on views definitions, making queries more light for clients. This is specially useful for web clients.  </p>

<p>Jonathan Gardner have aboard this problem with the concept of Materialized Views. These functions may be improved to support PostGIS functionality when creating, refreshing or deleting views. </p>

<p>ProposalNew functions for: </p>

<p>Add/Modify/Drop simple views Add/Modify/Drop materialized views Materialize simple views Refresh data of materialized views </p>

<p>MilestonesMilestones has been posted on this calendar. </p>

<p>KML outputHistoryWe use PostGIS to store vector data in PostgreSQL databases. This data is exposed in web clients like MapServer or desktop clients like QGIS or uDIG. However, Google Earth have growth as a better desktop client to show this data specially for people who never heard about GIS or maps. </p>

<p>PostGIS lacked of this functionality before version 1.2.1. This feature had been requested for many users but had not been included. At this point is where the magic of Open Source comes. I decided write this piece of code of a function for PostGIS that exposes geometry as KML objects. This code was reviewed by the guys at Refractions and committed on December 2006. Officially, AsKML() appears on 1.2.1 release of PostGIS. </p>

<p>There are many people using this function. Last January I heard of a course implementing this techniques here in Colombia! </p>

<p>AsKML (now ST_AsKML) function do not produce full featured KML documents. It just expose the geometry elements as KML objects to be included in programming interfaces in PHP and other client interfaces supported by PostgreSQL. </p>

<p>AdvantagesExposing &quot;live&quot; data for users. Instead of export static ESRI shapefiles We can create feeds of changing data reflecting live events  Process to convert vector data to KML geometry is done by database UsagePython Php New FeaturesExtrude Tesselate and Altitudemode Support People using ST_AsKMLOnline Soil Survey - California Soil Resource Lab. Press note The Timoney Group   FutureST_AsKML would be extended to support attributes? Adding support for 3D geometries Extrapolate this function to produce valid geometries for GeoRSS and GeoJSON  (Place for adding your own idea!) Mapserver geditSyntax file for highlighting of MapServer .map keywords in the gedit editor </p>

<p>INSTALLDownload the latest version of mapserver.lang: http://postexperiments.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/mapserver/gedit/mapserver.lang 
<br/>Copy mapserver.lang to /usr/share/gtksourceview-2.0/language-specs      sudo cp mapserver.lang /usr/share/gtksourceview-2.0/language-specs/Add mime types to /etc/mime.types      sudo echo -e &quot;application/x-mapserver  map&quot;  | sudo tee -a /etc/mime.types
<br/>     sudo echo -e &quot;application/x-mapserver-sym  sym&quot;  | sudo tee -a /etc/mime.typesUpdate mime types      sudo update-mime-database /usr/share/mimeOpen your mapfile and navigate to View-&gt;Syntax Highlighting-&gt;Other-&gt;MapServer</p>
 title : The postexperiments Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>A golf contest is a programming contest where the winner is the coder who writes the shortest program to complete a task. This tool was designed to help Postscript golfers in golfing competitions such as http://golf.shinh.org. </p>

<p>It reads a postscript program and outputs a new program where tokens are converted to binary form in an attempt to reduce the byte size of the program. Features include: </p>

<p>Unnecessary whitespace is removed. Comments are removed. Operators such as &#39;add&#39; and &#39;length&#39; are reduced to their two byte binary representation. Tokens are not converted to binary if doing so would increase their length. Strings with escape codes such as (\n) are converted to strings containing the equivalent binary characters. Optional mode: binary tokens are not allowed. Limitations: </p>

<p>Embedding data in the program and reading it using (for example) &#39;currentfile 100 string readline&#39; is not handled. For longer files (300 bytes+) it might be worth gzipping the program, but this is not supported. To attempt to reduce the size of a Postscript program, run the following command: </p>

<p>./psgolftool.py &lt; program.ps &gt; program.bin.ps </p>

<p>To disallow binary characters: </p>

<p>./psgolftool.py nobin &lt; program.ps &gt; program.nobin.ps</p>
 title : The postscript-golf-tool Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The Barcode Writer in Pure PostScript Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Barcode Writer in Pure Postscript implements the printing of all major barcode formats entirely within level 2 PostScript, so that the process of converting the input string into the printed output is performed by the printer itself. This avoids the need to re-implement the barcode generation process whenever your language needs change.  </p>

<p>The project supports all major barcode formats.</p>
 title : The postsharp-user-plugins Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Plug-ins and Aspect Libraries contributed by the PostSharp community. </p>

<p>This project currently contains the following components: </p>

<p>Log4PostSharp: trace your programs using a single custom attribute. Log4PostSharp emits optimal instructions for you. Yes, just like hand-tuned code! PostSharp4Unity: Mark classes as configurable and start enjoying Unity without the factory method! Old plain constructor still work. PostSharpAspNet: Enables to use PostSharp in ASP.NET projects even with JIT compilation. DesignByContract: transparently adds preconditions, postconditions and invariant to methods and classes. Just beginning, a lot of work to do. Awareness: makes PostSharp Laos aware of serialization (BinaryFormatter and WCF). GSharp: One of the classic uses of AOP is to automate logging.  But an unfortunate side-effect of logging everywhere is massive log files that are hard to read, hard to dig around in, and sometimes hard to just open without running out of memory. GSharp aspects let you trace your programs as well as log exceptions and profile performance.  You can then analyze and graph your data with Gibraltar.</p>
 summary : <p>Enhances the Spring.NET framework by build-time assembly enhancement using PostSharp. </p>

<p>If you want to contribute to this project, please write a message using the form http://www.postsharp.org/author/gfraiteur (communicate your Google account name).</p>

 summary : <p>Ruby bindings for the Pownce API. Providers abstraction layer over HTTP communications and xml/json seralization. Allows user to deal with native ruby objects. </p>

<p>notes = Note.find(:one, :from =&gt; &#39;/public_note_lists.xml&#39;, :params =&gt;  {:limit =&gt; 5})  </p>

<p>notes.note.length   =&gt; 5  </p>

<p>User.find(&#39;eggie5&#39;).blurb    =&gt; &quot;fighting javascript everyday.&quot;  </p>

<p>Note.find(1, :params=&gt;{:show_replies =&gt; &#39;false&#39;})  </p>

<p>User.find(:one, :from =&gt; &#39;/users/eggie5/friends.xml&#39;)  </p>

<p>User.find(:one, :from =&gt; &#39;/users/eggie5/fans.xml&#39;)  </p>

 title : The prawks Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Prawks is a library that allows you to express parameterized SQL and stored procedures as managed code functions (in C# or Visual Basic) using Microsoft&#39;s .NET Framework. Like Platform Invoke (P/Invoke), Prawks allows one to call stored procedures and parameterized SQL in a database by defining a compatible method definition and signature in managed code. Prawks does not rely on templates or scriptable code generators. Instead, it simply makes use of the innovative features of the Common Language Runtime (CLR) like metadata, reflection services, custom attributes and dynamic code emission to implement the boilerplate data access front.</p>
 title : The praxis-escola Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The precho Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Precho is a Ruby on Rails-based online music library, designed for streaming large music collections anywhere in the world.</p>
 summary : <p>Precipitate lets you search for and launch the information you have stored in the cloud from within Spotlight or Google Desktop for Mac. It currently supports the following services: </p>

<p>Google Docs (including Google Apps accounts) Google Bookmarks Picasa Web Albums </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Precipitate works by creating files on your machine that are imported by Spotlight, then periodically checking in with the server and updating the local files to reflect any changes. Note that changes may take up to an hour to be visible in local searches. </p>

<p>Installation and SetupOpen the Precipitate preference pane, and install it either for yourself or for all users. Enter your Google account information into the preference pane, check the box for each service you want to make searchable, then press &quot;Refresh Now&quot; to start the initial import (note that this may take some time, depending on how much data you have). Then just start searching! </p>

<p>Current versions of Precipitate require OS X 10.5 or later. 10.4 users should download 1.0.5</p>

 title : The predictions-league-3 Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The predtex Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>El texto predictivo es una tecnología de entrada diseñada para teléfonos móviles. Está tecnología permite formar palabras presionando un único botón por cada letra, al contrario de presionar varias veces cada tecla hasta obtener la letra deseada. La aplicación principal de esta tecnología es simplificar la escritura de mensajes de texto. </p>

<p>Los algoritmos de texto predictivo utilizan un conjunto de textos de referencia (corpus) de los que se extrae información de tipo probabilístico sobre las palabras. Cuando el usuario presiona los botones del móvil, se busca entre todas las palabras posibles que concuerdan con la combinación presionada, y se muestra la opción más probable. El usuario puede confirmar la selección y continuar con la siguiente palabra o usar una tecla para ver las otras combinaciones posibles.</p>
 title : The prefetch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project aims at providing complete Linux solution for prefetching data necessary for fast start of application (and the whole system during boot). </p>

<p>Information about progress of implementation during Google Summer of Code 2007 is on Soc2007Progress page. However this project is aimed at general prefetching solution for Linux, so anyone interested in prefetching is welcome to join in - please register in our prefetch-devel mailing list and introduce yourself. </p>

<p>Introduction to prefetching along with introductory notes is on Introduction page. </p>

<p>Quick links: </p>

<p>Comparison of prefetch to readahead Design of prefetch Documentation for prefetch Bibliography with links to interesting topics to read on prefetching. </p>

<p>This project is registered in Launchpad: https://launchpad.net/prefetch </p>

<p>News2008-08-17: kernel and userspace tools are available in prefetch PPA (https://launchpad.net/~prefetch/+archive) 2008-05-22: Scott James Remnant prepared kernel deb for Hardy (available at: http://people.ubuntu.com/~scott/prefetch/) Getting prefetchSee TestingBootPrefetching page for details how to install prefetch. </p>

<p>Please report problems and successes in Launchpad Answers or by sending e-mail to prefetch-users@googlegroups.com (no subscription/registration necessary)</p>

 title : The prelude-csharp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Prelude is a &quot;self-learning&quot;, i.e. teachable chatbot, which has been developed by Lennart Lopin. </p>

<p>It uses a simple yet surprisingly well working approach to create chatbots, which do not depend on pre-fabricated knowledge. preLude </p>

<p>Prelude learns while chatting with the user and applies a stunning algorithm to enable the Bot to chose a response he himself &quot;thinks&quot; appropriate. </p>

<p>It can be applied to any language and will quickly gain conversational skills as its memory expands. 2006 chatterbox challenge 3rd prizeIn 2005 Prelude even won the 3rd prize at the international    contest &quot;Chatterbox Challenge&quot; scoring high as being on of the best self-learning chatbots. </p>

<p>Though the work on Prelude was inspired by various self-learning chatbots like Leo it is based on a complete new approach. </p>

<p>Homepage: http://prelude.lennart-lopin.de 
<br/> Fan Site: http://groups.google.com/group/prelude-csharp  (screenshots, chat logs) </p>

<p>Tags: AI, chatbot, chatterbot, prelude, prelude-ai </p>

 title : The prettyflash Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PrettyFlash
<br/>===========</p>

<p>A nice and DRY sort of way of displaying your flash[:notice] or flash[:error].  Major credit to doing this type of thing in the first place to the crew at JadedPixel.  They are doing this in Shopify (http://www.shopify.com), which is an awesome product.  And also in the open source forum software they made called Opinion.  I recommend checking both out.</p>

<p>Just install the plugin:</p>

<p>ruby script/plugin install http://prettyflash.googlecode.com/svn/pretty_flash/</p>

<p>And as long as you have the default javascript include tag () in your layouts header, you will start seeing pretty DHTML flash notices and errors whenever you stick something in flash[:error] or flash[:notice] and render a javascript update or an entire page.</p>

<p>I leave it up to you though to have to delete all your  blocks. :)</p>

<p>If you don&#39;t like it just:</p>

<p>ruby script/plugin remove pretty_flash</p>

<p>If you want to update it please feel free to touch the pretty_flash.css and pretty_flash_ie.css files.  Let me know how it shakes out.</p>

<p>- Nate @ http://code.inklingmarkets.com</p>

 title : The proaudio Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>As of 14th May 2009, we are in the phase of migrating to http://archaudio.org as we port most of the packages here. At this point of time, updates may only be available from the AUR and the packages&#39; respective maintainers there. However, you may continue to post bug reports here as we don&#39;t yet have a proper framework for that at the new site. We apologise for the inconvenience, if any at all. </p>

<p>These packages are not supported by Arch Linux. This is a third-party community project compatible with the Arch Linux repositories including unsupported (AUR), but excluding testing (at the moment at least). We also upload our packages to the AUR, but due to the dependency on one maintainer, we provide the central location where a team of community members can develop and maintain them together. </p>

<p>The emphasis is on providing the latest releases (and techonology where applicable) in a timely fashion via a rolling-release schedule, based on Subversion checkouts and comfortable user-developer interaction via the Google Code project management facilities. Currently there are two binary mirrors, of which one may not be online. These mirrors, however, will not always be up-to-date and may contain other packages. </p>

<p>We cater to software that are recognised as being useful for audio/music engineering/production, and aid other Arch Linux package maintainers/developers of such software by uploading updated versions of their packages when they are broken (users are unable to build themselves) and out-of-date. Another reason for hosting packages already being maintained by an Arch Linux developer or Trusted User is different resulting binaries due to different configurations. </p>

<p>We will also be providing the latest releases of possibly untested and unstable software that may qualify as being important for a working environment (eg. freebob, ffado). As such, not all of these packages will build or work as expected. </p>

<p>Download details are available on the &quot;Source&quot; link above and you can ask questions in the proaudio-users group, or get more involved with packaging and apply for upload privileges in proaudio-devel. There is also an IRC chat group #archlinux-proaudio on the irc.freenode.org network and an ongoing discussion thread in the Arch Linux forums. Have a look at the Source page for a partial list of packages (the command below will list all of them), we look forward to your reports, ideas and suggestions. </p>

<p>~$ svn list http://proaudio.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Note: To have upload privileges you will need a Google ID (eg. Gmail) and then notify us that you want to be added as a project member, after which you can log in to this page and view your SVN password from the &quot;Settings&quot; link. Not many users have the need for these software, but even so, we would appreciate it if you could help keep the project active - and most importantly - updated.</p>

 title : The profesor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Projekt pro indukci uživatelských preferencí., </p>
 summary : <p>What is ProfitPy?ProfitPy is a set of libraries and tools for the development, testing, and execution of automated stock trading systems Specifically, ProfitPy is a collection of Python packages, modules, and scripts that work together to help you implement an automated stock trading program (or programs). The package features:  </p>

<p>A library with classes for accounts, orders, tickers, and more A GUI program for executing and plotting trades in real-time A GUI tool to collect ticker data for off-line use A CLI tool to back-test trading strategies Dozens of technical indicators and plotting widgets to display them An X11 keystroke tool for automating the TWS application No, really, what is it?ProfitPy is my trading toolkit. I use its collector tool to gather data from IB TWS. Using this data, I run the coverage tool to test my trading strategies. Once I&#39;m happy with a strategy, it gets executed with the main GUI program.  </p>

<p>I don&#39;t include any trading strategies that work -- those are for you to write.  </p>

<p>This toolkit only works with one broker, Interactive Brokers. Their TWS application and its API, along with crazy-low commissions and fees, make for many, many trading opportunities.</p>

 title : The profyframework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PROFY FRAMEWORK is a PHP Framework designed to use inside highload web sites and projects. </p>

<p>It is used in several projects with more than 1 million dynamic page views per day. </p>

<p>System requirements: PHP 4.3+ (Yes, we know and use PHP5, but this is not a requirement for most parts of code), MySQL 4.1+ (For working with Framework as CMS). </p>

<p>Framework has inbuilt web-based installer (used for rapid application development by our team). We also use it for testing and displying availiable features. </p>

<p>How to install sample website based on PROFY FRAMEWORK: </p>

<p>You need to put PROFY_FRAMEWORK somewhere onto your hard drive (ex. /usr/local/share/PROFY_FRAMEWORK/) extracting from archive downloaded from this site or by using &quot;svn checkout http://profyframework.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ /usr/local/share/PROFY_FRAMEWORK&quot;. Copy file &quot;PROFY_FRAMEWORK/INSTALL/install.php&quot; into any folder availiable through your web-server (ex. &quot;/var/www/test/install.php&quot;) Call it from web browser (ex. http://localhost/test/install.php) and follow installer instuctions. You will receive fully functional website with lot of features ready for use or modifications.</p>

 title : The project-z Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project Z is a system for testing agent-based goal seeking strategies in a simple and intuitive game world. </p>

<p>Project Z&#39;s main components: </p>

<p>ProblemDescription - an intro to the problem for players that describes the game world, the space of agent moves, and provides a brief implementation language agnostic game walk-through. SampleServer - an implementation fo the server side of both the WorldStateProtocol and the ActorProtocol that can be used for testing by participants as well as evaluation by event organizers DevKit packages - development materials that abstract away dealing with client-server communications allowing for a lower barrier-to-entry for novice participants.  Kits also contain sample agent implementations for moving randomly (ExampleRandomAgentOutput) and simple straight-line goal seeking (ExampleSmartAgentOutput). Currently available for: C with libc, Java, Ruby, Perl, and Python.  For more detail see LanguageSupport. FancyDisplay - a sample display implementation for more audience-driven events designed to maximize cuteness.  uses Danc&#39;s Miraculously Flexible Game Prototyping Tiles art by Daniel Cook (Lostgarden.com)  JoystickAgent - a sample agent that allows for one of the game participants to be controlled by a human with a game input pad SubmissionController - a sample back-end submission handler that runs agents against each other and reports results.</p>

 title : The projectguardian Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project will record electrocardiogram or pulse data of wheelchair-bound patients who have returned home after surgery. The remote unit uses an amplifier and analog-to-digital converter to record the electrical activity of the heart and a GPS receiver to record location data. This device will log the data and send it to our central server any time that it is within range of a wifi access point. </p>

 title : The projectzombie Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project Zombie: </p>

<p>Project zombie is a game based on the simulation of zombies on the GPU. Graphics will be simple. However, we will strive to make the graphics &quot;interesting looking.&quot; With regard to the term &quot;interesting looking,&quot; an inspiration of ours is the game Darwina. We are not saying our game&#39;s graphics will be based on the Darwina look, but rather, we try to achieve the idea presented in Darwina. We believe Darwina has that particular &quot;simplistic but interesting&quot; notion, which we hope to emulate.  </p>

<p>Another goal of PZ will be the implementation of cellular automaton based effects; we use CA to fake physical based effects, effects that affect the environment, in &quot;interesting&quot; ways. </p>

<p>Finally, our ultimate goal is to create an interesting game where the player battles massive hordes of zombie. We hope by injecting massive crowds, we will see emergent based game-play. This is our hope! Hence the reason for this project, to experiment!</p>

 title : The projfin-nsis Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Sinalização de QoS no Modelo RM Diffserv é um tema de projeto de fim de curso, do Curso Superior de Tecnologia em Sistemas de Telecomunicações </p>

<p>Este projeto visa implantar uma arquitetura de sinalização para o modelo RM Diffserv e integrá-la com um controle de admissão e controle de recursos a ser implementado através de simulação de gerenciamento. </p>

<p>O modelo DiffServ (Serviços diferenciados) provê diferenciação de fluxos, manipulando diferentes classes de tráfego. Fluxos individuais são agregados e associados a uma classe de tráfego, permitindo escalabilidade dos serviços na rede. </p>

<p>O DiffServ cria domínios, conjunto de roteadores, que disponibilizam serviços diferenciados de comunicação IP. A marcação da Qos é feita utilizando os bits TOS do IPv4 e os roteadores utilizam esses bits para identificar como os pacotes serão tratados na rede. </p>

<p>Para o gerenciamento do DiffServ, utilizaremos o RM Diffserv, que é uma proposição para o gerenciamento dinâmico de domínios diffserv. Ela preenche a lacuna apontada anteriormente no modelo diffserv no sentido de permitir a alocação eficiente de recursos em um domínio. </p>

<p>EtapasEstudar o modelo de QoS RM Diffserv; </p>

<p>Meta: Documento resumo do RM DiffservEstudar o protocolo de sinalização NSIS; </p>

<p>Meta: Documento resumo do NSISInstalar e aprender a utilizar uma implementação do NSIS, testando cenários básicos a serem definidos; </p>

<p>Meta: Scripts com cenários básicos de reserva funcionando e documento sobre a instalação e com explicação dos cenáriosDefinir o perfil de QoS para representação de fluxos individuais; </p>

<p>Meta: Documento descrevendo o QSPEC e colocando exemplos de sua utilizaçãoProjetar e implementar as entidades NSIS das bordas e do interior do domínio RM diffserv; </p>

<p>Meta: Projeto formalizado e implementação funcionando.Integrar e testar a arquitetura de sinalização com o sistema de controle de admissão nos roteadores; </p>

<p>Meta: Sistema funcionando e documento de testesRedação final do trabalho. </p>

<p>Meta: Redação final do trabalho.AutorRodrigo Ramiro Muniz Junior</p>

 summary : <p>todo, </p>

 title : The propmansheet Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Ruby on rails (RoR)Propmansheet is a Ruby on Rails spreadsheet. It was developed using &quot;active scaffolds&quot; for the British Red Cross in London. </p>

<p>Screen print </p>

<p>Propman by Grosvenor systemsIt makes it easier for property professionals to present and input property analysis and key note data into a Grosvenor Systems Propman property accounting system. </p>

<p>SpreadsheetThe spreadsheet is a web page that mirrors a current property excel spreadsheets. The data can be updated; new row can be added; sorted; filtered; sub-totaled; reformatted in to a Propman import file and reported on using Business Objects Crystal Report writer or Excel. </p>

<p>Easy Export to External DatabaseThe application can format data into a several keynote or analysis input files which can be easily used (after verification by Propman) to update a live instance of Propman, the property database. </p>

<p>Open SourceThe spreadsheet is very flexible as once the basic concepts are understood it can be modified to cope with many different situations.</p>

 title : The protobuf-actionscript Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The protobuf-c Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewThis package provides a code generator and runtime libraries to use Protocol Buffers from pure C (not C++). </p>

<p>It uses a modified version of protoc called protoc-c. </p>

<p>NewsMar 17, 2010protobuf-c 0.13 is released </p>

<p>Fix for when the number of connections gets too great in RPC.  (Leszek Swirski) (&amp;nbsp;issue #32&amp;nbsp;) Add --disable-protoc to only build libprotobuf-c (daveb) Bug fixes for protobuf_c_enum_descriptor_get_value_by_name() and protobuf_c_service_descriptor_get_method_by_name() use generated initialization function from protobuf_c_message_unpack(), a small optimization (daveb) implement protobuf_c_{client,server}_set_error_handler() </p>

<p>Jan 24, 2010 protobuf-c 0.12 is released </p>

<p>fixes some compilation bugs and big-endian platform issues (thanks, everyone!) adds protobuf_c_message_init() (thanks to Andrei Nigmatulin for this work) </p>

<p>Jun 11, 2009protobuf-c 0.11 is released. </p>

<p>mostly compilation fixes for new versions of g++ and protobuf, and a few other compilation issues (e.g. const correctness)  (Many thanks to dcreager, XXX name others) handle a few integer overflow situations a little better (unlikely to occur -- requires unpacking a huge message) no binary or source incompatibilities -- don&#39;t bother upgrading unless you are experiencing build problems </p>

<p>Apr 4, 2009protobuf-c 0.10 is released (don&#39;t ask about 0.9...) </p>

<p>several bug fixes for corruption and build issues numerous fixes to the RPC system generated source-incompatibility for service/rpc users:  you must re-run protoc-c (those using 0.9 or 10beta already have the new code-generator). credits: (thanks!) Jason Lunz for his allocation failure fixes (including excellent test code) Landon Fuller for his corruption test-cases and fixes. </p>

<p>Jan 29, 2009protobuf-c 0.8 is released </p>

<p>bugs fixed in service invocation; handle NULL in certain required fields (issues 12 and 13) An RPC_System is included, with tests and examples.  It&#39;s in beta, so be a little careful. </p>

<p>Dec 17, 2008protobuf-c 0.7 is released.  This is a bug fix release, it does not break any compatibility. </p>

<p>Bugs fixed: </p>

<p>fixes minor compilation issues (see issues 10 and 11 in the tracker) fixes a long-standing memory leak where unknown fields are not freed by free_unpacked() </p>

<p>Nov 30, 2008protobuf-c 0.6 is released.  It breaks binary and generated-source compatibility:  you must re-run protoc-c to generate new .pb-c.h and .pb-c.c files. </p>

<p>The new features of 0.6 are: </p>

<p>default values now set correctly For each message type, we generate a message__init(Message *) function.  This function never allocates memory, and is equivalent to using the MESSAGE__INIT macro. </p>

<p>DocumentationSee our wiki for documentation. </p>

<p>StatusThe message serialization and deserialization code has been thoroughly tested. Still designing the Service stuff, so be careful about using it. Need to decide what to do about extensions CaveatsSome binary compatibility changes are expected until version 1.0 is released; so make sure you are linking to the protobuf-c that corresponds to the generated code you are using! </p>

<p>Extensions are not implemented.   Need to decide what to implement (any ideas?).  (As of Jun 20, 2009, there are no complaints about this) </p>

<p>Groups are not implemented, and possibly I never will bother, since they are deprecated. </p>

<p>Repeated fields do not obey the &quot;packed&quot; option.  (I INTEND TO FIX THIS, BUT PATCHES TO THIS EFFECT WOULD BE APPRECIATED VERY MUCH) </p>

<p>AuthorDave Benson</p>
 title : The protobuf-js Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>NOTE: This project is just started and very experimental one. The functionalities are extremely limited and some of them may be completely changed in future editions. </p>

<p>What&#39;s this?`protobuf-js&#39; is a Protocol Buffers encoder/decoder for Javascript. </p>

<p>Would you like to try?download ruby bin/start_server.rb access http://yourserver:10080/ click the `Decode!&#39; button see the decoded message What&#39;s happen?Your browser downloaded data/sample.bin encoded by ruby-protobuf and then protobuf-js decoded the binary message. </p>

 title : The protobuf-mercury Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a Mercury backend for the Google protocol buffers compiler. </p>

<p>What it doesProtocol buffers allow you to define an extensible binary protocol format in a language-independent .proto file.  The protocol buffer compiler then compiles your .proto file into one of several target languages.  The generated API gives you a type-safe way to read or write messages in your protocol using your preferred language(s). </p>

<p>This extension generates a Mercury API for a protocol defined in a .proto file. </p>

<p>ExampleSay you define the following protocol in person.proto: </p>

<p>enum Gender {
<br/>    MALE = 0;
<br/>    FEMALE = 1;
<br/>}</p>

<p>enum MaritalStatus {
<br/>    MARRIED = 0;
<br/>    SINGLE = 1;
<br/>}</p>

<p>message Person {
<br/>    required int32 id = 1;
<br/>    required string name = 2;
<br/>    required Gender gender = 3;
<br/>    required double double= 4;
<br/>    optional string email = 5;
<br/>    optional MaritalStatus marital_status = 6 [default = SINGLE];
<br/>    repeated Person children = 7;
<br/>}Then you can generate the Mercury module person.m with the command: </p>

<p>mprotoc person.proto --out .The generated module will contain the following types and functions: </p>

<p>:- type person
<br/>    ---&gt;    person(
<br/>                person_id :: int,
<br/>                person_name :: string,
<br/>                person_gender :: gender,
<br/>                person_double :: float,
<br/>                person_email :: maybe(string),
<br/>                person_marital_status :: maybe(marital_status),
<br/>                person_children :: list(person)
<br/>            ).</p>

<p>:- func person_email_or_default(person) = string.</p>

<p>:- func person_marital_status_or_default(person) = marital_status.</p>

<p>:- type gender
<br/>    ---&gt;    gender_male
<br/>    ;       gender_female.</p>

<p>:- type marital_status
<br/>    ---&gt;    marital_status_married
<br/>    ;       marital_status_single.You can write values of type person to binary streams.  For example: </p>

<p>    Person = person( 
<br/>        1, &quot;Peter Pan&quot;, gender_male, 1.8, yes(&quot;pp@neverland.org&quot;), no,
<br/>            [
<br/>                person(2, &quot;Peter Pan Jnr.&quot;, gender_male, 0.5, no,
<br/>                    yes(marital_status_single), [])
<br/>            ]),
<br/>    stream.put(pb_writer(Stream), pb_message(Person), !IO),You can also read values of type person from binary streams.  For example: </p>

<p>    stream.get(pb_reader(Stream, 10000), GetRes, !IO),
<br/>    ( GetRes = ok(pb_message(Person)),
<br/>        % Do something with Person...</p>
 title : The protobuf-net Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>protobuf-net is a C#/.NET &quot;protocol buffers&quot; implementation that adopts .NET idioms. It provides fast and efficient binary serialization using a cross-platform open format, and supports most common .NET patterns.</p>
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The protobuf-perlxs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Protocol Buffers for Perl/XSThis project contains a Perl/XS code generator for Google&#39;s  Protocol Buffers.  The generated code is an XS wrapper around the generated C++ classes, and includes POD documentation for each message type. </p>

<p>Getting StartedLet&#39;s assume that you already know what Protocol Buffers are, and have downloaded, built, and installed the main protobuf package.  This gives you the core code generators (in particular, the C++ code generator, which we need), as well as various header files and the libprotoc library.  These are all dependencies for protobuf-perlxs, so you need to be sure that they&#39;re installed. </p>

<p>Next, download and install the protobuf-perlxs code: </p>

<p> wget http://protobuf-perlxs.googlecode.com/files/protobuf-perlxs-1.0.tar.gz
<br/> tar zxf protobuf-perlxs-1.0.tar.gz
<br/> cd protobuf-perlxs-1.0
<br/> ./configure --with-protobuf=/usr/local
<br/> make
<br/> sudo make installIn the sample instructions above, we assume that your protobuf headers and libraries are installed under /usr/local.  If you&#39;ve installed them under /usr, you don&#39;t need the --with-protobuf argument. </p>

<p>Once you&#39;ve installed protobuf-perlxs, you can invoke the protoxs executable, which gives you the ability to generate Perl/XS wrapper interfaces to protobuf messages.  To see a simple example, try this after you&#39;ve installed protoxs: </p>

<p> cd examples/simple
<br/> perl Makefile.PL
<br/> make
<br/> make testThis example gives you a Perl interface to the following message definition: </p>

<p> message Person {
<br/>   required int32 id = 1;
<br/>   required string name = 2;
<br/>   optional string email = 3;
<br/> }You can read the generated POD documentation for the Person message in the usual way: </p>

<p> perldoc PersonThis documentation shows you what constructors and methods are available for that message type.  Typical usage for the simple example we&#39;re using here might be something like the following: </p>

<p>    #!/usr/bin/perl</p>

<p>    use strict;
<br/>    use warnings;
<br/>    use Person;</p>

<p>    my $person = Person-&gt;new;</p>

<p>    # Set each of the fields.</p>

<p>    $person-&gt;set_id($id);
<br/>    $person-&gt;set_name($name);
<br/>    $person-&gt;set_email($email);</p>

<p>    # Serialize the object to a string.</p>

<p>    my $packed = $person-&gt;pack();</p>

<p>    # Clear the object contents.</p>

<p>    $person-&gt;clear();</p>

<p>    # Deserialize the object from the string.</p>

<p>    $person-&gt;unpack($packed);</p>

<p>    # Get each of the fields.</p>

<p>    $id = $person-&gt;id();
<br/>    $name = $person-&gt;name();
<br/>    $email = $person-&gt;email();This is a contrived example.  However, the performance is quite good.  It takes only 0.2 seconds for 10,000 iterations through the Perl code shown above (20 microseconds per iteration) on a 3.2 GHz Pentium 4 CPU, whereas the same number of Storable freeze/thaw iterations on the same data takes 0.7 seconds.  Storable is the fastest general-purpose Perl serialization module, and it is outperformed here by a considerable margin.   </p>

<p>How you can use itReally, this is up to you.  You have to decide whether you are willing to tolerate the extra work that is required in order to get your Perl/XS interfaces up and running.  If you prefer to work in a pure-Perl environment without any XS code, you may want to have a look at the protobuf-perl project. </p>

<p>If you want the best performance possible and are willing to jump through some extra hoops to get it, read on.  Depending on the sophistication of your usage of Protocol Buffers, you have a few options: </p>

<p>Entry levelYou can generate and compile Perl/XS and C++ code together from protobuf message definitions.  This is the approach taken in the example that is supplied with the source code.  A single call to protoxs on a single message definition generates all of the source files that are needed, and a fairly simple Makefile.PL can be used to build the Perl package.  In fact, with the person.proto message definition shown above, the corresponding Makefile.PL can be reproduced here in its entirety: </p>

<p>use ExtUtils::MakeMaker;</p>

<p>$CC = &#39;g++&#39;;</p>

<p># Generate the C++, XS, and Perl files that we need.</p>

<p>my $protoxs = &quot;protoxs --cpp_out=. --out=. person.proto&quot;;</p>

<p>print &quot;Generating C++ and Perl/XS sources...\n&quot;;
<br/>print &quot;$protoxs\n&quot;;</p>

<p>`$protoxs`;</p>

<p># Now write the Makefile.</p>

<p>WriteMakefile(
<br/>              &#39;NAME&#39;          =&gt; &#39;Person&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;VERSION_FROM&#39;  =&gt; &#39;Person.pm&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;OPTIMIZE&#39;      =&gt; &#39;-O2 -Wall&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;CC&#39;            =&gt; $CC,
<br/>              &#39;LD&#39;            =&gt; &#39;$(CC)&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;CCFLAGS&#39;       =&gt; &#39;-fno-strict-aliasing&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;OBJECT&#39;        =&gt; &#39;person.pb.o Person.o&#39;,
<br/>              &#39;TYPEMAPS&#39;      =&gt; [&#39;Person.typemap&#39;],
<br/>              &#39;INC&#39;           =&gt;  &quot; -I/usr/local/include&quot;,
<br/>              &#39;LIBS&#39;          =&gt; [&quot; -L/usr/local/lib -lprotobuf&quot;],
<br/>              &#39;XSOPT&#39;         =&gt; &#39;-C++&#39;,
<br/>              clean           =&gt; { FILES =&gt; &quot;Person.* person.pb.* lib&quot; }
<br/>             );
<br/>Next levelWhile the entry level approach might get you started, you may find at a certain point that your messages start having dependencies on other messages (imports).  If you have multiple &quot;top-level&quot; message types that share dependency on one or more other message types, the entry level compilation method will result in duplicate copies of the dependent code.  This is not a fatal problem, as the Perl/XS modules are built into dynamic objects that are dlopened by the Perl interpreter.  You should not run into any symbol conflicts.  However, you may wish instead to build a shared library out of the generated C++ code, and link your Perl/XS wrapper code with this shared library.  In this case, you will need to generate and compile the C++ shared object first, then generate, compile, and link the Perl/XS wrapper.  Since I myself am still at the Entry level with Protocol Buffers, I do not yet have an example of this &quot;Next level&quot; approach. </p>

<p>What works nowAs of now, all of the data types are supported, including enums and embedded messages.  Imports are also supported. </p>

<p>What doesn&#39;t work yetExtensions are not yet supported, nor is the RPC interface.  I plan to add support for Extensions next.  After that, I will look at the RPC interface. </p>

<p>Other things that need to be addedWe have been assigned a field ID of 1001 for custom options in protobuf-perlxs.  This will make it possible to specify file-level, message-level, and even field-level options that are recognized by protobuf-perlxs.  As of now, we have an immediate need to use these custom options, since more sophisticated package and message layouts in Perl/XS will require the suppression of certain .pm files from the output, the generation of others, and so on.  There will undoubtedly be other reasons to use custom options to customize the behavior of protobuf-perlxs on the .proto files that it processes.</p>

 title : The protocol-buffers-actionscript Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ImportantAs I have been inactive as of late with this project, some other ambitious people have taken it upon themselves to expand this project, they can be found here: http://code.google.com/p/protobuf-actionscript3/ </p>

<p>SummaryCreating the neccessary library files and code generation methods to have a decent implementation of Protocol Buffers for ActionScript. </p>

<p>Current ImplementationAlready in place is the ability to compile a basic proto message into a valid actionscript3 file(s). So far there is support for the following: </p>

<p> primitive fields: String, Boolean, int, Number, uint  all labels: required, optional, repeated  Messages consisting of embedded messages  conformity to IDataInput/IDataOutput Todo List merging messages together  implementation of Enums  extensions  services  implementation of more protobuf methods  compiler options and package assigning Current Project SituationSource available, snapshot download available </p>

<p>ThanksMany thanks to isee systems for letting me work on this during their time.</p>

<p>A Simple Messageusing System;

<p>//Based on http://code.google.com/apis/protocolbuffers/docs/encoding.html &quot;A Simple Message&quot;

<br/>            new MessageWriter(encoded).WriteMessage(new Test1() { A = 150 });
<br/>            Console.Write(&quot;Encoded = {&quot;);//Expected 08 96 01
<br/>            var sep = string.Empty;
<br/>            Array.ForEach(en</p>
