 title : The proxy-revealer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a port of Proxy Revealer 2.0.1 MOD (phpBB2) to phpBB3. Attempts to determine someone&#39;s &quot;real&quot; IP address, using a myriad of techniques, and &quot;blocks&quot; such people. Original techniques included XSS, Java, and X_FORWARDED_FOR checks. In this port, Flash has been added as yet another unmasking technique. There maybe additional techniques added on later. </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>HTTP(S)/SOCKS Proxy Detection by Flash and Java applet techniques, and optional blocking. Optional blocking of transparent HTTP Proxies detected with X_FORWARDED_FOR technique. CGI-Proxy Detection by XSS and Flash techniques, and optional blocking. Optional auto-banning of unmasked IP addresses with the chosen blocking techniques above. Blocking/Banning done within the confines of phpBB3&#39;s &quot;Session IP Validation&quot; setting in the ACP. Auto-Logging masked/unmasked IP addresses with possible extended info if Flash/Java was used. Optional Exception List Management for excluding particular proxy servers you may be running. Project&#39;s Home and discussion thread: http://www.phpbb.com/community/viewtopic.php?f=70&amp;t=1174765&amp;start=0</p>
 title : The proxy6151 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>#!/usr/bin/perl -- # #   CGIProxy 2.0.1 # #   nph-proxy.cgi-- CGIProxy 2.0.1: a proxy in the form of a CGI script. #     Retrieves the resource at any HTTP or FTP URL, updating embedded URLs #     in HTML resources to point back through this script.  By default, no #     user info is sent to the server.  Options include text-only proxying #     to save bandwidth, cookie filtering, ad filtering, script removal, #     user-defined encoding of the target URL, and more.  Requires Perl 5. # #   Copyright (C) 1996, 1998-2002 by James Marshall, james@jmarshall.com #   All rights reserved. # #   For the latest, see http://www.jmarshall.com/tools/cgiproxy/ # # #   IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT ANONYMOUS BROWSING: #     CGIProxy was originally made for indirect browsing more than #       anonymity, but since people are using it for anonymity, I&#39;ve tried #       to make it as anonymous as possible.  Suggestions welcome.  For best #       anonymity, browse with JavaScript turned off.  In fact, that&#39;s the #       only reliable way, in spite of what certain anonymity vendors claim. #     Anonymity is pretty good, but may not be bulletproof.  For example, #       if even a single JavaScript statement can be run, your anonymity can #       be compromised.  I&#39;ve tried to remove JS from every place it can #       exist, but please tell me if I missed any.  Also, browser plugins or #       other executable extensions may be able to reveal you to a server. #     If you find any way your anonymity can be compromised even with scripts #       turned off, please let me know. # # #   CONFIGURATION: # #     None required in most situations.  On some servers, these might be #       required (all in the &quot;user configuration&quot; section): #       . If you&#39;re using another HTTP or SSL proxy, set $HTTP_PROXY, #           $SSL_PROXY, and $NO_PROXY as needed.  If those proxies use #           authentication, set $PROXY_AUTH and $SSL_PROXY_AUTH accordingly. #       . If this is running on an SSL server that doesn&#39;t use port 443, set #           $RUNNING_ON_SSL_SERVER=1 (otherwise, the default of &#39;&#39; is fine). # #     Options include: #       . Set $TEXT_ONLY, $REMOVE_COOKIES, $REMOVE_SCRIPTS, $FILTER_ADS, #           $HIDE_REFERER, and $INSERT_ENTRY_FORM as desired.  Set #           $REMOVE_SCRIPTS if anonymity is important. #       . To let the user choose all of those settings (except $TEXT_ONLY), #           set $ALLOW_USER_CONFIG=1. #       . To change the encoding format of the URL, modify the #           proxy_encode() and proxy_decode() routines.  The default #           routines are suitable for simple PATH_INFO compliance. #       . To encode cookies, modify the cookie_encode() and cookie_decode() #           routines. #       . You can restrict which servers this proxy will access, with #           @ALLOWED_SERVERS and @BANNED_SERVERS. #       . Similarly, you can specify allowed and denied server lists for #           both cookies and scripts. #       . For security, you can ban access to private IP ranges, with #           @BANNED_NETWORKS. #       . If filtering ads, you can customize this with a few settings. #       . To insert your own block of HTML into each page, set $INSERT_HTML #           or $INSERT_FILE. #       . As a last resort, if you really can&#39;t run this script as NPH, #           you can try to run it as non-NPH by setting $NOT_RUNNING_AS_NPH=1. #           BUT, read the notes and warnings above that line.  Caveat surfor. #       . For crude load-balancing among a set of proxies, set @PROXY_GROUP. #       . Other config is possible; see the user configuration section. #       . If heavy use of this proxy puts a load on your server, see the #           &quot;NOTES ON PERFORMANCE&quot; section below. # #     For more info, read the comments regarding any config options you set. # #     This script MUST be installed as a non-parsed header (NPH) script. #       In Apache and many other servers, this is done by simply starting the #       filename with &quot;nph-&quot;.  It MAY be possible to fake it as a non-NPH #       script, MOST of the time, by using the $NOT_RUNNING_AS_NPH feature. #       This is not advised.  See the comments by that option for warnings. # # #   TO USE: #     Start a browsing session by calling the script with no parameters. #       You can bookmark pages you browse to through the proxy, or link to #       the URLs that are generated. # # #   NOTES ON PERFORMANCE: #     Unfortunately, this has gotten slower through the versions, mostly #       because of optional new features.  Configured equally, version 1.3 #       takes 25% longer to run than 1.0 or 1.1 (based on cough highly #       abbreviated testing).  Compiling takes about 50% longer. #     Leaving $REMOVE_SCRIPTS=1 adds 25-50% to the running time. #     Remember that we&#39;re talking about tenths of a second here.  Most of #       the delay experienced by the user is from waiting on two network #       connections.  These performance issues only matter if your server #       CPU is getting overloaded.  Also, these only matter when retrieving #       HTML, because it&#39;s the HTML modification that takes all the time. #     If you can, use mod_perl.  Starting with version 1.3.1, this should #       work under mod_perl, which requires Perl 5.004 or later.  If you use #       mod_perl, be careful to install this as an NPH script, i.e. set the #       &quot;PerlSendHeader Off&quot; configuration directive.  For more info, see the #       mod_perl documentation. #     If you use mod_perl and modify this script, see the note near the #       &quot;reset &#39;a-z&#39;&quot; line below, regarding UPPER_CASE and lower_case #       variables. # # #   TO DO: #     What I want to hear about: #       . Any HTML tags not being converted here. #       . Any method of introducing JavaScript or other script, that&#39;s not #           being filtered out here. #       . Any script MIME types other than those already in @SCRIPT_MIME_TYPES. #       . Any MIME types other than text/html that have links that need to #           be converted. # #     plug any other script holes (e.g. MSIE-proprietary, other MIME types?) #     This could use cleaner URL-encoding all over ($base_url, etc.) #     more error checking? #     find a simple encryption technique for proxy_encode() #     support more protocols, like mailto: or gopher: #     For ad filtering, add option to disable images from servers other than #       that of the containing HTML page?  Is it worth it? # # #   BUGS: #     Anonymity may not not perfect.  In particular, there may be some remaining #       JavaScript holes. #     URLs generated by JavaScript or similar mechanisms won&#39;t be re-proxy&#39;ed #       correctly.  JavaScript in general may not work as expected. #     Since ALL of your cookies are sent to this script (which then chooses #       the relevant ones), some cookies could conceivably be dropped if #       you accumulate a whole lot.  I haven&#39;t seen this happen yet. # # #   I first wrote this in 1996 as an experiment to allow indirect browsing. #     The original seed was a program I wrote for Rich Morin&#39;s article #     in the June 1996 issue of Unix Review, online at #     http://www.cfcl.com/tin/P/199606.shtml. # #   Confession: I didn&#39;t originally write this with the spec for HTTP #     proxies in mind, and there are probably some violations of the protocol #     (at least for proxies).  This whole thing is one big violation of the #     proxy model anyway, so I hereby rationalize that the spec can be widely #     interpreted here.  If there is demand, I can make it more conformant. #     The HTTP client and server components should be fine; it&#39;s just the #     special requirements for proxies that may not be followed. # #-------------------------------------------------------------------------- </p>

<p>use strict ; use Socket ; </p>

<p># First block below is config variables, second block is sort-of config #   variables, third block is persistent constants, fourth block is would-be #   persistent constants (not set until needed), and last block is variables. use vars qw( </p>

<p>$TEXT_ONLY 
<br/>$REMOVE_COOKIES  $REMOVE_SCRIPTS  $FILTER_ADS  $HIDE_REFERER 
<br/>$INSERT_ENTRY_FORM  $ALLOW_USER_CONFIG 
<br/>@ALLOWED_SERVERS  @BANNED_SERVERS  @BANNED_NETWORKS 
<br/>$NO_COOKIE_WITH_IMAGE  @ALLOWED_COOKIE_SERVERS  @BANNED_COOKIE_SERVERS 
<br/>@ALLOWED_SCRIPT_SERVERS  @BANNED_SCRIPT_SERVERS 
<br/>@BANNED_IMAGE_URL_PATTERNS  $RETURN_EMPTY_GIF 
<br/>$INSERT_HTML  $INSERT_FILE  $ANONYMIZE_INSERTION  $FORM_AFTER_INSERTION 
<br/>$INSERTION_FRAME_HEIGHT 
<br/>$RUNNING_ON_SSL_SERVER  $NOT_RUNNING_AS_NPH 
<br/>$HTTP_PROXY  $SSL_PROXY  $NO_PROXY  $PROXY_AUTH  $SSL_PROXY_AUTH 
<br/>$MINIMIZE_CACHING  $SESSION_COOKIES_ONLY 
<br/>@PROXY_GROUP 
<br/>$USER_AGENT  $USE_PASSIVE_FTP_MODE  $SHOW_FTP_WELCOME  $USE_POST_ON_START 
<br/>$REMOVE_TITLES  $NO_BROWSE_THROUGH_SELF  $NO_LINK_TO_START  $MAX_REQUEST_SIZE 
<br/>$QUIETLY_EXIT_PROXY_SESSION 
<br/>$OVERRIDE_SECURITY </p>

<p>$PROXIFY_SCRIPTS  $PROXIFY_COMMENTS 
<br/>@SCRIPT_MIME_TYPES  @OTHER_TYPES_TO_REGISTER  @TYPES_TO_HANDLE 
<br/>$NON_TEXT_EXTENSIONS 
<br/>$PROXY_VERSION 
<br/>@MONTH  @WEEKDAY  %UN_MONTH 
<br/>@BANNED_NETWORK_ADDRS 
<br/>$RUNNING_ON_IIS 
<br/>@NO_PROXY 
<br/>$NO_CACHE_HEADERS 
<br/>@ALL_TYPES  %MIME_TYPE_ID  $SCRIPT_TYPE_REGEX  $TYPES_TO_HANDLE_REGEX 
<br/>$THIS_HOST  $ENV_SERVER_PORT  $ENV_SCRIPT_NAME  $THIS_SCRIPT_URL 
<br/>$HAS_BEGUN 
<br/>$CUSTOM_INSERTION 
<br/>$HTTP_VERSION  $HTTP_1_X 
<br/>$URL 
<br/>$now 
<br/>$packed_flags  $encoded_URL  $doing_insert_here  $env_accept 
<br/>$e_remove_cookies  $e_remove_scripts  $e_filter_ads  $e_insert_entry_form 
<br/>$e_hide_referer 
<br/>$images_are_banned_here  $scripts_are_banned_here  $cookies_are_banned_here 
<br/>$scheme  $authority  $path  $host  $port  $username  $password 
<br/>$cookie_to_server  %auth 
<br/>$script_url  $url_start  $url_start_inframe  $url_start_noframe 
<br/>$is_in_frame  $expected_type 
<br/>$base_url  $base_scheme  $base_host  $base_path  $base_unframes 
<br/>$default_style_type  $default_script_type 
<br/>$status  $headers  $body  $is_html  $response_sent 
<br/>$debug ) ; 
<br/># Under mod_perl, persistent constants only need to be initialized once, so #   use this one-time block to do so. unless ($HAS_BEGUN) { </p>

<p>#-------------------------------------------------------------------------- #    user configuration #-------------------------------------------------------------------------- </p>

<p># If set, then proxy traffic will be restricted to text data only, to save #   bandwidth (though it can still be circumvented with uuencode, etc.). </p>

<p>$TEXT_ONLY= 0 ;      # set to 1 to allow only text data, 0 to allow all </p>

<p># If set, then prevent all cookies from passing through the proxy.  To allow #   cookies from some servers, set this to 0 and see @ALLOWED_COOKIE_SERVERS #   and @BANNED_COOKIE_SERVERS below.  You can also prevent cookies with #   images by setting $NO_COOKIE_WITH_IMAGE below. # Note that this only affects cookies from the target server.   The proxy #   script sends its own cookies for other reasons too, like to support #   authentication.  This flag does not stop these cookies from being sent. </p>

<p>$REMOVE_COOKIES= 0 ; </p>

<p># If set, then remove as much scripting as possible.  If anonymity is #   important, this is strongly recommended!  Better yet, turn off script #   support in your browser. # On the HTTP level: #   . prevent transmission of script MIME types (which only works if the server #       marks them as such, so a malicious server could get around this, but #       then the browser probably wouldn&#39;t execute the script). #   . remove Link: headers that link to a resource of a script MIME type. # Within HTML resources: #   . remove </p>

<p>... . #   . remove intrinsic event attributes from tags, i.e. attributes whose names #       begin with &quot;on&quot;. #   . remove ... where &quot;type&quot; attribute is a script MIME type. #   . remove various HTML tags that appear to link to a script MIME type. #   . remove script macros (aka Netscape-specific &quot;JavaScript entities&quot;), #       i.e. any attributes containing the string &quot;&amp;{&quot; . #   . remove &quot;JavaScript conditional comments&quot;. #   . remove MSIE-specific &quot;dynamic properties&quot;. # To allow scripts from some sites but not from others, set this to 0 and #   see @ALLOWED_SCRIPT_SERVERS and @BANNED_SCRIPT_SERVERS below. # See @SCRIPT_MIME_TYPES below for a list of which MIME types are filtered out. # I do NOT know for certain that this removes all script content!  It removes #   all that I know of, but I don&#39;t have a definitive list of places scripts #   can exist.  If you do, please send it to me.  EVEN RUNNING A SINGLE #   JAVASCRIPT STATEMENT CAN COMPROMISE YOUR ANONYMITY!  Just so you know. # Richard Smith has a good test site for anonymizing proxies, at #   http://users.rcn.com/rms2000/anon/test.htm # Note that turning this on removes most popup ads!  :) </p>

<p>$REMOVE_SCRIPTS= 1 ; </p>

<p># If set, then filter out images that match one of @BANNED_IMAGE_URL_PATTERNS, #   below.  Also removes cookies attached to images, as if $NO_COOKIE_WITH_IMAGE #   is set. # To remove most popup advertisements, also set $REMOVE_SCRIPTS=1 above. </p>

<p>$FILTER_ADS= 0 ; </p>

<p># If set, then don&#39;t send a Referer: sic header with each request #   (i.e. something that tells the server which page you&#39;re coming from #   that linked to it).  This is a minor privacy issue, but a few sites #   won&#39;t send you pages or images if the Referer: is not what they&#39;re #   expecting.  If a page is loading without images or a link seems to be #   refused, then try turning this off, and a correct Referer: header will #   be sent. # This is only a problem in a VERY small percentage of sites, so few that #   I&#39;m kinda hesitant to put this in the entry form.  Other arrangements #   have their own problems, though. </p>

<p>$HIDE_REFERER= 1 ; </p>

<p># If set, insert a compact version of the URL entry form at the top of each #   page.  This will also display the URL currently being viewed. # When viewing a page with frames, then a new top frame is created and the #   insertion goes there. # If you want to customize the appearance of the form, modify the routine #   mini_start_form() near the end of the script. # If you want to insert something other than this form, see $INSERT_HTML and #   $INSERT_FILE below. # Users should realize that options changed via the form only take affect when #   the form is submitted by entering a new URL or pressing the &quot;Go&quot; button. #   Selecting an option, then following a link on the page, will not cause #   the option to take effect. # Users should also realize that anything inserted into a page may throw #   off any precise layout.  The insertion will also be subject to #   background colors and images, and any other page-wide settings. </p>

<p>$INSERT_ENTRY_FORM= 1 ; </p>

<p># If set, then allow the user to control $REMOVE_COOKIES, $REMOVE_SCRIPTS, #   $FILTER_ADS, $HIDE_REFERER, and $INSERT_ENTRY_FORM.  Note that they #   can&#39;t fine-tune any related options, such as the various @ALLOWED... and #   @BANNED... lists. </p>

<p>$ALLOW_USER_CONFIG= 1 ; </p>

<p># Create your own proxy_encode() and proxy_decode() to tranform the target #   URL to and from the format that will be stored in PATH_INFO.  The encoded #   form should only contain characters that are legal in PATH_INFO.  This #   varies by server, but using only printable chars, no &quot;?&quot; or &quot;#&quot;, and no #   two adjacent slashes (&quot;//&quot;) works on most servers.  Don&#39;t let PATH_INFO #   contain the strings &quot;./&quot;, &quot;/.&quot;, &quot;../&quot;, or &quot;/..&quot;, or else it may get #   compressed like a pathname somewhere.  Try not to make the resulting #   string too long, either. # Of course, proxy_decode() must exactly undo whatever proxy_encode() does. # Make proxy_encode() as fast as possible-- it&#39;s a major bottleneck for the #   whole program. # Because of the simplified absolute URL resolution in full_url(), there may #   be &quot;..&quot; segments in the default encoding here, notably in the first path #   segment.  Normally, that&#39;s just an HTML mistake, but please tell me if #   you see any privacy exploit with it. # Note that a few sites have embedded applications (like applets or Shockwave) #   that expect to access URLs relative to the page&#39;s URL.  This means they #   may not work if the encoded target URL can&#39;t be treated like a base URL, #   e.g. that it can&#39;t be appended with something like &quot;../data/foo.data&quot; #   to get that expected data file.  In such cases, the default encoding below #   should let these sites work fine, as should any other encoding that can #   support URLs relative to it. </p>

<p>sub proxy_encode { </p>

<p>my($URL)= @ ; 
<br/>$URL=~ s#^(\w+.-+)://#$1/# ;                 # http://xxx -&gt; http/xxx 
<br/>#    $URL=~ s/(.)/ sprintf(&#39;%02x&#39;,ord($1)) /ge ;   # each char -&gt; 2-hex #    $URL=~ tr/a-zA-Z/n-za-mN-ZA-M/ ;              # rot-13 return $URL ; 
<br/>} </p>

<p>sub proxy_decode { </p>

<p>my($enc_URL)= @ ; 
<br/>#    $enc_URL=~ tr/a-zA-Z/n-za-mN-ZA-M/ ;        # rot-13 #    $enc_URL=~ s/(0-9A-Fa-f{2})/ sprintf(&quot;%c&quot;,hex($1)) /ge ; $enc_URL=~ s#^(\w+.-+)/#$1://# ;           # http/xxx -&gt; http://xxx 
<br/>return $enc_URL ; 
<br/>} </p>

<p># Encode cookies before they&#39;re sent back to the user. # The return value must only contain characters that are legal in cookie #   names and values, i.e. only printable characters, and no &quot;;&quot;, &quot;,&quot;, &quot;=&quot;, #   or white space. # cookie_encode() is called twice for each cookie: once to encode the cookie #   name, and once to encode the cookie value.  The two are then joined with #   &quot;=&quot; and sent to the user. # cookie_decode() must exactly undo whatever cookie_encode() does. # Also, cookie_encode() must always encode a given input string into the #   same output string.  This is because browsers need the cookie name to #   identify and manage a cookie, so the name must be consistent. # This is not a bottleneck like proxy_encode() is, so speed is not critical. </p>

<p>sub cookie_encode { </p>

<p>my($cookie)= @ ; 
<br/>#    $cookie=~ s/(.)/ sprintf(&#39;%02x&#39;,ord($1)) /ge ;   # each char -&gt; 2-hex #    $cookie=~ tr/a-zA-Z/n-za-mN-ZA-M/ ;              # rot-13 $cookie=~ s/(\W)/ &#39;%&#39; . sprintf(&#39;%02x&#39;,ord($1)) /ge ; # simple URL-encoding 
<br/>return $cookie ; 
<br/>} </p>

<p>sub cookie_decode { </p>

<p>my($enc_cookie)= @ ; 
<br/>$enc_cookie=~ s/%(\da-fA-F{2})/ pack(&#39;C&#39;, hex($1)) /ge ;  # URL-decode 
<br/>#    $enc_cookie=~ tr/a-zA-Z/n-za-mN-ZA-M/ ;          # rot-13 #    $enc_cookie=~ s/(0-9A-Fa-f{2})/ sprintf(&quot;%c&quot;,hex($1)) /ge ; return $enc_cookie ; 
<br/>} </p>

<p># Use @ALLOWED_SERVERS and @BANNED_SERVERS to restrict which servers a user #   can visit through this proxy.  Any URL at a host matching a pattern in #   @BANNED_SERVERS will be forbidden.  In addition, if @ALLOWED_SERVERS is #   not empty, then access is allowed only to servers that match a pattern #   in it.  In other words, @BANNED_SERVERS means &quot;ban these servers&quot;, and #   @ALLOWED_SERVERS (if not empty) means &quot;allow only these servers&quot;.  If a #   server matches both lists, it is banned. # These are each a list of Perl 5 regular expressions (aka patterns or #   regexes), not literal host names.  To turn a hostname into a pattern, #   replace every &quot;.&quot; with &quot;\.&quot;, add &quot;^&quot; to the beginning, and add &quot;$&quot; to the #   end.  For example, &quot;www.example.com&quot; becomes &quot;^www\.example\.com$&quot;.  To #   match every host ending in something, leave out the &quot;^&quot;.  For example, #   &quot;\.example\.com$&quot; matches every host ending in &quot;.example.com&quot;.  For more #   details about Perl regular expressions, see the Perl documentation.  (They #   may seem cryptic at first, but they&#39;re very powerful once you know how to #   use them.) @ALLOWED_SERVERS= () ; @BANNED_SERVERS= () ; </p>

<p># If @BANNED_NETWORKS is set, then forbid access to these hosts or networks. # This is done by IP address, not name, so it provides more certain security #   than @BANNED_SERVERS above. # Specify each element as a decimal IP address-- all four integers for a host, #   or one to three integers for a network.  For example, &#39;127.0.0.1&#39; bans #   access to the local host, and &#39;192.168&#39; bans access to all IP addresses #   in the 192.168 network.  Sorry, no banning yet for subnets other than #   8, 16, or 24 bits. # IF YOU&#39;RE RUNNING THIS ON OR INSIDE A FIREWALL, THIS SETTING IS STRONGLY #   RECOMMENDED!!  In particular, you should ban access to other machines #   inside the firewall that the firewall machine itself may have access to. #   Otherwise, external users will be able to access any internal hosts that #   the firewall can access.  Even if that&#39;s what you intend, you should ban #   access to any hosts that you don&#39;t explicitly want to expose to outside #   users. # In addition to the recommended defaults below, add all IP addresses of your #   server machine if you want to protect it like this. # After you set this, YOU SHOULD TEST to verify that the proxy can&#39;t access #   the IP addresses you&#39;re banning! # This feature is simple now but will be more complete in future releases. #   How would you like this to be extended?  What would be useful to you? @BANNED_NETWORKS= (&#39;127.0.0.1&#39;, &#39;192.168&#39;, &#39;10&#39;) ; </p>

<p># Settings to fine-tune cookie filtering, if cookies are not banned altogether #   (by user checkbox or $REMOVE_COOKIES above). # Use @ALLOWED_COOKIE_SERVERS and @BANNED_COOKIE_SERVERS to restrict which #   servers can send cookies through this proxy.  They work like #   @ALLOWED_SERVERS and @BANNED_SERVERS above, both in how their precedence #   works, and that they&#39;re lists of Perl 5 regular expressions.  See the #   comments there for details. </p>

<p># If non-empty, only allow cookies from servers matching one of these patterns. # Comment this out to allow all cookies (subject to @BANNED_COOKIE_SERVERS). #@ALLOWED_COOKIE_SERVERS= (&#39;\bslashdot\.org$&#39;) ;</p>

They can serve as a layer 4 gateway, and provide various network related regulatory functionalities. Sample proxies include the transparent TCP proxy and the reverse TCP proxy.</p>

 title : The proyectofinalquintoutncordoba Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Anteproyecto Integrador Quinto Año </p>

<p>Tema Elegido: Adquisición de Voz a Distancia con Conexión a PC </p>

<p>Introducción: El proyecto consiste en la construcción de un sistema de Adquisición de Voz Inalámbrico con conexión a PC para una posterior utilización de la señal adquirida. </p>

<p>Objetivos: Lograr un sistema capaz de adquirir el discurso de un locutor, durante un tiempo determinado, para posteriormente realizar distintas operaciones como: mostrar la señal adquirida, su espectro de frecuencia, realizar compresiones de la misma, reproducción local o remota ( via red ). </p>

<p>Desarrollo: El sistema de medición de la voz se realizará a través de un acondicionador de señal, pasando por el A/D de un microntrolador para su posterior envío vía RF ( 2.4 GHz ) al receptor el cual se comunicará por USB con la PC, la cual tendra el control absoluto del tiempo de adquisición. Luego con el Software se podrá elegir entre las acciones nombradas anteriormente. </p>

<p>El Hardware, Software y Documentación se realizará con Software Libre ( en lo posible ). Todo el proyecto estará licenciado con la GPLv3 ( General Public License v3 ) y se publicará en distintas WEB interesadas para la posible reutilización del mismo por parte de terceros. </p>

<p>Integrantes: Henze Agustín, Delfino Ariel, Redolfi Javier</p>
 summary : <p>pa los medicos, </p>

 title : The prs500fs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Sony® Reader provides a new way to experience reading.  </p>

<p>More details on the reader device from sony website: &#39;The Sony® Reader’s display uses e Ink® - a significant improvement over CRT and LCD technology. Instead of rows of glowing cells, e Ink® microcapsules actually appear as either black or white depending on a positive or negative charge determined by the content. The result is a reading experience that’s similar to paper - high contrast, high resolution, viewable in direct sunlight and at a nearly 180-degree angle, and requiring no power to maintain the image. In other words, it&#39;s a screen that, like you, is well read.&#39; </p>

<p>Unfortunately no support is provided for the device on Linux and Mac OS X. This library is an effort to provide FUSE-based filesystem which can mount prs500&#39;s on Linux, MacOS and, possibly, other OSes using Kovid Goyal&#39;s libprs500 as a starting point. </p>

<p>The device supports PDF, RTF, TXT and proprietary Sony® Ebook Format (BBeB). </p>

<p>Currently the project is ON HOLD. There is some libusb code in there that might be useful, and that&#39;s why I&#39;m not deleting it for now.</p>
 title : The prssr Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>News5.2.2009: Project discontinued. FeaturesFormats </p>

<p>pRSSreader can handle many versions of feeds: RSS 0.90, 0.91, 0.92 and 2.0, RDF 1.0 and Atom 0.3. </p>

<p>Google Reader Synchronization </p>

<p>pRSSreader offers you the synchronization with Google Reader. Just fill in your authentication and it will work (from 1.4.3). </p>

<p>Bookmarking </p>

<p>You can set up your favorite social bookmarking site and simply send links there directly from the pRSSreader while you reading. </p>

<p>Site Manager </p>

<p>Site manager allows you to subscribe to sites you want to read. You can group your feeds into folders and you can set up feed options such as displaying on the Today screen, caching options, etc. </p>

<p>Items </p>

<p>pRSSreader can mark feed items with three states: new, unread and read. Those states are preserved between starts of pRSSreader. You can sort the feed items or you can hide already read items. </p>

<p>Sequential reading </p>

<p>Once you start reading, you can read from the start to the end without getting back to the main window to switch between items or even feeds. </p>

<p>Caching </p>

<p>pRSSreader have quite powerful caching abilities, it can cache images included within feeds, enclosures and it can also cache web pages for offline browsing. pRSSreader has a built-in Cache manager that helps you to maintain your cache. </p>

<p>Offline Reading </p>

<p>You can specify special rules to get PDA optimized web pages or you can use the HTML optimizer. </p>

<p>Import/Export </p>

<p>You can import your OPML file from the local file system. Or you can import your subscriptions from the Google Reader. pRSSreader can also export your subscriptions into an OPML file. </p>

<p>Customizable </p>

<p>pRSSreader is quite customizable. You can set up appearance of reading dialog, change font sizes, enable clear type, set the location of cache or an external browser for viewing the whole messages and many more (see registry tweaks for more options). </p>

<p>Updates </p>

<p>You can update your feeds manually or you can also let pRSSreader to update your feeds automatically. They can be updated periodically (you can select the update interval) or you can set up the update for a specific time. </p>

<p>Today screen </p>

<p>pRSSreader has integration with Today screen. It can simply display the number of new/unread items or can cycle feed names or even items from a feed. The plugin is compatible with Pocket Breeze. </p>

<p>Keywords </p>

<p>You can enter a list of keywords and pRSSreader will show you feed items that includes these keywords (from 1.3.0). </p>

<p>Proxy Support </p>

<p>pRSSreader supports HTTP, SOCKS4 and SOCKS5 proxy servers (from 1.3.0). </p>

<p>HTTP Authentication </p>

<p>pRSSreader can access feeds and web pages protected with Basic or Digest authentication (from 1.3.0). </p>

<p>DonationsIf you like pRSSreader, please, consider supporting the project by donating via paypal.</p>
 title : The prtl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Nowadays, it&#39;s a test environment, my personal playground, but I  want to share the tools I can create with Ruby ;) I&#39;m playing a lot with that language so I expect to do contributions very soon.</p>
 summary : <p>PRuby aims at creating a set of libraries and later a virtual machine for integration of PHP and Ruby programming languages. The first edition was written by Szabo Peter and is currently being re-written by Arthur J. Mukembo in partnership with Peter. The meta-language is currently only available for nix platforms  with windows support planned for future releases. </p>

<p>Using a set of libraries, its able to map object instances and associated methods from one language into another.  </p>

<p>Requirements include: Ruby 1.8.4+ Source PHP 4.x/ 5.x Source Apache Source GNU Make utility </p>

<p>Detailed utilization instructions will soon be made available except of course for the &#39;Milk and Cookies&#39; which we imagine is obvious. </p>

<p>We are seeking core committers with advanced knowledge of PHP, Ruby, Apache, Systems Architecture and Systems Engineering.</p>

 title : The psake Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>psake is a build automation tool written in PowerShell. It avoids the angle-bracket tax associated with executable XML by leveraging the PowerShell syntax in your build scripts. psake has a syntax inspired by rake (aka make in Ruby) and bake (aka make in Boo), but is easier to script because it leverages your existent command-line knowledge. </p>

<p>psake is pronounced sake - as in Japanese rice wine. It does NOT rhyme with make, bake, or rake. </p>

<p>The source code has moved to GitHub: </p>

<p>git://github.com/JamesKovacs/psake.git </p>

<p>You can also download ZIP files of the project &quot;binaries&quot; from GitHub by selecting the appropriate tag and clicking the Download link: </p>

<p>http://github.com/JamesKovacs/psake</p>

 title : The psi--zet Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Proteomics Informatics Standards Group (PSI-PI)  </p>

<p>Proteomics Informatics Group CharterThe PSI Proteomics Informatics (PSI-PI) standards group consists of academic, government and industry researchers, software developers, publishers and instrument manufacturers. The goals of the group are: </p>

<p>to provide a set of minimal reporting requirements which augment the MIAPE reporting guidelines with respect to analysis of data derived from proteomics experiments; to provide vendor-neutral and standard formats for representing results of analyzing and processing experimental data; to foster adoption of the format by highlighting efforts made by vendors and individuals that utilize the format in their products. </p>

<p>Where is the Work of PSI-PI Documented?Please note that HUPO-PSI is documented primarily at http://psidev.info.  This Google Code site is being used only to provide a reliable SVN repository for the deliverables of the PSI-PI group. </p>

<p>How do I use Subversion?Take a look at http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.4/index.html which provides comprehensive documentation of Subversion (SVN). </p>

<p>New Committers - please see the new WIKI page describing how to use Subversion tagging to tag validating versions of XML instance docs and the corresponding schema version.</p>
 title : The psi-pi Open Source Project on Open Hub

 summary : <p>PSP Player is an emulator for Sony&#39;s PlayStation Portable handheld game system. It&#39;s developed exclusively in my spare time as a labor of hobby; this means that I won&#39;t support it, follow your demands, or (most importantly) sell it.  title : The pspstacklesspython Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is the port of Python programming language to the Sony PSP console.The current version is 2.5.2 which is the latest ported release from CPython and Stackless Python. </p>

<p>From the Stackless main page: </p>

<p>Stackless Python is an enhanced version of the Python programming language. It allows programmers to reap the benefits of thread-based programming without the performance and complexity problems associated with conventional threads. The microthreads that Stackless adds to Python are a cheap and lightweight convenience which can if used properly, give the following benefits: </p>

<p>Improved program structure. More readable code. Increased programmer productivity. Check the BasicInstallandUsage wiki page for installation and usage instructions. </p>

<p>For more information on module usage, check PSPPythonModules and MusicSupport Wiki pages. </p>

<p>For Python and Stackless Python help follow the links section on the right. </p>

<p>After installing, take a look in the small GameDemo created using features from Stackless and PSP modules. This demo can be seen in this video provided by a user. </p>

<p>All releases follow the same naming scheme, for example:  StacklessPSP2.5.2_R1.zip you find the name - StacklessPSP, 2.5.2 which is the Python release and a underline followed by a number which is the StacklessPSP release version. When multiple releases from the same Python version are made, the number after the underline will change. </p>

<p>Check the ChangeLog wiki page for information about the releases.</p>

 title : The puddy Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A project based on wanting a web framework built for speed and integration with standards. Currently modeling Rails in the area of application design, but improving areas with modules that are optimized for speed because I sit there and benchmark every line until I can do it no more. </p>

<p>Model uses Rose::DB::Object for ORM support, but it hase been designed for you to use anything that you want -- just my recommendation. It will handle to the association with the database that is well designed -- meaning the database handles the relationships not the ORM. </p>

<p>View uses a custom built XML::Builder and EPB that will handle templating that make incorporating Perl code into document easily. There is no language better than the langauge the application is built to use for the View. I am basing off the fact that out of my personal experience I have never met a &#39;designer&#39; that just use a simple templating language. The view module is easily extendible to support any template you want, just requires that it knows how to render it correctly. Right now each view is loaded as a moudle with a render method. </p>

<p>Controller is designed to allow pre/post operations of a method call, plus rendering of different views. Trying to determine what takes precedence as phtml, pxml, text, etc. </p>

<p>Just recently I have submitted an actual working example of a project can be setup. Its very small and crude, but it will actually work in a browser and render the templates of a controllers action (YAY!!!).</p>

 title : The pure-lang Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Pure is a modern-style functional programming language based on term rewriting. It offers equational definitions with pattern matching, full symbolic rewriting capabilities, dynamic typing, eager and lazy evaluation, lexical closures, built-in list and matrix support and an easy-to-use C interface. The interpreter uses LLVM as a backend to JIT-compile Pure programs to fast native code. Pure also integrates nicely with a number of other computing environments, most notably Faust, PureData, Octave, Reduce and TeXmacs. A fairly extensive collection of addon modules is available, which makes Pure usable as a compiled scripting language for a variety of purposes.</p>

 title : The puz Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Across Lite is crossword software used by sites like the New York Times for distributing crosswords. </p>

<p>File FormatThe file format is not documented anywhere, which meant third-party software could neither read nor produce Across Lite files.  So the primary output of this project is the file format documentation. </p>

<p>Some implementations that consume or produce these files: </p>

<p>libpuz (C, GPL): see below rubypuz (Ruby, MIT): http://neugierig.org/software/ruby/rubypuz/ puzhs (Haskell bindings for libpuz, GPL and MIT): http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hpuz </p>

<p>libpuzlibpuz is a C library for reading and writing Across Lite&#39;s .puz files.  The library is relatively stable and in current use.  The latest version is available from this project page - see the downloads section for a tarball.  Older versions are available at: http://www.joshisanerd.com/puz/.  Haskell bindings for the library are available from a different page, see above. </p>

<p>DHTML CrosswordsWe&#39;ve also built a rudimentary web-based multiplayer server for solving crosswords with your friends.  Have you ever worked on a crossword in the same newspaper, sharing a pen?  It&#39;s sorta like that except everyone can type at the same time. </p>

<p>It&#39;s not nearly complete but it is playable and can be pulled from the subversion repository.</p>

 title : The pweasel Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PWeasel is a web library tested under php 4.0 and it is not ready for production. I created it because i have an old server and a project based on that environment to maintain and no major framework works on such old platform. The design is very simple, web/mysql centric, and somehow modular but fast, simple, flexible. it provides: </p>

<p>php based templating some view helper function, table and form over all action based module controler, with no front controllers at all configuration, based on php files SQL construction routines </p>

<p>under testing: </p>

<p>DAL model/list following the table data gateway structure with DataDictionary file based cache of components automatic admin interface(CRUD) generator user/auth per action mapping </p>

<p>i would like to summarize what leads my design decisions in 2 sentences: </p>

<p>&quot;Truth has no path. Truth is living and, therefore, changing&quot; &quot;Use only that which works, and take it from any place you can find it&quot;</p>

 title : The pwnide Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The goal of Inventor IDE, a.k.a. PwnIDE, is to avoid the shortcomings of the current standard code editors by moving inherently non-text constructs like functions, structures, files, variables, constants, and documentation out of their shoehorned purely-text positions.  This allows for control of those constructs that is largely language-independent. </p>

<p>The latest version, Alpha 5, focuses on assembly language, for development of the PwnOS project.  It has built-in assembling for Windows executables.  Support for C will be quite simple to add later on.</p>

 title : The py-jasmine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The py-jasmine project will help journal editors to produce pdf file and publish it easily. The ultimate goal of this project is to help people setup a new form of collaboration to generate high quality content. </p>

<p>We just began the project, and are seeking your helps! </p>

<p>BackgroundThe background of this project is that an emerging form of online collaboration is becoming popular in China in 2007. </p>

<p>All readers must join an online group to receive new issues by email. Contributors have an online groups to discuss internal affairs. An email address is setuped for contributors to send articles to editors. The editors filter the articles and organize them into an issue in pdf format. The editors send a new issue to the readers&#39; group.  These kinds of collaboration is highly dependent on the email and group service. Although it is closed to the mass to some extend, we still think it will be useful for some part of the users. For these kinds of collaboration, the most burdensome work is the editor&#39;s work. So we want to make a tool to help the editors. </p>

<p>Examples are Far And Wide Journal, Chinese Independent Reading Report and others. </p>

<p>Coding Style Guidelinehttp://wiki.woodpecker.org.cn/moin/PythonCodingRule (in Chinese) RequirementUseCasesAndWorkflow</p>

<p>The utilities attempt to cover the lightweight portions of OpenOffice.org&#39;s ODF Toolkit project (sans UNO), as well as Rob Weir&#39;s proposal for an OpenDocument Developer&#39;s Kit: </p>

<p>http://odftoolkit.openoffice.org/ </p>

<p>http://opendocument.xml.org/node/154 </p>

<p>Current FeaturesCommand-line interface:Powerful interface for batch scripting Output document contents as HTML, XML or plain text Print a list of authors for all input files Regular-expression replacement of strings inside the document Convert an ODF document to and from SQLite as a binary string blob Written entirely in Python, so it&#39;s usable anywhere Python is available Additional library functions:Parse and serialize ODF documents Get individual document components (content, styles, metadata, app settings, etc.), as an XML string Extract objects embedded in the document using regular expressions or UNIX-style glob patterns Determine the correct file extension based on the mimetype Scan a directory for ODF files</p>

<p>Active Resource attempts to provide a coherent wrapper object-relational mapping for REST web services. It follows the same philosophy as Active Record, in that one of its prime aims is to reduce the amount of code needed to map to these resources.

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The PyAMG Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyAMG is a library of Algebraic Multigrid (AMG) solvers with a convenient Python interface.   </p>

<p>AMG is a multilevel technique for solving large-scale linear systems with optimal or near-optimal efficiency.  Unlike geometric multigrid, AMG requires little or no geometric information about the underlying problem and develops a sequence of coarser grids directly from the input matrix.  This feature is especially important for problems discretized on unstructured meshes and irregular grids. </p>

<p>PyAMG features implementations of several popular AMG methods: Ruge-Stuben (RS) or Classical AMG, AMG based on Smoothed Aggregation (SA), and Adaptive Smoothed Aggregation (aSA).</p>
 title : The pybluez Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyBluez is an effort to create python wrappers around system Bluetooth resources to allow Python developers to easily and quickly create Bluetooth applications. </p>

<p>PyBluez works on GNU/Linux and Windows XP (Microsoft and Widcomm Bluetooth stacks). It is freely available under the GNU General Public License. </p>

<p>DocumentationSee the Documentation page. </p>

<p>Mailing List / ContactPlease use the mailing list at http://groups.google.com/group/pybluez/ </p>

<p>NewsOct 15, 2009Version 0.17 released.  This is a bugfix release, affecting GNU/Linux only.  See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Feb 5, 2009Version 0.16 released.  This is a bugfix release, affecting both GNU/Linux and Windows.  See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Jan 21, 2008Version 0.15 released.  This is a bugfix release, affecting both GNU/Linux and Windows.  See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Jan 3, 2008We are slowly transitioning the website from MIT (org.csail.mit.edu/pybluez) to Google Code (http://pybluez.googlecode.com).  All new software releases will now be hosted on google code. </p>

<p>Nov 12, 2007Version 0.14 released. This is a bugfix release only, affecting only GNU/Linux. See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Aug 30, 2007Version 0.13 released. This is a bugfix release only, affecting only GNU/Linux. See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Aug 29, 2007Version 0.12 released. This is a bugfix release only, affecting only GNU/Linux. See the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Aug 25, 2007Version 0.11 released. This is a bugfix release only, affecting only MS Windows see the CHANGELOG for more details. </p>

<p>Aug 15, 2007Version 0.10 released. Big news this time is that I&#39;ve added support for the Widcomm stack in Windows XP. This is not well tested and very experimental at this point, so bug reports are appreciated. From the CHANGELOG: </p>

<p>    added experimental Broadcom/Widcomm support.  All the basics should be
<br/>    supported:
<br/>        RFCOMM sockets
<br/>        L2CAP sockets
<br/>        Device Discovery, Name Lookup
<br/>        SDP search on remote devices
<br/>        SDP advertisement (RFCOMM, L2CAP)</p>

<p>    Widcomm stack notes:
<br/>        1. BluetoothSocket.accept () always returns 0 for the port,
<br/>           as the RFCOMM channel/L2CAP PSM of the client device is not exposed
<br/>           by the Widcomm API
<br/>        2. Not all fields of advertise_service are supported.  The following
<br/>           parameters are currently not supported:
<br/>               description, protocols
<br/>        3. The following methods of BluetoothSocket are not supported:
<br/>              gettimeout, dup, makefile, settimeout
<br/>        4. The following parameters to discover_devices are not supported:
<br/>               duration, flush_cache (cache always flushes)
<br/>        5. The timeout parameter of lookup_name is not supported
<br/>        6. Once a listening socket has accepted a connection, it is not put
<br/>           back into listening mode.  The original listening socket essentially
<br/>           becomes useless.
<br/>        7. SDP search/browse operations on the local host are not yet supportedDec 27, 2006Version 0.9.2 released. Fixed an endian-error that affects L2CAP sockets on big-endian machines only. </p>

<p>Sep 14, 2006Version 0.9.1 released. Fixed a missing #include that prevented PyBluez from compiling with new versions of BlueZ </p>

<p>Sep 1, 2006Version 0.9 released. Bug fixes and minor functionality improvements. See the CHANGELOG for details. </p>

<p>July 31, 2006Version 0.8 released. Bug fix for Linux and minor functionality improvements for Windows XP. See the CHANGELOG for details. </p>

<p>May 13, 2006Version 0.7.1 released. Bug fixes and minor functionality improvements for Windows XP. See the CHANGELOG for more details. Code examples and documentation on this website should be up to date now. </p>

<p>May 5, 2006Version 0.7 released. Support added for Windows XP. See the CHANGELOG for more details. The documentation on this website is now a little out of date, see the examples included in the source distributions for... examples. Web documentation will hopefully be updated soon. </p>

<p>Mar 20, 2006PyBluez is now available in Debian unstable as package python-bluez. .deb binaries will no longer be distributed from this page for future releases. To obtain them, either use Debian or download from http://packages.debian.org. </p>

<p>Feb 24, 2006Version 0.6.1 released. Last week&#39;s release was a little hasty, and I missed a bunch of bugs. All of those should be squashed now. </p>

<p>Feb 18, 2006Version 0.6 released. Bug fixes. </p>

<p>Dec 16, 2005Version 0.5 released. Bug fixes and minor functionality added for SDP. </p>

<p>Nov 9, 2005Version 0.4 released. Minor bug fixes. No major new features. </p>

<p>Sep 20, 2005Version 0.3 released. Bug fixes for big-endian architectures, and sdp support. No major new features. Link added to some better documentation. </p>

<p>Apr 4, 2005Version 0.2 released. Support for SDP service advertisement and searching added. Support for easy asynchronous device discovery added. New API is incompatible with 0.1. </p>

<p>Dec 16, 2004Version 0.1 released. Support for HCI, L2CAP, and RFCOMM sockets. No support for OBEX or SDP.</p>
 summary : <p>The goal of the Pybots project is to allow people to run automated tests for their Python programs in real time. Testing is done every time a commit is made to the Python&#39;s subversion repository, with Python binaries built from the latest source.</p>

 summary : <p>pybox2d2D physics library for Python under the *zlib* license. (not BSD, see below) </p>

<p>BSD? zlib? Which license?As Google Code does not allow projects to be listed under some of the less popular licenses (see here and here for more information), pybox2d is currently listed under BSD. However, the code is licensed under the very liberal zlib license, the same as the underlying Box2D library. </p>

 summary : <p>Bugz is a python and command line interface to Bugzilla. </p>

<p>It was conceived as a tool to speed up the workflow for Gentoo Linux developers and contributors when dealing with bugs using Bugzilla. By avoiding the clunky web interface, the user quickly search, isolate and contribute to the project very quickly. Developers alike can easily extract attachments and close bugs all from the comfort of the command line. </p>

<p>PyBugz is written in Python and written in a way to be extended easily for use on other Bugzillas. It&#39;s known to work full or partially on XenSource, Gnome, Novell and Landfill Bugzillas. </p>

<p>Current development is taking place in http://github.com/ColdWind/pybugz</p>

 title : The pycarc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Carcassonne board game implemented in Python and PyGame</p>
 summary : <p>This is a very helpful, very functional program written in Python to download Picasa photo albums or just the photos (in full resolution) you like the best from a given album. You just have to provide the username, and all the available —public— albums from that user will be presented to you (you can also browse an unlisted album if you have its url). </p>

<p>The program let you download all the photos from one or several Picasa albums, in full resolution, with just one click. You can also browse a given album and choose which photos to download. </p>

<p>Since Pycasa 1.0 you also have the option to log in with your Picasa account and manage your albums: create, edit, delete albums, and upload and edit your photos. </p>

<p>Pycasa provides a super user-friendly PyGTK GUI and it is based on the Google Picasa API. </p>

<p>How to reach us: </p>

<p>Join #pycasa at irc.freenode.net  </p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>基于python的中文分词项目。 </p>

<p>第一个版本实现了基于的MMSEG中文分词算法Python实现。MMSEG实际上是一个正向最大匹配+多个规则的分词算法。链接给出的几个网站写的很清楚了。在开发过程中我增加了一个规则来处理原来的算法中有可能出现的冲突问题。当所有的规则都无法唯一的确定一个chunk时，优先选择后面比较长的词。开发过程中参照了MMSEG的Java实现和ruby实现。并且对性能进行了初步的优化。 </p>

<p>目前的性能数据：在Pentium D 2.8G的CPU下处理2.9MB的文本数据，全切分的复杂算法不开启pysco的情况下104s，开启pysco的情况下90s，能达到32KB/s。简单算法可以达到64KB/s。经测试速度能达到Java版本MMSEG的1/3，未来如果要进一步优化速度的话应该是把关键的算法的实现移植到c语言中。 </p>

<p>实现了简单的余弦相似度计算的算法。 </p>

<p>TODO: </p>

<p>实现NLTK兼容的接口。(目前已经增加了tokenizer接口) C语言级别的优化 （测试中，增加了is_basic_latin的c实现，考虑字典用c语言优化） 实现其他算法，目前考虑一个ICTCLAS的python实现，要看有没有时间。 支持停用词，支持unicode的字母数字检测等。 与分词有关的其他想法 </p>

<p>研究一下ferret/cferret，能否实现一个python binding并且结合进去。（研究发现ferret的实现非常复杂，ruby绑定的接口部分的c代码都有上万行，放弃了，还是用solr吧） 与nlp/datamining的进一步结合</p>

 summary : <p>pydelicious allows you to access the web service of del.icio.us via it&#39;s API through python. </p>

<p>(The original website was here: http://deliciouspython.python-hosting.com/ however pydelicious broke on the last del.icio.us API update and I was unable to contact the author so I&#39;m posting the repaired code here going forward.) </p>

<p>  &gt;&gt;&gt; from pydelicious import DeliciousAPI
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; from getpass import getpass
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; a = DeliciousAPI(&#39;username&#39;, getpass(&#39;Password:&#39;))
<br/>  Password:
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; # Either succeeds or raises DeliciousError or subclass:
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; a.posts_add(&quot;http://my.url/&quot;, &quot;title&quot;, 
<br/>  ... extended=&quot;description&quot;, tags=&quot;my tags&quot;)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; len(a.posts_all()[&#39;posts&#39;])
<br/>  1
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; a.tags_get() # or: a.request(&#39;tags/get&#39;)
<br/>  {&#39;tags&#39;: [{&#39;count&#39;: &#39;1&#39;, &#39;tag&#39;: &#39;my&#39;}, {&#39;count&#39;: &#39;1&#39;, &#39;tag&#39;: &#39;tags&#39;}]}
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; a.posts_update()
<br/>  {&#39;update&#39;: {&#39;time&#39;: (2008, 11, 28, 2, 35, 51, 4, 333, -1)}}
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; # Either succeeds or raises DeliciousError or subclass:
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; a.posts_delete(&quot;http://my.com/&quot;)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; len(a.posts_all()[&#39;posts&#39;])
<br/>  0</p>

 title : The pye-u Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pye-u is a simple tool to connect to wireless e-U (www.e-u.pt)., </p>
 summary : <p>PyeTVThis plugin allows access to EyeTV from within Front Row on Leopard, adding a EyeTV item to Front Row&#39;s top level menu.  The plugin gives access to EyeTV&#39;s recordings (grouped by series), along with an image preview and recording metadata. </p>

<p>PyeTV also integrates with ETVComskip, a Mac OS X port of comskip (http://www.kaashoek.com/comskip/) designed to work with EyeTV.  ETVComskip allows users of EyeTV to enjoy commercial-free recorded television.  PyeTV provides capabilities of turning commercial skipping on and off from within Front Row, as well as starting a commercial search for recordings which do not have commercial markers already. You will have to install ETVComskip separately if you want this functionality. </p>

<p>InstallationDownload the .dmg file.  Double click to open the .dmg file and run the installer application.  The installer will prompt for an administrator&#39;s password (because it needs to be installed in /Library).  Further, if you do not have &quot;Enable access for assistive devices&quot; turned on in the Universal access preference pane, the installer will attempt to do that for you after another password prompt. </p>

<p>A few users have reported problems with the .dmg file. In this case, make sure that the extension on the file is .dmg and try again to open it.  This should resolve the problem. </p>

<p>Special Note for Snow Leopard and EyeTV 3.2.1The 10.6.2 update to Snow Leopard broke the usage of the Apple remote to control EyeTV. Until there is an update to EyeTV, the default remote driver will not work.  The work around I&#39;ve found us to install the Candleair driver from: http://www.iospirit.com/labs/candelair/, and enable Leopard combatibility mode in the corresponding preference pane. </p>

<p>NewsNov 28, 2009Version 2.0 released, with Snow Leopard support. </p>

<p>This version also includes support for the favorite channels playlist. </p>

<p>Oct 24, 2008Version 1.2 released!  Changes include </p>

<p>The channels list now has program info as metadata, if it&#39;s available from EyeTV.   Cleaner interaction with EyeTV.  We no longer return to PyeTV on &quot;pause&quot; but only on &quot;menu&quot; which makes it possible to pause live tv, etc.   Problems switching back and forth between watching live tv and recorded programs are resolved. EyeTV windows closed when Front Row exits Improved Program guide access. Can now handle non-ascii characters in recording titles. See Version_1_2_Changelog for details. </p>

<p>Apr 16, 2008Version 1.1 released.  This version features image previews of the recordings, and has a very similar look to browsing the music library in Front Row.  The recordings list is cleaned up slightly, sorted by date, and the recordings are shown in a slightly smaller font to allow for longer episode titles to be seen without scrolling.</p>
 title : The pyetv Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyevolveDescriptionThis project focus on development of a complete cross-platform (Windows, Linux) framework for Genetic Algorithms in pure python. </p>

<p>The project is in active development, and I&#39;m doing great efforts to release a good version and documentation soon. </p>

<p>Main features: Many selector algorithms like: Rank Selector Uniform Selector Roulette Wheel Selector Tournament Selector Pure python, you can use in any platform which runs python; Easy to use, easy for end-user; Simple to customize Create new representations, genetic operators; </p>

<p>You can view the Tutorial </p>

<p> - Christian S. Perone </p>

<p>News 05/08/2008 Added documentation to the code; Created API Docs. </p>

<p>04/08/2008 I&#39;ve created a Tutorial. </p>

<p>31/07/2008 Released Pyevolve 0.3 (changes in ChangeLogVersion03)! </p>

<p>29/06/2008 Good news, Pyevolve was figured in the &quot;10 Must-Have Python Packages for Social Scientists&quot; !  </p>

<p>25/01/2008 Released Pyevolve 0.2 (changes in ChangeLogVersion02)! </p>

<p>Some code example (SimpleCodeExample)from pyevolve import G1DList
<br/>from pyevolve import GSimpleGA
<br/>from pyevolve import Selectors</p>

<p>def eval_func(ind):
<br/>   score = 0.0
<br/>   for x in range(0,len(ind)):
<br/>      if ind[x]==0: score += 0.1
<br/>   return score</p>

<p># Genome instance
<br/>genome = G1DList.G1DList(7)
<br/>genome.setInitParams(rangemin=0, rangemax=6)</p>

<p># The evaluator function (objective function)
<br/>genome.evaluator.set(eval_func)</p>

<p># Genetic Algorithm Instance
<br/>ga = GSimpleGA.GSimpleGA(genome)
<br/>ga.selector.set(Selectors.GRouletteWheel)</p>

<p># Do the evolution
<br/>ga.evolve()</p>

<p># Best individual
<br/>print ga.bestIndividual()
<br/>And the result: </p>

<p>- GenomeBase
<br/>        Evaluated:               True
<br/>        Score:                   0.70
<br/>        Fitness:                 0.70</p>

<p>        Slot name: Evaluator (Count: 1)
<br/>                Name: eval_func
<br/>                        Doc: No documentation !
<br/>        Slot name: Initializator (Count: 1)
<br/>                Name: G1DListInitializatorInteger
<br/>                        Doc: This is the init function !!
<br/>        Slot name: Mutator (Count: 1)
<br/>                Name: G1DListMutatorSwap
<br/>                        Doc: No documentation !
<br/>        Slot name: Crossover (Count: 1)
<br/>                Name: G1DListCrossoverSinglePoint
<br/>                        Doc: No documentation !</p>

<p>- G1DList
<br/>        List size:       7
<br/>        List:            [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]</p>
 title : The pyevolve Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyFFmpeg is a wrapper around FFmpeg&#39;s libavcodec, libavformat and libavutil libraries whose main purpose is to provide access to individual frames of video files of various formats (including MPEG and DIVX encoded videos), and, also in latest beta,to audio data. </p>

<p>Download PyFFmpeg </p>

<p>FFmpeghttp://ffmpeg.mplayerhq.hu/ is a software package containing libraries and utilities for encoding, decoding and converting audio and video files. It includes libavcodec, a leading audio/video codec library that can work with most video and audio formats. This library generally uses its own codec. And thus it does not depend on your operating system installed libraries. </p>

<p>Using FFmpeg and libavcodec you can develop applications that can parse and display video files and be sure they will work on most platform, including of course Linux, Macintosh and Windows boxes. </p>

<p>PyFFmpegThe libavcodec and libavformat libraries of the FFmpeg project are quite complex to use, especially from Python.  </p>

<p>PyFFmpeg provides a simple object oriented interface to those libraries. </p>

<p>PyFFmpeg-1 : Original releasePyFFmpeg has stayed in minimal status where it could be used to extract individual frames from video files and create PIL image objects from them.  </p>

<p>While there were several Python libraries that offer to play video files most  of them did not provide any API to extract individual frames, and this is the  reason PyFFmpeg was created. </p>

<p>A more complex wrapper around FFMPEG has been implemented within PyMedia.  However, PyMEDIA is now based on and old version of ffmpeg, and probably also need some minor rewrites. </p>

<p>ExampleHere&#39;s a simple example that extracts the first frame from a video file and saves it in .png format. You&#39;ll need PIL to run it. </p>

<p>import pyffmpeg</p>

<p>stream = pyffmpeg.VideoStream()
<br/>stream.open(&#39;myvideo.avi&#39;)
<br/>image = stream.GetFrameNo(0)
<br/>image.save(&#39;firstframe.png&#39;)PyFFmpeg : Upcoming betaWe have recenlty performed a complete rewrite of PyFFMPEG. </p>

<p>It is now available from the normal SVN download in the standard directory  for testing purposes, and also as a source package in the download section. </p>

<p>The new PyFFMPEG is bound to NumPy rather than to Python Imaging Library (PIL),  it supports video and audio decoding. (But still not encoding or streaming/thought we are thinking about it) </p>

<p>Usage ExamplesThe previous example shall still work ( at least on the files where it used to work ). </p>

<p>Here examples of new usage : </p>

<p>import pyffmpeg</p>

<p>## create the reader object
<br/>mp=FFMpegReader()</p>

<p>## open an audio-video file
<br/>mp.open(&quot;your file.mpg&quot;)
<br/>tracks=mp.get_tracks()</p>

<p>## define a function to be called back each time a frame is read...
<br/>def obs(f):
<br/>  display(f[2]) # you have to write your display function</p>

<p>tracks[0].set_observer(obs)</p>

<p>mp.run()Many working examples can be found in the example directory </p>

<p>For those that prefer PILSome users that  were using pyffmpeg for non scientific purpose to prefer PIL. Hence, A support for PIL will still be maintained but functionalities will be limitated (No audiosupport / Only RGB pixels) </p>

<p>Currently, numpy is still required for compiling in all the cases.</p>

 title : The pyfusion Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>13 May 09: Note: development has slowed on this branch because Dave is working on a new version of pyfusion, designed to be more modular, extensible and easier to use. development version is over at http://github.com/dpretty/pyfusion/tree/dev for now </p>

<p>The pyfusion library has been designed to allow data analysis code to be written independent of (magnetic confinement) device and data acquisition system. </p>

<p>Using SQLAlchemy, object oriented code is mapped to a SQL database (object-relational mapping). </p>

<p>For more information, please refer to the wiki: PyFusionOverview </p>

<p>Some examplesShowing a singular value decomposition (SVD) of H-1NF Mirnov dataimport pyfusion</p>

<p>diag_name = &#39;mirnovbeans&#39;</p>

<p>shot_number = 58080</p>

<p>s = pyfusion.get_shot(shot_number)
<br/>s.load_diag(diag_name)</p>

<p>t0 = 0.030
<br/>t1 = 0.035</p>

<p>ts = pyfusion.new_timesegment(s, diag_name, t0,t1)
<br/>ts_svd = pyfusion.new_svd(ts)</p>

<p>ts_svd.plot()gives an interactive view of the SVD:  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Preprocessing of H1 data for data miningimport pyfusion
<br/>diag_name = &#39;mirnovbeans&#39;</p>

<p>shot_number = 58087</p>

<p>s = pyfusion.get_shot(shot_number)
<br/>s.load_diag(diag_name)</p>

<p>from pyfusion.datamining.clustering.core import generate_flucstrucs</p>

<p>generate_flucstrucs(s, diag_name, &#39;test_flucstrucs&#39;, store_chronos=True)</p>

 title : The pygraphics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyGraphics Installation Instructions:   </p>

<p>WindowsInstall LinuxInstall </p>

<p>PyGraphics OverviewPyGraphics aims to translate the new features of Media Computation from its JPython version to CPython. We aim to implement support for image, sound and video manipulation. As well as adding simple 3D capabilities. </p>

<p>We are inheriting the media.py file from the Georgia development Team 7, and basing our effort on their previous work. </p>

<p>The website for the Georgia development team. Wing 101 IDE that media.py needs to work with. The CPython release that we are working with.  Project OverviewThe PyGraphics project aims to provide Media Computation technology for use in introductory computer science courses at the University of Toronto. This technology consists of a simplified multimedia framework originally written by Mark Guzdial for use in his introductory Computational Media course CS1315/16 in the College of Computing at the Georgia  Institute of Technology. This multimedia library allows first year students to better learn basic computing concepts through the manipulation of images, sounds, and videos through the Python programming language. In addition, the library provides professors and teaching assistants with a means to create simple interactive demonstrations to augment the traditional means of teaching.</p>

 title : The pyipopt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Ipopt is a state-of-the-art optimization solver for nonlinear optimization problems. Unfortunately, the only interface available is C/C++ or Fortran. As Python becomes more popular these days, a connector to python is necessary.  This project consists several major parts: </p>

<p>1. A simple connector using python list to pass the value for users don&#39;t want to get things done quickly. </p>

<p>2. A complicated version of pyipopt that using numpy data types from users who wants to do high performance computation.  </p>

<p>3. With the help of nlpy, now you can directly manipulate AMPL nl file in python directly and send it to ipopt with one or two lines of code.  </p>

<p>4. A connector to openopt (DONE by openopt community now) </p>

<p>5. Pyipopt support multiple instances of problems. Aka, you can use one module and solve multiple problem instances.  </p>

<p>Pyipopt is reasonably robust according to my own test.  </p>

<p>This work is sponsored by my advisor Dr. Yixin Chen&#39;s Early Career Young Investigator Award from the Department of Energy and is done at Washington University.</p>
 title : The pyiso8601 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Many file formats and standards use the ISO 8601 date format (e.g. 2007-01-14T20:34:22+00:00) to store dates in a neutral, unambiguous manner. This simple module parses the most common forms encountered and returns datetime objects. </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; import iso8601
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; iso8601.parse_date(&quot;2007-06-20T12:34:40+03:00&quot;)
<br/>datetime.datetime(2007, 6, 20, 12, 34, 40, tzinfo=)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; iso8601.parse_date(&quot;2007-06-20T12:34:40Z&quot;)
<br/>datetime.datetime(2007, 6, 20, 12, 34, 40, tzinfo=)</p>

<p>Installationeasy_install PyJawDevelopmentPyJaw is still very much under active development.  0.2 will bring a much easier interface for creating a Rejaw client with built in threading. </p>

<p>To install the current development version check out the current code and install: </p>

<p>$ svn checkout http://pyjaw.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ pyjaw
<br/>$ cd pyjaw
<br/>$ python setup.py developAlternatively, install the development version using easy_install: </p>

<p>$ easy_install PyJaw==dev</p>

 title : The pylolz Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyLOLzA Python library for translating English to LOLspeak </p>

<p>Created by Stephen Newey </p>

<p>Original Python code, copyright 2008 Stephen Newey </p>

<p>Inspired by Dave Dribin&#39;s Ruby library lolspeak (http://www.dribin.org/dave/lolspeak/) </p>

<p>tranzlator.yml dictionary by Dave Dribin </p>

<p>Python code licensed under the Mozilla Public License v1.1. http://www.mozilla.org/MPL/MPL-1.1.html </p>

<p>Requires: PyYAML (http://pyyaml.org/)_ </p>

<p>Download latest version (0.3): http://pylolz.googlecode.com/files/pylolz-0.3.tar.gz </p>

<p>Usage:
<br/>Run the lolz.py file from the command line followed by a word or sentence to translate</p>

<p>In code:
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; from pylolz.lolz import Tranzlator
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; t = Tranzlator()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; t.translate_sentence(&#39;Hello. My English skills are perfect.&#39;)
<br/>&#39;y halo thar. mah english skillz r perfik.&#39;</p>
 title : The pymapper Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The pymc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyMCBayesian estimation, particularly using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), is an increasingly relevant approach to statistical estimation. However, few statistical software packages implement MCMC samplers, and they are non-trivial to code by hand. PyMC is a python module that implements the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm as a python class, and is extremely flexible and applicable to a large suite of problems. PyMC includes methods for summarizing output, plotting, goodness-of-fit and convergence diagnostics. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>DownloadSource code and binary packages for the 2.0 release are now available at the Python Package Index. If a binary package is not available for your platform, building PyMC should pose no particular problem, requiring only a C and Fortran compiler. Build instructions can be found in the user guide included in the source distribution. </p>

<p>Previous users of the 1.3 version should note that the syntax used to define statistical models has changed significantly. While it is always difficult to break backward-compatibility, the changes bring drastic improvements in performance and flexibility.  </p>

<p>ExamplesTo get an idea of what a PyMC2 model looks like, we have provided a few examples: </p>

<p>Simple occupancy model using latent states Waterfowl band recovery model Simple pricing model Hierarchical Poisson failure rates Fisheries surplus production model (updated Aug. 2009) Salamander occupancy estimation model Simple probit regression model </p>

<p>For users familiar with BUGS, here are a few examples that are translated directly from BUGS models; the original code is included in each file as a docstring: </p>

<p>Koala sighting model (from Link &amp; Barker 2009) Conditional multinomial mark-recapture model (from Link &amp; Barker 2009) Unconditional multinomial mark-recapture model (apparently not possible in BUGS) </p>

<p>User-contributed tutorials and recipes can be found in in the wiki. More examples can be found in the examples folder in the source tree. </p>

<p>Also, the user guide contains a tutorial section. </p>

<p>SupportThe PyMC User’s Guide contains detailed installation instructions, as well as some MCMC theoretical background and a tutorial on using PyMC. The user&#39;s guide is available in the downloads section. </p>

<p>For help, questions or suggestions on a particular topic related to PyMC, please visit the PyMC Google Group. </p>

<p>If you wish to file a bug report or suggest enhancements to PyMC, please submit an issue at our issues page. </p>

<p>Note: A large number of bugs and issues have been fixed since PyMC 2.0 was released. We therefore recommend that serious users build a version for themselves using the current development code, rather than run the released version.</p>
 summary : <p>Pymediawiki a text-to-HTML conversion tool for web writers. Pymediawiki allows you to write using an easy-to-read, easy-to-write plain text format.</p>
 title : The pymediawiki Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The pymel Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Python in Maya Done RightPyMEL makes python scripting with Maya work the way it should. Maya&#39;s command module is a direct translation of mel commands into python commands. The result is a very awkward and unpythonic syntax which does not take advantage of python&#39;s strengths -- particulary, a flexible, object-oriented design. PyMEL builds on the cmds module by organizing many of its commands into a class hierarchy, and by customizing them to operate in a more succinct and intuitive way. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Project GoalsCreate an open-source python module for Maya that is intuitive to MEL users and python users alike Fix bugs and design limitations in Maya&#39;s python modues, maya.cmds and maya.mel Keep code concise and readable Add organization through class hierarchy and sub-modules Provide documentation accessible via html and the builtin help() function Make it &quot;just work&quot; Production ProvenSince its release over a year ago PyMEL, has accumulated an impressive resume in both feature films and games: </p>

<p>DreamWorks: Fung Fu Panda, Shrek 4, Monsters Vs Aliens, and How to Train Your Dragon Luma Pictures: Pirates of the Carribean: At World&#39;s End, Harry Potter 6, and Wolverine ImageMovers Digital: Robert Zemeckis&#39; upcoming A Christman Carol Here&#39;s what Seth Gibson of Bungie Studios, makers of the hit game Halo, has to say: </p>

<p>&quot;Having done production python code myself for many years, wrapping my head around Maya&#39;s native implementation took a little bit of time. With PyMel, I can think and write the python code and syntax I&#39;m already used to, which speeds up my development time considerably. It&#39;s also going to help our other Technical Artists with their Python learning curve, since PyMEL&#39;s syntax is consistent with most other python packages. Kudos to the PyMel team for such a well thought out project!&quot; </p>

<p>What&#39;s NewAPI HybridizationPyMEL 0.9 is a dramatic leap forward in the evolution of python in Maya. The node and attribute classes have been rewritten from the ground up to use the python API as their foundation, increasing the speed and fidelity of PyMEL&#39;s object-oriented design. </p>

<p>PyMEL harnesses the API to create a name-independent representation of your object. This means that the annoying inconsistencies of string comparisons are over: no more worrying about short names versus long names, DAG paths, unique paths, instance paths... it&#39;s all handled intelligently for you. And what&#39;s more, if anything causes the name of yourobject to change it will automatically be reflected in your python object. </p>

<p>PyMEL node classes now include hundreds of new methods derived from the API, but with the same intuitive and unified design as before. With PyMEL you get the benefits of API speed and versatility without the advanced learning curve. </p>

<p>BSD LicensePyMEL is released under the BSD license, which is as open as open source gets. Your studio can freely use, contribute to, and modify this module with no strings attached. </p>

<p>Improved Standalone SupportUnlike the maya module, PyMEL behaves the same in a standalone interpreter as it does in an GUI session. When pymel detects that it is being imported in a standalone interpreter it performs these operations: </p>

<p>initializes maya.standalone parses your Maya.env and adds variables to your environment sources Autodesk&#39;s initialization MEL scripts sources user preferences sources userSetup.mel This makes using Maya in a standalone environment the ideal environment for for batch processes and even rendering. </p>

<p>Tighter MEL IntegrationCalling MEL from python is still an unfortunate necessity, so PyMEL makes it as easy as possible. This release builds on PyMEL&#39;s already vastly improved method, which allows you to call a mel procedure as if it was a python function: </p>

<p>values = [&#39;one&#39;, &#39;two&#39;, &#39;three&#39;, &#39;four&#39;]</p>

<p># default
<br/>maya.mel.eval( &#39;stringArrayRemoveDuplicates( {&quot;&#39;+&#39;&quot;,&quot;&#39;.join(values)+&#39;&quot;})&#39;)</p>

<p># PyMEL
<br/>mel.stringArrayRemoveDuplicates( values )
<br/>In the new release, when a MEL script called from PyMEL raises an error, you will get the specific MEL error message in the python traceback, along with line numbers!For example, here&#39;s a procedure &quot;myScript&quot; with a line that will result in an error: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; mel.eval( &#39;&#39;&#39;global proc myScript( string $stringArg, float $floatArray[] ){
<br/>...     float $donuts = `ls -type camera`;}&#39;&#39;&#39;)When we call the procedure via PyMEL, we can quickly determine the problem, because PyMEL gives us the error and the line number: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; mel.myScript( &#39;foo&#39;, [] )
<br/>Traceback (most recent call last):
<br/>    ...
<br/>MelConversionError: Error occurred during execution of MEL script: line 2: Cannot convert data of type string[] to type float.Also, getting and setting MEL global variables is accomplished via a special dictionary-like object, which keeps it simple and intuitive: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; melGlobals[&#39;$gMainFileMenu&#39;]
<br/>mainFileMenu
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; melGlobals[&#39;$gGridDisplayGridLinesDefault&#39;] = 2Who is PyMEL for?For the NoviceObject-oriented programming, like that provided by PyMEL, is more intuitive to learn because the functionality of an object is directly associated with the object itself. For an artist starting to program in Maya, the first question you might ask is &quot;what can I do with this node?&quot; Using a procedural approach, like that offered by MEL or maya.cmds, you&#39;ll have to dig through the hundreds of MEL commands looking for the one that you want. For a camera node, the camera MEL command is easy to find, but did you find orbit, track, dolly, and tumble, which also work on cameras? In PyMEL, all you have to do is type help(Camera) in the python script editor to find out all the things a camera node can do, or just look up the Camera class in the PyMEL docs. </p>

<p>For the MEL ScripterWhen we say PyMEL is concise and easy to read, we mean it. </p>

<p>MELstring $sel[] = `ls -sl`;
<br/>string $shapes[] = `listRelatives -s $sel[0]`;
<br/>string $conn[] = `listConnections -s 1 -d 0 $shapes[0]`;
<br/>setAttr ( $conn[0] + &quot;.radius&quot;) 3;PyMELselected()[0].getShape().inputs()[0].radius.set(3)For the Technical DirectorFor those looking to master python in a production environment, PyMEL is more than a module for Maya scripting, it is a repository of example python code -- a self-contained pipeline demonstrating advanced python concepts like function factories, metaclasses, and decorators, as well as essential production practices such as parsing, pickling, logging, and unit testing. </p>

<p>For those who are already masters of python and who naturally expect more out of a python package, PyMEL is for you, too. It was written in for use in production by experiened programmers with a vision for how to add object-oriented design to Maya. </p>

<p>Powerful ClassesNode classes for every node type </p>

<br/>cam.track(left=10)
<br/>cam.addBookmark(&#39;new&#39;)An Attribute class organizes all the attribute commands in one place </p>

<br/>    backupDir.mkdir()
<br/>for file in basedir.files( &#39;*.mb&#39; ):
