<br/>    optionVar[&#39;numbers&#39;] = [1,24,47]
<br/>optionVar[&#39;numbers&#39;].append(9)
<br/>numArray = optionVar.pop(&#39;numbers&#39;)PyMEL provides customized operators for succinct scripting: </p>

<p>cam.tx &gt;&gt; cam.ty  # connect operator
<br/>cam.tx // cam.ty  # disconnect operatorIncludes Tools to Ease Your Transition to Pythonmel-to-python translator for converting mel script into python scripts python-to-mel plugin factory for turning python classes into mel commands  ipymel customized python interpreter </p>

<p>Code Comparisonwith Melstring $objs[] = `ls -type transform`;
<br/>for ($x in $objs) {
<br/>    print (longNameOf($x)); print &quot;\n&quot;;</p>

<p>    // make and break some connections
<br/>    connectAttr( $x + &quot;.sx&quot;) ($x + &quot;.sy&quot;);
<br/>    connectAttr( $x + &quot;.sx&quot;) ($x + &quot;.sz&quot;);
<br/>    disconnectAttr( $x + &quot;.sx&quot;) ($x + &quot;.sy&quot;);
<br/>    string $conn[] = `listConnections -s 0 -d 1 -p 1 ($x + &quot;.sx&quot;)`;
<br/>    for ($inputPlug in $conn)
<br/>        disconnectAttr ($x + &quot;.sx&quot;) $inputPlug;</p>

<p>    // add and set a string array attribute with the history of this transform&#39;s shape
<br/>    if ( !`attributeExists &quot;newAt&quot; $x`)
<br/>        addAttr -ln newAt -dataType stringArray $x;
<br/>    string $shape[] = `listRelatives -s $x`;
<br/>    string $history[] = `listHistory $shape[0]`;
<br/>    string $elements = &quot;&quot;;
<br/>    for ($elem in $history)
<br/>        $elements += &quot;&quot;&quot; + $elem + &quot;&quot; &quot;;
<br/>    eval (&quot;setAttr -type stringArray &quot; + $x + &quot;.newAt &quot; + `size $history` + $elements);
<br/>    print `getAttr ( $x + &quot;.newAt&quot; )`;</p>

<p>    // get and set some attributes
<br/>    setAttr ($x + &quot;.rotate&quot;) 1 1 1;
<br/>    float $trans[] = `getAttr ($x + &quot;.translate&quot;)`;
<br/>    float $scale[] = `getAttr ($x + &quot;.scale&quot;)`;
<br/>    $trans[0] *= $scale[0];
<br/>    $trans[1] *= $scale[1];
<br/>    $trans[2] *= $scale[2];
<br/>    setAttr ($x + &quot;.scale&quot;) $trans[0] $trans[1] $trans[2];</p>

<p>    // call some other scripts
<br/>    myMelScript( `nodeType $x`, $trans );
<br/>}default Pythonobjs = cmds.ls( type= &#39;transform&#39;)
<br/>if objs is not None:                    # returns None when it finds no matches
<br/>    for x in objs:
<br/>        print mm.eval(&#39;longNameOf(&quot;%s&quot;)&#39; % x)</p>

<p>        # make and break some connections
<br/>        cmds.connectAttr(   &#39;%s.sx&#39; % x,  &#39;%s.sy&#39; % x )
<br/>        cmds.connectAttr(   &#39;%s.sx&#39; % x,  &#39;%s.sz&#39; % x )
<br/>        cmds.disconnectAttr( &#39;%s.sx&#39; % x,  &#39;%s.sy&#39; % x)</p>

<p>        conn = cmds.listConnections( x + &quot;.sx&quot;, s=0, d=1, p=1)
<br/>        # returns None when it finds no matches
<br/>        if conn is not None:
<br/>            for inputPlug in conn:
<br/>                cmds.disconnectAttr( x + &quot;.sx&quot;, inputPlug )</p>

<p>        # add and set a string array attribute with the history of this transform&#39;s shape
<br/>        if not mm.eval( &#39;attributeExists &quot;newAt&quot; &quot;%s&quot;&#39; % x):
<br/>            cmds.addAttr(  x, ln=&#39;newAt&#39;, dataType=&#39;stringArray&#39;)
<br/>        shape = cmds.listRelatives( x, s=1 )
<br/>        if shape is not None:
<br/>            history = cmds.listHistory( shape[0] )
<br/>        else:
<br/>            history = []
<br/>        args = tuple( [&#39;%s.newAt&#39; % x, len(history)] + history )
<br/>        cmds.setAttr( *args ,  type= &#39;stringArray&#39; )</p>

<p>        # get and set some attributes
<br/>        cmds.setAttr ( &#39;%s.rotate&#39; % x, 1,  1, 1 )
<br/>        scale = cmds.getAttr ( &#39;%s.scale&#39; % x )
<br/>        scale = scale[0] # maya packs the previous result in a list for no apparent reason
<br/>        trans = list( cmds.getAttr ( &#39;%s.translate&#39; % x )[0] )  # the tuple must be converted to a list for item assignment
<br/>        trans[0] *= scale[0]
<br/>        trans[1] *= scale[1]
<br/>        trans[2] *= scale[2]
<br/>        cmds.setAttr ( &#39;%s.scale&#39; % x, trans[0], trans[1], trans[2] )
<br/>        mm.eval(&#39;myMelScript(&quot;%s&quot;,{%s,%s,%s})&#39; % (cmds.nodeType(x), trans[0], trans[1], trans[2]) )with Pymelfrom pymel import *                   # safe to import into main namespace
<br/>for x in ls( type=&#39;transform&#39;):
<br/>    print x.longName()                # object oriented design</p>

<p>    # make and break some connections
<br/>    x.sx &gt;&gt; x.sy                      # connection operator
<br/>    x.sx &gt;&gt; x.sz
<br/>    x.sx // x.sy                      # disconnection operator
<br/>    x.sx.disconnect()                 # smarter methods -- (automatically disconnects all inputs and outputs when no arg is passed)</p>

<p>    # add and set a string array attribute with the history of this transform&#39;s shape
<br/>    x.setAttr( &#39;newAt&#39;, x.getShape().history(), force=1 )</p>

<p>    # get and set some attributes
<br/>    x.rotate.set( [1,1,1] )
<br/>    trans = x.translate.get()
<br/>    trans *= x.scale.get()           # vector math
<br/>    x.translate.set( trans )         # ability to pass list/vector args
<br/>    mel.myMelScript(x.type(), trans) # automatic handling of mel proceduresthere&#39;s a reason why python is rapidly becoming the industry stanadard. with pymel, python and maya finally play well together. </p>

 summary : <p>PyMSN-IM is a Jabber transport to MSN instant messaging network. </p>

<p>PyMSN-IM is a fork from James Bunton&#39;s PyMSNt. The purpose of this fork is to continue the active development of his work. </p>

<p>Project just started, and main difference from original PyMSNt is support for recent changes in MSN protocol. </p>

<p>If you are jabber server administrator with PyMSNt installed and got report Error in line: VER 1 MSNP11 (Invalid version response) then you have two solutions: </p>

<p>Patch PyMSNt manually check this thread Or use PyMSN-IM </p>

<p>You can submit feature requests and bug reports to the Py-transports mailing list </p>

<p>Feel free to enter to our room at: pymsn-im@muc.ejabberd.im </p>

<p>Stay tunned for more news :D</p>
 title : The pynext Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SummaryA python web programming library based around modern trends in web-development like WSGI, XML, XML databases, automatic form generation, advanced authentication schemes and much more. </p>

<p>Status of the projectPlanning. </p>

<p>DetailsPyNext is in many ways a natural evolution of Enkel. It has many of the same goals and as such might be considered as Enkel 2.0. The sections below explains the most important ideas/goals of PyNext. </p>

<p>Tight XML intergrationWe are planning XML Scheme, XPath, RelaxNG, DOM3, SAX and XQuery implementations. This will enable us to: </p>

<p>Create an XML database (in C++ with a python api). Implement a good xml-based config file system which autovalidates. Implement XML based models which can be used to validate data from web-forms (WAP, XHTML1, XForms..) and to autogenerate forms. Implement the XML TopicMap standard. </p>

<p>We are currently considering using these libraries to achieve this: </p>

<p>Apache Xerces XQilla Boost.Python lxml </p>

<p>WSGI utilities and serverEnkel already has much of this: </p>

<p>WSGI server for HTTP, SCGI and CGI. WSGI application runner which can be used in automatic tests (unit and doc tests). Utility functions for working with WSGI environment dicts. but a review and cleanup is required. </p>

<p>InternationalizationThis should probably be improved a bit from the implementation in Enkel. </p>

<p>Filesystem abstraction layerA filesystem abstraction layer similar to gnome VFS. </p>

<p>Strong automatic testing supportWe are working on a JUnit-4, testNG and unittest inspired test framework. Planned features: </p>

<p>Automatic testing of programs using posix threads and stackless threads. Tests will be able to depend on other tests. A test runner application will be included. Something like &quot;python -m pynext.test.runner myproject.MyTest&quot;. Compatibility layer for unittest. A test will be able to belong to one or more groups. Groups can be excluded/included by the test runner. </p>

<p>MailWe wish to have strong mail support. Our first goal is an object-oriented and easy to use imap library.</p>

 summary : <p>Pyrit takes a step ahead in attacking WPA-PSK and WPA2-PSK, the protocol that today de-facto protects public WIFI-airspace. The project&#39;s goal is to estimate the real-world security provided by these protocols. Pyrit does not provide binary files or wordlists and does not encourage anyone to participate or engage in any harmful activity. This is a research project, not a cracking tool. </p>

<p>Pyrit&#39;s implementation allows to create massive databases, pre-computing part of the WPA/WPA2-PSK authentication phase in a space-time-tradeoff. The performance gain for real-world-attacks is in the range of three orders of magnitude which urges for re-consideration of the protocol&#39;s security. Exploiting the computational power of GPUs, Pyrit is currently by far the most powerful attack against one of the</p>

 summary : <p>pyroms is a suite of tools for working with the Regional Ocean Modeling System.  A grid class allows creation, reading and writing of model grids.  Other tools are included to facilitate analysis and visualization of model output. </p>

<p>The modules include: </p>

<p>boundaryclick - Interactive boundary generation for use with Gridgen, a MATLAB-based  orthogonal grid generator. </p>

<p>Dataset - A wrapper for netCDF4.Dataset and MFnetCDF4.Dataset </p>

<p>depths - Calculates regular depths from S-coordinate depths and parameters. </p>

<p>focus - Creates focus elements for use with Gridgen. </p>

<p>greatcircle - Calculates great circle distances. </p>

<p>grid - Creates a ROMS input grid. </p>

<p>gshhs - Reads Global Self-consistant Hierarchical High-resolution Shorelines (GSHHS) binary files. </p>

<p>ocean - Calculates density as a function of salinity, temperature, and pressure.  Also calculates O2 saturation concentrations for a given temperature and pressure at STP. </p>

<p>ocean_time - </p>

<p>polyclick - Interactive polygon generation. </p>

<p>polygeom - Calculates if a point lies within a given polygon. </p>

<p>pupynere - a PUre PYthon NEtcdf REader </p>

<p>roms_tools - Tools for working with ROMS model input and output including: </p>

<p>rot2d - Rotates vectors by an angle. nanmask - Obtains the land/ocean mask. zatr - Finds z at rho points. zatw - Finds z at w points. scoordr - Finds z at rho points. scoordw - Finds z at w points. isoslice - Calculates a horizontal or vertical slice of a property. shrink - Shrinks an array to fit a specified shape. zslice -  iso_integrate -  surface -  transect - Interpolates a property on a horizontal grid to a transect. N2 - Calculates the stratification frequency given rho and z. arg_nearest - Returns the indices of the N-dim arrays closes to a given N-dim vector. nc_gls_dissipation - Calculates the dissipation based on TKE, GLS and the GLS scheme parameters. nc_N2 - Calculates the buoyancy frequency squared. nc_curl - nc_div - nc_pstrain -      step3d_t - </p>

<p>velocity - Calculates vector velocities from u and v components.</p>
 title : The pyroms Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The pyroteknix Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Create and customize fireworks for Garry&#39;s Mod 10., </p>
 summary : <p>Aboutpysage is a lightweight high-level message passing library supporting actor based concurrency.   </p>

<p>It also extends the &quot;actor model&quot; to support actor partitioning/grouping to further scalability.  pysage has a simple high-level interface.  Messages are serialized and sent lightweight using pipes or domain sockets across local &quot;groups&quot;.  In the case of network messages, UDP is used. </p>

<p>simple pythonic API efficient message propagation within group, across group, across network network messages can optionally be configured to be reliable and/or ordered using UDP grouping - actors can be partitioned into groups that are run in separate os processes process-local singleton manager - actor registration, discovery, message propagation publisher/subscriber pattern built-in </p>

<p>pysage strives to stay thin and lightweight. </p>

<p>Installationpysage can be installed via setuptools: </p>

<p>easy_install pysageUsageHere, we have a simple actor that receives a &quot;take damage&quot; message in a 30 ticks/sec game loop. </p>

<p>import time
<br/>from pysage import Actor, ActorManager, Message</p>

<p>mgr = ActorManager.get_singleton()</p>

<p>class BombMessage(Message):
<br/>    properties = [&#39;damage&#39;]
<br/>    packet_type = 101</p>

<p>class Player(Actor):
<br/>    subscriptions = [&#39;BombMessage&#39;]
<br/>    def handle_BombMessage(self, msg):
<br/>        print &#39;I took %s damage from the bomb&#39; % msg.get_property(&#39;damage&#39;)</p>

<p>mgr.register_actor(Player(), &#39;player1&#39;)
<br/>mgr.queue_message(BombMessage(damage=10))</p>

<p>while True:
<br/>    processed = mgr.tick()
<br/>    time.sleep(.03)pysage allows you to use this same simple API, for messaging across processes and networks.   </p>

<p>pysage does not confine you to the constraints of the &quot;actor model&quot;.  For example, the &quot;grouping&quot; concept allows many actors to reside in the same process.  This allows you to avoid spawning too many os processes and reduce IPC overhead.   </p>

<p>Further, actors in the same group are local to each other, so they can have access to each other.  It&#39;s kind of like a: &quot;what happens in the group, stays in the group&quot; concept.  Although, using messages are encouraged instead of straight calls for most situations, even in the same pysage group. </p>

<p>Look at Documentation for more. </p>

<p>Statusstable release 1.5.2 </p>

<p>May 11th, 2009 - this includes the latest grouping with processes and networking functionality. </p>

<p>Licensepysage itself uses MIT license.   </p>

<p>However, if you need messaging across network, pysage uses pyraknet and therefore Raknet for UDP network implementation.  pyraknet uses the GNU Lesser General Public License. </p>

<p>RakNet is free to use for non-commercial use and purchasable for commercial use. It uses the Creative Commons Attribution - NonCommercial 2.5 license. </p>

<p>(see raknet/pyraknet)</p>
 title : The pysage Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The pyscripter Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>PyScripter is a free and open-source Python Integrated Development Environment (IDE) created with the ambition to become competitive in functionality with commercial Windows-based IDEs available for other languages. Being built in a compiled language is rather snappier than some of the other Python IDEs and provides an extensive blend of features that make it a productive Python development environment. </p>

<p>Support: Get support on PyScripter by emailing to pyscripter@gmail.com or by visiting the PyScripter Internet group and posting your questions and comments. </p>

<p>Notes:  </p>

<p>For compatibility with Python 2.6 and Python 3.0, since version 1.9.9.5, PyScripter requires the latest C++ Redistributable Package. This is automatically installed by Python 2.6 and Python 3.x. If you do not have any of these versions installed, then you need to download and install it manually.  If you are using a 64bit version of Windows note that PyScripter will only work if a 32bit version of Python is installed. It is recommended that you use the remote interpreter and debugger. To do that you need to download and install the Python package Rpyc version 2.6 available for download in the project downloads. </p>

<p>Donations: If you find PyScripter useful and make regular use, please consider making a donation. This will support further development of this project.</p>

 title : The pyshards Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Pyshards is a python and MySQL based horizontal partitioning and sharding toolkit.  Horizontal partitioning is a data segmenting pattern in which distinct groups of physical row-based datasets are distributed across multiple partitions.  When the partitions exist as independent databases and when they exist within a shared-nothing architecture they are known as shards. (Google apparently coined the term shard for such database partitions, and we&#39;ve adopted it here.) The goal is to provide big opportunities for database scalability while maintaining good performance. Sharded datasets can be queried individually (one shard) or collectively (aggregate of all shards). Pyshards uses a hash/modulo based algorithm to distribute data.   </p>

<p>One of the goals for this project was to provide a way to reasonably add polynomial capacity (number of original shards squared) without requiring re-balancing (re-sharding).   Another goal for the project was to provide a web-based shard monitoring tool, one that would allows admins to keep an eye on resource capacity. </p>

<p>Pyshards is no longer under development, but many of its core functions are implemented and are stable. There are a number of other projects that provide similar functionality, but their goals and/or implementations are quite different. Here are a few: </p>

<p>http://www.sqlalchemy.org/ SQLAlchemy </p>

<p>http://couchdb.apache.org/ CouchDB </p>

<p>http://incubator.apache.org/cassandra/ </p>

<p>To see what the Project Owner is up to now, visit http://www.devinvenable.com/</p>
 summary : <p>Lightweight python wrapper for Apache Solr., </p>

 title : The pysparql Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>It performs SELECT and ASK queries on an endpoint which implements the HTTP (GET or POST) bindings of the SPARQL Protocol.</p>

<p>Typed literals are converted to their equivalent Python types. If isodate module is present, date strings are parsed, and if rdflib is present, the URI literals are converted to URIRef objects, otherwise both types are treated as unicode strings.</p>

<p>The API is based on SPARQL JavaScript Library by Lee Feigenbaum and Elias Torres.</p>
 title : The pyspeech Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>speech.pyspeech.py is a Python module that provides a clean interface to Windows&#39;s voice recognition and text-to-speech capabilities.  It&#39;s very easy to use within a program that needs to listen for specific phrases or general speech, or that needs to speak. </p>

<p>It is available on PyPI at http://pypi.python.org/pypi/speech/ . </p>

<p>Questions?  You can contact Michael Gundlach, the developer, at gundlach at gmail.  Or, just file a bug under &quot;Issues&quot; above. </p>

<p>Example codeHere&#39;s a very simple program that repeats whatever it hears you say, until you say &quot;turn off&quot;. </p>

<p>import speech</p>

<p>while True:
<br/>    phrase = speech.input()
<br/>    speech.say(&quot;You said %s&quot; % phrase)
<br/>    if phrase == &quot;turn off&quot;:
<br/>        breakspeech.input() in the above example blocks the program until it hears you.  Below is the same examp</p>

 title : The pysv Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pysv is intended to make working with subversion a little easier, especially for folks who use branches. It wraps the svn command and figures out some of the fiddlier arguments for you. </p>

<p>It expects the repository layout to look like this: </p>

<p>.../myproject/trunk/
<br/>              branches/
<br/>              tags/The commands also expect to be run inside a checked out copy of the source. </p>

<p>The idea is to encourage good branching practice by making it very easy to do. </p>

<p>An example workflow: </p>

<p>svn co http://mysvn/projects/myproject/trunk myproject cd myproject Make some changes Realise that you should be on a branch pysv.py branch mybranch pysv.py switch mybranch work and svn commit pysv.py merge trunk pysv.py switch trunk pysv.py merge mybranch Resolve conflicts. pysv.py mergelog mybranch svn commit pysv.py rmbranch mybranch</p>

 title : The python-cobra Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Python, like Java and C#, is based on a stack-based virtual machine. It will be very existing if you can &quot;see&quot; the execution flow of the Python&#39;s vm. Cobra is such a project that visualize the vm. In Cobra, you can see how many bytecodes will be executed by the vm for a Python statement, you can see how a bytecode affecting the namespace and vm&#39;s stack.Understanding the mechanism of the vm will improve your understanding of Python. </p>

<p>The Cobra is made up by three main componenets: VM Server, Web Server and Web Client. I use Django to build web server. And in the web client, I use Ajax to communicate with web server. The web server will connect to the vm server to get information after it received the command from web client. The vm server is modified from Python itself. So here is the simplest architecture. </p>

<p>                   Browser  Web Server(Django)  VM Server(Modified Pythonn)</p>

 title : The python-elements Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is Elements</p>

<p>NOTE: Elements v2 is now being developed in SVN trunk, and the documentation will soon change. Elements will also change license from Apache to New BSD. The older version will however still use Apache.  </p>

<p>Elements is a Python library that provides simple parsing from XML to Python objects and back. It uses the well known ElementTree API to parse XML into Python objects. ElementTrees are very nice for parsing XML, but sometimes you want something even closer to Python. You want the XML to &quot;magically&quot; fill out your Python objects, and be able to access your values using dotted notation. This is what Elements does for you. Elements is similar to lxml.objectify and Amara2 Bindery. </p>

<p>However, Elements does not work well for all kinds of XML documents. It&#39;s a compromise. It&#39;s very good for parsing XML over HTTP based protocols such as Atom, but may not work well for you when the ordering of the elements is significant such as for XHTML or Apple Property Lists (PList). At first you might get the feeling of over-engineering when looking at Elements, but once your classes are defined, you will feel and enjoy the power of the this library.  </p>

<p>HistoryMost of the idea, design and code has been taken from the CouchDB Python Library. They have made a fantastic implementation of their Schema/Mapping which is a higher-level API for mapping between CouchDB documents and Python objects. With Elements v2 we are using the same design to parse and generate XML documents. </p>

<p>Elements v1 was based on the Atom parser of the gdata-python-client library. I really liked the idea and wanted to make it easy to use with other applications and for other XML formats as well. Elements v1 works well but the class declarations are quite verbose.  </p>

<p>SourceTo browse the Elements library source code, visit the Source tab. </p>

<p>ExampleA simple example. Lets say you want to parse the following XML document: </p>

<p>    Dag Brattli
<br/>    39
<br/>    
<br/>With Elements you have to declare a Python class for storing the information you are interested in. Unspecified elements and attributes will be ignored by the parser. </p>

<p>from elements import Element</p>

<p>class Example(Element):
<br/>    _tag = &#39;Example&#39;</p>

<p>    version = TextAttribute()</p>

<p>    hacker = BoolElement(tag=&quot;Hacker&quot;)
<br/>    name = TextElement(name=&quot;Name&quot;)
<br/>    age = IntegerElement(name=&quot;Age&quot;))    Now you are ready for some action: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; e = Example.from_string(example) # The XML doc above
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print e.name
<br/>Dag Brattli
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print e.age
<br/>39
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; print e.hacker
<br/>TrueNice! There are many other and more advanced features, so check out the documentation for details. </p>

<p>Enjoy </p>

<p>Dag Brattli</p>
 title : The python-fastcgi-iis Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The python-gamedev-brasil Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Esse é o repositório de código da comunidade Python Gamedev Brasil - uma comunidade dedicada ao desenvolvimento de jogos em python - que serve como um meio de compartilhar código relacionado ao tema, principalmente com fins didáticos. </p>

<p>Para que serve o repositório?O repositório não é centrado em um único projeto, mas sim dedicado a vários pequenos projetos, trechos úteis de código, exemplos, etc. Projetos que eventualmente crescerem deverão ser movidos para seu próprio repositório para uma maior organização. Enfim, esse espaço deve ser visto como um laboratório de experimentos para os membros da comunidade Python Gamedev Brasil. </p>

<p>Organização do repositórioPela pequena quantidade de código disponível no momento a organização do código ainda está sendo definida. </p>

<p>Como baixar o código?Você pode instalar um cliente SVN na sua máquina e seguir as instruções descritas na opção Checkout da aba Source (a que vem aberta por padrão ao clicar na aba) ou você pode escolher a opção Browse para ver a estrutura de diretórios do repositório e baixar arquivos direto pelo seu browser. </p>

<p>O código está concentrado no diretório trunk. Ao selecionar esse diretório na árvore ele abrirá e mostrará os subdiretórios. Sempre que a pequena seta for mostrada ao lado de um diretório, quer dizer q ele tem mais subdiretórios dentro dele, então, ao baixar os arquivos de um projeto, procure sempre observar se não existem subdiretórios que possam conter mais arquivos necessários para a execução dos códigos.</p>
 summary : <p>python-graph is a library for working with graphs in Python. </p>

<p>This software provides ﻿a suitable data structure for representing graphs and a whole set of important algorithms. </p>

<p>The code is appropriately documented and API reference is generated automatically by epydoc. </p>

<p>Comments, bug reports and suggestions are welcome. </p>

<p>Current release: 1.7.0 - Mar 20, 2010 </p>

<p>This release introduces Bellman-Ford shortest path algorithm and Edmonds–Karp maximum-flow/minimum-cut algorithm. </p>

<p>Please check our Changelog for detailed information. </p>

<p>Installing </p>

<p>If you have easy_install on your system, you can simply run: </p>

<p># easy_install python-graph-core </p>

<p>And, optionally, for Dot-Language support: </p>

<p># easy_install python-graph-dot </p>

<p>Otherwise, you can download a package from the Downloads page. </p>

<p>Dependencies: The Core module requires Python 2.6 or 3.x. Dot-Language support requires Python 2.6, pydot and pyparsing. </p>

<p>Provided features and algorithms: </p>

<p>Support for directed, undirected, weighted and non-weighted graphs Support for hypergraphs Canonical operations XML import and export DOT-Language import and export (for usage with Graphviz) Random graph generation Accessibility (transitive closure) Breadth-first search Critical path algorithm Cut-vertex and cut-edge identification Cycle detection Depth-first search Heuristic search (A* algorithm) Identification of connected components Maximum-flow / Minimum-cut (Edmonds-Karp algorithm) Minimum spanning tree (Prim&#39;s algorithm) Mutual-accessibility (strongly connected components) Shortest path search (Dijkstra&#39;s algorithm) Shortest path search (Bellman-Ford algorithm) Topological sorting Transitive edge identification</p>

 title : The python-markdown2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Markdown is a light text markup format and a processor to convert that to HTML. The originator describes it as follows: </p>

<p>Markdown is a text-to-HTML conversion tool for web writers. 
<br/>Markdown allows you to write using an easy-to-read,  
<br/>easy-to-write plain text format, then convert it to  
<br/>structurally valid XHTML (or HTML). 
<br/>-- http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/ 
<br/>This project provides a converter written in Python that closely matches the behaviour of the original Perl-implemented Markdown.pl. There is another Python markdown.py (see link at right), but markdown2.py is faster (see PerformanceNotes) and, to my knowledge, more correct (see TestingNotes). </p>

<p>Basic Python Module Usage&gt;&gt;&gt; import markdown2
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; markdown2.markdown(&quot;*boo!*&quot;)  # or use `html = markdown_path(PATH)`
<br/>u&#39;boo!</p>

<p>\n&#39;</p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; markdowner = Markdown()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; markdowner.convert(&quot;*boo!*&quot;)
<br/>u&#39;boo!</p>

<p>\n&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; markdowner.convert(&quot;**boom!**&quot;)
<br/>u&#39;boom!</p>

<p>\n&#39;Basic Command-Line Usage$ cat foo.txt
<br/>*boo!*
<br/>$ python markdown2.py foo.txt
<br/>boo!</p>

<p>$ python markdown2.py -h
<br/>...detailed command-line usage...Please see the Change Log for recent work.</p>
 title : The python-money Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>python-money provides carefully designed basic Python primitives for working with money and currencies.   </p>

<p>The primary objectives of this module is to aid in the development of financial applications by increasing testability and reusability, reducing code duplication and reducing the risk of defects occurring in the code.   </p>

<p>The module defines two basic Python classes -- a Currency class and a Money class.  It also pre-defines all the world&#39;s currencies, according to the ISO 4217 standard.  The classes define some basic operations for working with money, overriding Python&#39;s addition, substraction, multiplication, etc. in order to account for working with money in different currencies.  They also define currency-aware comparison operators.  To avoid floating point precision errors in monetary calculations, the module uses Python&#39;s Decimal type exclusively.  </p>

<p>The design of the module is based on the Money enterprise design pattern, as described in Martin Fowler&#39;s &quot;Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture&quot;.   </p>

<p>This project also contains Django helper classes for easy integration with python-money.   </p>

<p>Use this command to anonymously check out the latest project source code: </p>

<p># Non-members may check out a read-only working copy anonymously over HTTP.
<br/>svn checkout http://python-money.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ python-money-read-onlyThis project is sponsored by A115 Ltd.</p>
 title : The python-nose Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>nose provides an alternate test discovery and running process for unittest, one that is intended to mimic the behavior of py.test as much as is reasonably possible without resorting to too much magic. </p>

 title : The python-on-windows-docs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>While Python&#39;s own documentation set is well-maintained and meets most people&#39;s needs, people coming to Python on Windows suffer from a couple of drawbacks. One is that, historically, Python comes from a Unix background and some of its functionality reflects that. Even when low-level functions are available on Windows, they often refer to a Posix-compliant layer which Microsoft seems to have abandoned long ago. Another is that, while the pywin32 extensions are wide-ranging and actively maintained, their documentation tends towards the sparse and functional. </p>

<p>This project is a Sphinx-based documentation project which aims to provide example-based documentation for Windows developers looking to use Python for Windows-specific tasks. </p>

<p>The current status can usually be seen at: </p>

<p>http://timgolden.me.uk/python-on-windows</p>
 title : The python-openid-graph Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The python-openid-graph application can be used to store and return information about relationships between OpenId identity URLs.</p>
 title : The python-pages Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Python pages is a framework that makes it easier to develop web applications in Python. What is actually does is: </p>

<p>Provide an easy way to embed Python code into HTML, similar to PHP, JSP and other server side languages. Cross platform: runs on Mac, Windows and Linux Aims to be as declarative as possible. But the Python language is always available to do the same. Standards compliant: XHTML strict output (forced through the framework) Correct use of HTTP status codes Unicode support Make reusing HTML very easy. It uses concepts like master pages and inclusion of other pages as a web control. This is a very rich template mechanism. when pages act like web controls for other pages, they are simply available as a member variable of the other pages. It contains a built-in HTTP/1.1 web server but supports CGI. Uses clean URLs. There are no .page extensions, and suffixes are available as a variable. For instance, if there&#39;s a page /test.page, then the URL /test/abc will render /test.page, but pass the suffix /abc. This is totally not a new concept, but just very easy to use. Output filters for post processing of the generated XHTML tree. URLs will always be relative to the page where they&#39;ve been generated. This makes it very easy for included pages to use URLs relative to their own even if they are in a totally different directory. (This mechanism requires an output filter.) The framework does not yet run in IronPython, but the IPy team will hopefully fix it soon. </p>

<p>When Python 3000 will be released, this framework will also be ported to Python 3000, and we&#39;ll stop supporting earlier versions as well. </p>

<p>The core (or render engine) is stable and working very well. However, there are still a few other parts of the framework that can be improved. (like the documentation) </p>

<p>Interested in contributing to the framework? Please contact me. We certainly can use some additional developers. </p>

<p>In the futureSome things we are working on: </p>

<p>The render engine has built-in debug functionality. The current web based debugger isn&#39;t yet ready to use, but most of the back-end is already implemented. It should be possible to add or remove breakpoints while debugging and viewing the locals/globals. We will keep adding more web controls (like a forum, guestbook, ...) FastCGI support ExamplesNOTE: this examples are outdated and cannot be used anymore in this way. I have to rewrite them, but still, you get an idea of some possibilities. </p>

<p>A master page </p>

<p>    
<br/>        
<br/>    
<br/>    
<br/>        
<br/>    
<br/>A &#39;child&#39; using this master </p>

<p>Hello world page</p>

<p>    
<br/>        
<br/>    </p>

<p>    The factorial of 10 is </p>

<br/>xaml.textblock.Text = &#39;Hello world from IronPython&#39;</p>

 title : The python-payflowpro Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The python-pipelines Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Python Pipelines lets you solve a complex problem by breaking it up into a series of smaller, less complex programs. These simple programs, also called stages, can then be hooked together to get the results you want. The output resulting from a stage is the input to the next stage. A series of stages is called a pipeline. Each stage consists of a stage and its operands. Pipelines has many built-in stages; you may add your own written in Python or pseudo-Rexx.  </p>

<p>Stages may have more than one input and/or output stream; these streams may be connected to other stages in no particular order. </p>

<p>Pipelines is a superset of pipes as found in unix/linux shells. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartmann_pipeline for a more detailed description. </p>

<p>Python Pipelines may be invoked from a command prompt or incorporated into another Python program as an imported module. </p>

<p>This project is under construction. Contributions are welcome. Especially Python developers, formal language parsing algorithms, tester (especially those familiar with CMS Pipelines) and potential users. </p>

<p>Also see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_Pipelines. </p>

<p>Please contact the project manager Bob Gailer: bgailer at gmail dot com or by phone at 1-919-636-4239. </p>

<p>Python Pipelines is based on and is a subset of IBM&#39;s CMS/TSO Pipelines. See the IBM Reference Link at the upper right. </p>

<p>In CMS Pipelines users may write their own stages using the Rexx programming language. Due to the nature of the &#39;dispatcher&#39; (each stage is a co-routine) these program are more complex than they could be. </p>

<p>Python Pipeline supports coding the IBM way (in &#39;pseudo-Rexx&#39;), which makes it somewhat easy to incorporate legacy code or write new stages using a known technology. </p>

<p>Ideally, however, Python Pipeline users learn to write their own stages in Python, using a much simpler approach (each stage has a run() method that is invoked as many times as needed). 7 or more lines of Rexx replaced by 2 lines of Python!</p>
 title : The python-pocdock Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>pocdock is a PyGTK docking widget. </p>

<p>It&#39;s called pocdock because it&#39;s a proof-of-concept docking implementation, a playground for some ideas about how to dock a widget to another with Python and PyGTK. </p>

<p>Exampleimport gtk
<br/>import pdock</p>

<p>win = gtk.Window()
<br/>win.connect(&#39;destroy&#39;, lambda w: gtk.main_quit())
<br/>win.resize(350, 250)</p>

<p>dock = pdock.Dock()
<br/>win.add(dock)</p>

<p>item1 = pdock.DockItem(dock, &#39;id1&#39;, gtk.Label(&#39;Item 1&#39;), &#39;Label 1&#39;)
<br/>dock.add_item(item1)</p>

<p>item2 = pdock.DockItem(dock, &#39;id2&#39;, gtk.Label(&#39;Item 2&#39;), &#39;Label 2&#39;,
<br/>                       pos=gtk.POS_LEFT)
<br/>dock.add_item(item2)</p>

<p>win.show_all()</p>

<p>gtk.main()DocumentionInstallation instructions, requirements and an API documentation can be found here.</p>

 title : The python-spidermonkey Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Python-SpidermonkeyThis Python module allows for the implementation of Javascript? classes, objects and functions in Python, as well as the evaluation and calling of Javascript scripts and functions. It borrows heavily from Claes Jacobssen&#39;s Javascript Perl module, which in turn is based on Mozilla&#39;s PerlConnect Perl binding. </p>

<p>This code was originally written by John J. Lee in 2003.  After being unmaintained for a number of years, it was subsequently picked up by Atul Varma in 2008. </p>

<p>TutorialThe first thing you&#39;ll want to do is create a Runtime instance, which encapsulates a JSRuntime object from Spidermonkey.  From the JSAPI User Guide: </p>

<p>A JSRuntime, or runtime, is the space in which the Javascript variables, objects, scripts, and contexts used by your application are allocated. Every JSContext and every object in an application lives within a JSRuntime. They cannot travel to other runtimes or be shared across runtimes. Most applications only need one runtime. </p>

<p>Creating the Runtime instance is straightforward: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; from spidermonkey import Runtime
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; rt = Runtime()You&#39;ll then want to use the Runtime to create a Contextinstance, which encapsulates a JSContext object from Spidermonkey. From the JSAPI User Guide: </p>

<p>A JSContext, or context, is like a little machine that can do many things involving Javascript code and objects. It can compile and execute scripts, get and set object properties, call Javascript functions, convert Javascript data from one type to another, create objects, and so on. </p>

<p>In Firefox, for instance, a different context is used for each webpage you view.  A separate context is even created for each physical browser window, because much of Firefox&#39;s functionality is actually written in Javascript.  Contexts can have their own security policies associated with them, and objects can be shared between multiple contexts. </p>

<p>Creating a context in Python-Spidermonkey is done like so: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx = rt.new_context()Now that you&#39;ve got a context, you can do lots of things, like evaluating arbitrary Javascript expressions and using their results in Python code: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx.eval_script(&quot;1 + 2&quot;) + 3
<br/>6We can create classes in Python and access them in Javascript, too: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; class Foo:
<br/>...   def hello(self):
<br/>...     print &quot;Hello, Javascript world!&quot;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx.bind_class(Foo, bind_constructor=True)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx.eval_script(&quot;var f = new Foo(); f.hello();&quot;)
<br/>Hello, Javascript world!We can also get back objects from Javascript and use them: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; f = cx.eval_script(&quot;f;&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; f.hello()
<br/>Hello, Javascript world!LimitationsThe module currently has a number of features that still need to be implemented.  For instance, it&#39;s not yet possible to call a function defined in Javascript: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx.eval_script(&quot;function foo(x) { return x + 1; }; foo;&quot;)
<br/>{&#39;prototype&#39;: {}}Errors in Javascript code also don&#39;t produce particularly helpful tracebacks: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; cx.eval_script(&quot;3 + undefinedVariable&quot;)
<br/>Traceback (most recent call last):
<br/>...
<br/>JSError: can&#39;t evaluate Javascript scriptInstallationNote that at present, installation has only been tested on OS X and 64-bit Ubuntu Linux; support for Windows is forthcoming. </p>

<p>At present, you&#39;ll need a C compiler on your system to install this extension, as well as the Pyrex package. </p>

<p>Check out the Python-Spidermonkey module from the SVN repository. From the root of your checkout, run: python setup.py buildDon&#39;t worry about the compiler warnings.  Then, with appropriate permissions, run: 
<br/>python setup.py installTestingThe module has a test suite.  Just run: </p>

<p>python test.pyNote that one of the tests currently prints out a Javascript error message.  This isn&#39;t a test failure (though it is a bug). </p>

<p>AcknowledgementsThanks to Brendan Eich for help with several Spidermonkey issues (and for all his Mozilla work), and to Erwin on the freenode #c IRC channel for gdb tips.</p>
 summary : <p>Object Oriented Python Video4Linux 2 library.
<br/>Provides easy access to video, radio and vbi devices in python.</p>

Program parses XML feeds from zip file on disk or live from the web. At the API level, it parses observations into python dictionary format with the Weather.Station class.  title : The python-xbee Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Tools include a library for working with XBee API mode serial data and an XBee serial command shell for interacting with XBee radios. E.g.: </p>

<p>import serial
<br/>from xbee import xbee</p>

<p>serial = serial.Serial()
<br/>serial.port = &#39;/dev/tty.usbserial-A4001ib8&#39;
<br/>serial.open()</p>

<p>while 1:
<br/>	packet = xbee.find_packet(serial)
<br/>	if packet:
<br/>		xb = xbee(packet)
<br/>		print xbThe xbee object provides accessors for the radio&#39;s address, signal strength, analog and digital input values, etc. </p>

<p>The XBee API code is incomplete, missing support for valid checksums and an implementation for working with the Series 2 API. It is an incomplete port of Rob Faludi&#39;s XBee Processing library.</p>

 title : The pythontask Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Warning: this is WIPI wanted something like http://www.beckingham.net/task.html , but being a programmer wanted to do it my way ;), i.e. adding a few extra bits and removing some others, so I&#39;m doing it in a language that is faster for me to implement stuff in. </p>

<p>Aiming to have support for many kinds of miscellaneous details per task: taskname, tags, projects, start/finish date/time, requires, requiredby, priority, started, done, people, phones, emails, location, gpslocation, etc </p>

<p>usageadd a task: td.py a New task :proj1 :proj2 +tag1 +tag2 </p>

<p>list all tasks td.py ls </p>

<p>remove task by number (need to change into name or number or etc) td.py r 1 </p>

<p>Smart enough to pick out things and recombine when adding: </p>

<p>td.py a New task :proj1 :proj2 +tag1 +tag2 </p>

<p>gives the same result as: </p>

<p>td.py a +tag2 :proj1 New +tag1 :proj2 task </p>

<p>but not the following (note that the words that make up the task name are in a different order): </p>

<p>td.py a +tag2 :proj1 task +tag1 :proj2 New</p>

 title : The pyweblog Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The pywebman project will endeavor to provide hosting management via web interface, similar to Plesk, cPanel, and ISPConfig. </p>

<p>ISPConfig (http://www.ispconfig.org) is a truly wonderful system. However, the database structure used is needlessly complex and obfuscated. It&#39;s also written in PHP, and I don&#39;t much care for PHP. I know that PHP has it&#39;s place, but that place is not as the foundation of a large software project. </p>

<p>The tools used in this project shall include: </p>

<p>The python language (http://www.python.org) The Django framework (http://www.djangoproject.org) MySQL (http://www.mysql.com) PureFTP (http://www.pureftpd.org/project/pure-ftpd) MyDNS (http://mydns.bboy.net/) Apache (http://httpd.apache.org) Postfix (http://www.postfix.org) Courier (http://www.courier-mta.org) </p>

<p>All user authentication will be performed via MySQL. </p>

<p>Wherever possible, this system will NOT depend upon writing config files to disk. As much system config as possible will be handled via MySQL. </p>

<p>This system is being designed with server farms and automatic failover in mind. We will make use of MySQL&#39;s multi-master replication, and will make use of message-passing to notify servers when updates need to be processed. </p>

<p>Resources: </p>

<p>Courier MySQL authentication: http://www.courier-mta.org/authlib/README.authmysql.html Python: http://www.python.org Django: http://www.djangoproject.org Online Django book: http://www.djangobook.com/ </p>

<p>If you&#39;d like to be notified of project updates or become a developer on this project, send an e-mail to catdude@gmail.com.</p>

 title : The pyweek5-maze Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Our entry for Pyweek 5. The theme is twisted and our project hopes to score with our simple scheme of gameplay. </p>

<p>The player controls a marble and the challenge is to find the end of the maze. To make the game fun, challenging and to fit the theme of the competition, we have created an interesting control scheme. </p>

<p>By dragging on screen with the mouse, the player will be able to rotate the level around the marble. Gravity always acts upon the marble, down, relative to the screen. In this way the player can manuever the marble in all sorts of interesting ways. </p>

<p>To coincide with the traditional traps of the original Murmel-Labyrinths the marble in this game will be fragile. Fall too far a distance and you&#39;ll shatter forcing you to restart.</p>

 title : The qcrypto Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is the repository for the source code used in a series of quantum key distribution experiments at the National University of Singapore, from key generation in form time-stamped detector data to error correction and privacy amplification. </p>

<p>The code was designed to work with entanglement-based pair detection schemes, either implementing a BB84-type/BBM92 protocol, or an Ekert-91 protocol, which we (Centre for Quantum Technologies) used for our implementations (1,2) of quantum key ditribution systems. </p>

<p>The code is mostly ANSI C, typically compiled with gcc (4.2 or 4.3, but earlier versions also work). We have run the suite mostly on Linux machines running various distros, haven&#39;t tested out anything else because our USB hardware has at the moment only a linux driver. </p>

<p>Discussions on implementation details/problems/leaks are welcome, and should ultimately lead to an openly available implementation of a QKD scheme which hopefully has less open security problems than implementations using proprietary code. We believe that one of the main attack scheme for a quantum key distribution system lies in the software and communication implementation, and would encourage people to try to break it. </p>

<p>We eventually will open hardware specs and detailled designs as well, but please bear with us since this publicization is sort of a side project. Our internal documentation is at the moment somewhat chaotic. But if you have any specific questions, do not hesitate to get in touch with us directly. </p>

<p>In an initial phase, have deposited code which has been running on several linux systems in our labs, and definitions of file formats and hardware. </p>

<p>The currently recommended way of installing it is to draw the complete source tree from the source repository and compile the different elements following the readme instructions. The code as used in (1) and for a demo at the 24C3 conference is currently available as a tarball in the download area here as qcrypto_20071229.tgz. Consolidation for our internal code branches is in progress; the inclusion of all the gui and other components for an implementation of an Ekert91 protocol  is not yet complete. </p>

<p>If you are interested in joining the project, please send an email to the project owner at gmail.com. </p>

<p>NewsWe currently have a visitor, Vadim Makarov from Norway in our group who had an excllent idea how to break the QKD system. It looks like we are a bit in trouble with his attack, and we may get completely compromised. We will probably show up at DEFCON 17 with this scheme, and the hacking hardware if we manage to get together enough manpower. We&#39;ll join the quantum lounge there organized by the guys from NIST. </p>

<p>We may need some help to get the key out of the &#39;classical&#39; communication and the outcome of Vadim&#39;s physical attack hardware - if you are interested, contact us one way or another, we&#39;d appreciate some help. </p>

<p>ReferencesOur published work can be found under </p>

<p>(1) I. Marckic, A. Lamas-Linares, and C. Kurtsiefer, Appl. Phys. Lett. 89, 101122 (2006), earlier version at arXiv:quant-ph/0606072v2. </p>

<p>(2) Alexander Ling, Matthew P. Peloso, Ivan Marcikic, Valerio Scarani, Antia Lamas-Linares, Christian Kurtsiefer: Experimental quantum key distribution based on a Bell test, Phys. Rev. A. 78, 020301 (R) (2008) http://arxiv.org/abs/0805.3629. </p>

<p>(3) Matthew P. Peloso, Ilja Gerhardt, Caleb Ho, A. Lamas-Linares, C. Kurtsiefer: Daylight operation of a free space, entanglement-based quantum key distribution system.  New Journal of Physics *11*, 045007 (2009). </p>

<p>(4) Caleb Ho, A. Lamas-Linares, and C. Kurtsiefer: Clock synchronization by remote detection of correlated photon pairs.  New Journal of Physics 11, 045011 (2009). </p>

<p>A notoriously outdated web page of the QKD activities in the SG group can be found under http://www.qolah.org/research/crypto/crypto.html</p>

 title : The qfinance Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Qi Actionscript 2.0 Framework</p>
 title : The qi-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>1. What is Qi? </p>

<p>A language implemented in Common Lisp that generates efficient type secure Lisp programs which you can run on any machine. </p>

<p>2. What advantages does writing in Qi have over writing in Lisp? </p>

<p>Quite a few. </p>

<p> Qi uses pattern-matching instead of forcing you to write in CARs and CDRs. Typically Qi programs have 40% of the non-whitespace characters that Lisp programs have. 2. Qi has optional static type checking. You don&#39;t have to pray your program will not crash with a type error in a real application. 
<br/>3. Qi is lambda-calculus consistent. It makes Common Lisp understand things like partial applications. 
<br/>3. If I choose Qi, do I have to give up Lisp? </p>

<p>Absolutely not. In fact you can mix Qi and Lisp functions into one file and load them together. You can use Lisp functions within Qi code with no problems. You can even add to the type discipline of Qi to tell it about the types of functions that you have written in Lisp and it will accept your information. </p>

<p>4. What advantages does writing in Qi have over writing in ML or Haskell? </p>

<p> Qi runs on top of Lisp, which means that Qi inherits all the features of Lisp that ML and Haskell do not have; (think macros, EVAL, hash-tables, property-lists, metaprogramming ....) 2. Static typing is optional in Qi. You do not have to buy into it if you are dealing with code that is resistant to type checking. Or you can choose to check only that code you are interested in. 
<br/>3. The type discipline of Qi is based on sequent notation which is a much more powerful and flexible tool for defining types than that used in ML or Haskell. To find out why click here.</p>

<p>Sorry for the inconveniences.</p>
 summary : <p>QPlib plot libraryQPlib is an open-source 2D plotting library for C++ applications, in particular those which make use of Qt. QPlib is designed to be very easy to use. It makes use of the Trolltech Qt class library, and so can be used on Linux, Unix, Mac OS X, and MS Windows. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The philosophy behind QPlib: </p>

<p>it should be very easy to use, plots should look &quot;nice&quot;, it should be possible to make plots from the command line (including on Linux/Unix with no X11). </p>

<p>Current plots available include: </p>

<p>line plots, scatter plots, semi-log and log-log plots, error bars, candlesticks, filled curves, bar charts, 1D histograms, 2D histograms, spectrograms, pie charts. </p>

<p>Other features: </p>

<p>5 line styles, 16 symbol types, automatic major and minor ticks or user-defined, custom tick labels, major and minor grids, can have a dependent or independent second y-axis, horizontal and vertical lines can be drawn at user-defined positions, horizontal and vertical transparent shaded regions can be drawn at user-defined positions to highlight regions of interest. </p>

<p>Plots can be saved in a variety of file formats including PNG, PDF and SVG. Plots are also available as QImages, which enables them to be used within GUI applications. (QPlib however is not designed to provide interactive plotting widgets). </p>

<p>Many example codes are included demonstrating how to use all the main features of QPlib. </p>

<p>QPlib is still in a very early stage of development. </p>

<p>Installation notesInstallation notes can be found here. </p>

<p>Example plotsSome example plots can be seen here. These are taken from the included examples.</p>

 title : The qrails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>qRails is a Ruby on Rails plugin for the Qooxdoo javascript framework. qRails allows you to create rich internet applications easily than ever before.</p>
 summary : <p>QRCode for Ruby on RailsA plugin for Ruby on Rails to generate QRCode (QRコード). </p>

<p>AboutThis plugin use javascript to generate QRCode. The original javascript program is  developed by Kazuhiko Arase. (http://www.d-project.com/qrcode/index.html) </p>

<p>If you want to generate image directly from rails, check my another Rails QRCode Generator (its git repository) </p>

<p>UsageIn your rails project, install the plugin by following command:    ./script/plugin install http://qrcode-rails.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/plugins/qrcodeAdd javascript include tag in HTML header:     Add following funtion to where you want to generate QRCode.    - Add following funtion to where you want to generate QRCode. 
<br/>The first parameter is URL The second optional parameter is pixel size. The third optional parameter is QR Code type number, 1-10. Higher the type number, more data can be stored (max 976-2192 bits, depends on error correction level). Default 4. (For the relationship about adata size and type number, please refer to http://www.denso-wave.com/qrcode/vertable1-e.html) The 4th optional parameter is ID of the generated div ExampleYou can find source of an example project here: http://qrcode-rails.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/examples </p>

<p>I have package the sample program into a WAR, deploy it into any Web Container (e.g. Tomcat, Jetty, Glassfish ...etc) to see how it works!  </p>

<p>Sample CodeSample Screen </p>

<p>LicenseReleased under the MIT license. </p>

<p>AuthorFrancis Chong - siuying at reality dot hk</p>

 title : The quake3-brainworks Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Brainworks is a Quake 3 mod designed to give Quake 3 Arena bots working brains.  It is a complete rewrite of all the Artificial Intelligence used by the bots.  Brainworks includes: </p>

<p>Sound and visual awareness system Randomized dodging in battles Avoidance of incoming missiles Strafejumping Improved enemy aiming Goal and score-based selection of item pickups Timing of item respawns Dynamic weapon selection (based on weapon accuracy) Redesigned internal goal selection Redesigned internal aim selection Redesigned Teamplay logic Rewritten chat code Redesigned internal logic infrastructure The goal of Brainworks is to make Quake 3 Arena bots as human-like as possible.  With that in mind, the following human equivalents were set as the &quot;goal for realism&quot; for each bot. </p>

<p>Skill 1: Someone who has played Q3A for less than 2 weeks Skill 2: Someone who has played Q3A for less than 3 months Skill 3: Average player on a public server Skill 4: The best player on a public server Skill 5: A clan player who plays in professional tournaments Obviously it&#39;s harder to make realistic skill 5 bots than skill 1 bots, but we&#39;ve done everything we can in a reasonable amount of time to reach these five goals for realistic bots. </p>

<p>NOTE: The parts of code still derived from the original Quake 3 code (for example, function interfaces between the AI code and the main server) are covered under the original software license ID Software included with the source code release.  Parts that are not based on the original code are covered by the select license for this project.</p>

 title : The quantumfractals Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AbstractEvent Enhanced Quantum (EEQT) allows for simulation of an individual quantum system on which a simultaneous measurement of several noncommuting observables is being performed. Such a coupling of a quantum system to the measuring devices causes chaotic quantum jumps and fractal-like pattern generation (via nonlinear IFS) on the manifold of quantum states (usually complex projective plane). The simplest example is a 2-dimensional comlex Hilbert space, which leads to fractals on the two-sphere. A short introduction into the subject will be given. It will be then shown that EEQT algorithm works also with indefinite metric, and that here are no negative probabilities. Symmetric configurations of detectors will be shown to generate quantum fractals on the Poincare disk. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The AlgorithmIn applications the vectors  </p>

<p>   n[i], i= 1, 2, ..., Ncan be arbitrary except that they are of unit length, that is they all lie on the surface of the sphere of unit radius, and they add to zero vector:  </p>

<p>   n[1] + n[2] + ... + n[N] = 0- so they are balance each other in such a way that their common center of gravity is at the center of the sphere. </p>

<p>The algorithm describes a sequence of maps of the sphere. These maps are applied, sequentially, to a randomly chosen starting point. Thus what we get is a point on the sphere jumping in a somewhat chaotic way on the surface of the sphere. After 100 000 jumps or so a pattern appear. This pattern is independent of the starting point, as it is usual in chaotic dynamics with an attractor. What we see is an approximation of the attractor set. For instance, for a particular value of the fuzziness parameter alpha = 0.65, and the dodecahedron, we get the following images for 10 000,100 000, 1000 000 and 10 000 000 respectively. The more jumps we generate, the more details of the attractor set shows up. The 100 000 000 dots image shows even more details: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>There are two separate problems when creating these fractal images, namely that of generating data, and of rendering the generated date into an image.  Let us first discuss the data generating algorithm. This problem itself can be separated into two: a) generating the sequence of points on the sphere, and b) storing these data into an array. Storing the coordinates of all generated points is not a good idea, as it takes lot of space. For instance, if we use 2 bytes for a floating point number, then the picture on the left would require storing space of 600 MB of RAM (storing the data on the disk would essentially slow down the generation process). Therefore we create a double array dj of integers by dividing the unit square into JxJ &quot;pixels&quot;, initialize it to 0 (or to 1), and with each generated point r = (x, y, z) on the unit sphere we increase dj by 1 if the (x, y) coordinates of the point are within (i, j) pixel. So, for instance, the image on the left was created using 400x400 array, and the highest occupation &quot;pixel&quot; got 8029 &quot;hits&quot;. (In fact, we are using two arrays: one for z negative, and one for z positive. So the pictures here are obtained by &quot;looking at the sphere from above&quot; - thus using only z-positive data.). </p>

<p>Given a point r the algorithm first computes probabilities p(i, r) of sum 1:  </p>

<p>   p(1, r) + p(2, r) + ... + p(N, r) = 1 with which we select the map that is to be applied to r. The formula, explained in more details in the paper, reads: </p>

<p>   p(i,r) = (1 + alpha2 + 2 alpha n[i].r )/( N( 1 + alpha2 ))where n[i ].r stands fro the scalar product of n[i ] and r, that is, in our case, for the cosine of the angle between the vectors n[i ] and r, and alpha is the &quot;fuzzy&quot; parameter 0 &lt; a &lt; 1 . Once, for a given current point r, the probability distribution p(i) = p(i, r) is computed, a vertex n[i ] is selected accordingly. Here we follow the standard procedure of selecting a case according to the given probability distribution. In Java code: </p>

<p>// Get random number
<br/>double r=Math.random();</p>

<p>// Check which detector that clicked
<br/>double ptmp = 0;
<br/>double[] detector = null;</p>

<p>for (int i = 0; i &lt; p.length; i++)
<br/>{
<br/>   ptmp += p[i];
<br/>   if (r  (IFS). </p>

<p>Rendering of the imageOnce the data are collected in a pixel array dj, they need to be converted into a picture, either using grayscale or some coloring scheme. For instance one can find the maximum m = max (dj) divide it into 256 equal intervals, and aasign a grayscale value between 0 and 1 to an (i, j) pixel according to the value of dj/m. In fractal images it is neccessary to make some transformation of the array values before, otherwise details of the pattern are lost. For rendering of the greyscale pictures above we have used  </p>

<p>   log10(log10(d[i, j] + 1) + 1) transformation.</p>
 title : The quarzo Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Quarzo it&#39;s a Ruby on Rails based Learning Management System</p>
 title : The qubit-toolkit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is Qubit?Qubit is a generic information management toolkit that can be used by organizations and projects to make community-specific, web-based cataloging applications. Qubit provides a range of common web application features as well as support for professional metadata standards. </p>

<p>Qubit is primarily intended for use in archives and libraries that manage and host web based collections of information resources. Qubit supports multilingual and multi repository collections. </p>

<p>What can I use it for?Artefactual Systems has developed Qubit to deliver and manage the ICA-AtoM and Digital Collection Builder applications. If one of those applications doesn&#39;t meet your needs, you can use the Qubit toolkit to develop, customize, theme and brand your own web-based collections management application.  </p>

<p>Also, if you want to contribute patches or develop new features for ICA-AtoM or DCB, then checkout a copy of the Qubit trunk to make your code contributions. These are merged to the ICA-AtoM and DCB stable branches twice a year as part of the project&#39;s time-based release schedule. </p>

<p>ArchitectureQubit is developed using an open architecture that takes advantage of emerging web based tools and practices. Qubit is built using the symfony PHP 5 framework and a number of other open-source libraries. See the system architecture wiki page for more information about technical architecture and software requirements. </p>

<p>Who is involved?Qubit is the collaborative effort of related but separate open-source software projects that have decided to work together to leverage time, knowledge and resources. Each of these projects is using and contributing to Qubit as the underlying toolkit to build their own applications. Please visit the respective project websites for more information, </p>

<p>ICA-AtoM Digital Collection Builder (DCB) A number of different people have contributed time and skills to the Qubit project. They are listed on the contributors wiki page. </p>

<p>The day-to-day technical and project management for the Qubit project is provided by Artefactual Systems </p>

<p>More?Online documentation is available in the project wiki hosted at qubit-toolkit.org.</p>

 title : The quicklook Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is it?Quick Look is a package to collect system statistics and output pretty graphics and (X)HTML pages. It allows system administrators to have a quick look on the status of their systems, without going for a more advanced (and heavier) solution. </p>

<p>Quick Look currently shows... </p>

<p>CPU and memory usage Load average and process spawning rates I/O operations Network traffic rates Tracked network connections A static demo is available at http://www.carlos-rodrigues.com/projects/quicklook/demo/. </p>

<p>What does it need to run?Python 2.3 or newer Cheetah 0.9.16 or newer Linux 2.4.27 or newer, 2.6.8 or newer rrdtool 1.0.49 or newer python-rrd 0.2.1 or newer Older versions of any of these packages may work, but haven&#39;t been tested. Newer versions should also work, and you should use them if possible. If you notice any problems, please file a bug report and I&#39;ll try to fix them. </p>

<p>InstallationTo install Quick Look into /opt/quicklook, just run the following commands: </p>

<p>make DESTDIR=/opt/quicklook install cp extras/quicklook.cron /etc/cron.d/stats By default, data files are stored in /var/opt/quicklook and webpages are generated into the /var/www/quicklook directory. If you wish to make changes to the output directories, or you chose a different installation directory, edit the quicklook.cron file before copying it. </p>

<p>Quick Look will now collect data and generate webpages every five minutes. No other steps are needed, but you can always run stats.py without parameters to check out the options available. </p>

<p>Upgrade from 1.0.xWhen using Quick Look 1.0.x, a reboot could cause some of the graphs to have a huge spike. To prevent this from happening, the format for some of the data files (*.rrd) had to be changed. </p>

<p>Newer versions of Quick Look cannot read these files, and they have to be converted if you wish to keep the data contained in them. To do this, you can use the extras/convert.sh script. </p>

<p>For example, if you are storing data files in /var/opt/quicklook (default), they can be converted with the following command: </p>

<p>convert.sh /var/opt/quicklook 
<br/>Backup this directory first, just in case. </p>

<p>Releases</p>

<p>Date  Version  Changes   2008-04-12  1.1  Fixed problem with occasional huge spikes in graphs after rebooting, but existing data files must be converted (see: Upgrade from 1.0.x).   2007-12-01  1.0.2  Fixed problems with disk devices with slashes in their names (e.g. HP SmartArray RAID volumes).   2006-12-17  1.0.1  Fixed problems with dhttpd. Automatic refresh for statistics pages. New color scheme for graphs.   2006-09-02  1.0a  Fixed problem with rrdtool 1.2.x.   2006-09-01  1.0  Initial public release.</p>

<p>http://tec.toi-planning.net/mt/quickrebuild/ </p>

 title : The quipt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What&#39;s qUIpt?qUIpt is a small library that is capable of caching Javascript files inside the users browser - even if SSL is active. qUIpt helps the site owner by reducing  traffic costs and the user with faster page loading. Developers by the way might want to check https://groups.google.com/group/quipt </p>

<p>How does it work?Quite simple  It checks for the contents of window.name while your page is being loaded. If there&#39;s nothing inside the window.name cache the JS files defined by you are fetched via XHR  The same happens if the users enters your site for the first time of his current browser session or if document.referrer is off-domain or empty After that the contents of window.name are being evaluated If the user requests the next page on your domain the JS files are directly taken from window.name - no more requests necessary Is this secure?Yep - if the user enters your site the first time the JS files are requested - no matter what&#39;s already inside window.name An attacker can&#39;t set window.name from other tabs the user might surf on parallely Click for happinessSources Example usage Feedback is always appreciated - especially in this very early stage of the project.</p>

 summary : <p>R-Bench models how well various shapes of reflectors concentrate light from different angles.   </p>

<p>In particular this software is designed to analyze the performance of different solar trough designs for use in renewable energy production.  </p>

<p>Intended scope: </p>

<p> Single reflector  Single light source (directional or point-source)  One optional &#39;receiver&#39; or &#39;light sink&#39; (the pipe or panel in a solar application- r-bench will provide performance characteristics of the receiver for a given angle or averaged over a range of angles) </p>

<p>Current Features: </p>

<p> handles angles between 5 and 175 degrees  supports catenary, parabola and semicircle reflector shapes  adjustable reflector attributes (function min/max, alpha or &#39;steepness&#39;)  recursively bounces light rays until they no longer intersect reflector  both circle and line shaped &#39;light sinks&#39; </p>

<p>Current version is programmed using Qt4. The Windows version 0.9 is in the downloads section. </p>

<p>R-Bench 0.9 Screenshot </p>

<p>R-Bench 0.75 Screenshot </p>

<p>Earlier versions programmed using Java via Processing.  R-Bench v0.6 Processing applet here.</p>

 title : The radia-source Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The operation of radio stations is deﬁned by three main factors: content, production environment, and resources. The content of radio station programming schedules is mostly composed of automated music playlists or programs produced by their authors. Also, content contributions may come from a controlled environment or from different sources. Finally, the availability of human and ﬁnancial resources also have a great impact on their operation.  </p>

<p>Currently, there is no adequate application support for radio stations focused on author programming, that receive content from different sources and have low human and ﬁnancial resources. Radia Source presents a solution for radio stations with the aforementioned characteristics. It is based on an analysis of a station of this type, as well as requirements elicited from several radio stations with similar characteristics.  </p>

<p>The system is based on the Representational State Transfer (REST) architectural style. It supports the main processes associated with the broadcast in such stations, including the programming schedule deﬁnition, content contribution by authors and its usage for audio playback.</p>

 title : The radiant-configuration-extension Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Radiant Configuration ExtensionThe configuration extensions allows you to configure Radiant through  the Radiant interface. There isn&#39;t a configuration interface available in the current Radiant version, which isn&#39;t much of a problem, because the configuration could easily be altered through the console. </p>

<p>Unfortunately, some of my extensions allow my end-users to change some configurations. Therefore I created this configuration interface. </p>

<p>How to useJust checkout from SVN in the vendor/extensions folder of your Radiant  installation. </p>

<p>When enabled, this extension will add &#39;Configuration&#39; tab to your Radiant. This tab and the underlying page will only be visible for Administrators. The underlying page displays all configuration keys and their values. The values can easily be altered by the form.</p>

 title : The radiant-hikifilter Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Allows you to compose page parts or snippets in Radiant using the HikiDoc text filter. </p>

<p>To install: </p>

 summary : <p>Rails Support ExtensionExtending Radiant via the standard Rails action pack is a bit painful  right now cause it&#39;s not easy to re-use the Radiant Layouts. </p>

<p>This Radiant Extension allows you to create Radiant Extensions that can  use the normal Rail action pack to create rich database driven application  but which are still tightly integrated via the Radiant layout system. </p>

<p>Quick UsageOnce this extension is installed, update your controllers so that  they extended SiteController.  This extension adds a radiant_render method to the SiteController which is identical to the standard Rails render method except that it uses Radiant to layout the  view. </p>

<p>For example, app/controllers/sample_controller.rb: </p>

<p>class SampleController &lt; SiteController
<br/>  def index    
<br/>    radiant_render :layout=&gt;&quot;path/to/page&quot;
<br/>  end    
<br/>endThe above will look up the Radiant page that maps to URL  &quot;path/to/page&quot; and use that as the template for rendering the  content of the rendered rhtml view.  Instead of using the page&#39;s body part, the result of rendering the rhtml view will be used as the body. </p>

<p>If layout is not specified, it uses the layout of the root page. </p>

<p>This extension also adds a helper to include snippets from Radiant </p>

<p>For example, app/views/sample_controller/index.rhtml: </p>

<p>How to include a snippet:
<br/>Detailed ExampleFor those folks having problems getting started with this extension, I recommend you download and install the following extension which show you how to use the rails_support: http://radiant-rails-support.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/extensions/rails_support_example </p>

<p>These are the steps that were taken to build that example: </p>

<p>1. First generate the extension and example controler </p>

<p>C:\radiant&gt;ruby script\generate extension rails_support_example
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/app/controllers
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/app/helpers
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/app/models
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/app/views
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/db/migrate
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/lib/tasks
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/test/fixtures
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/test/functional
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/test/unit
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/README
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/Rakefile
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/rails_support_example_extension.rb
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/lib/tasks/rails_support_example_extension_tasks.rake
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/test/test_helper.rb
<br/>      create  vendor/extensions/rails_support_example/test/functional/rails_support_example_extension_test.rb</p>

<p>C:\radiant&gt;ruby script\generate extension_controler rails_support_example example
<br/>      exists  app/controllers/
<br/>      exists  app/helpers/
<br/>      create  app/views/example
<br/>      exists  test/functional/
<br/>      create  app/controllers/example_controller.rb
<br/>      create  test/functional/example_controller_test.rb
<br/>      create  app/helpers/example_helper.rb</p>

<p>C:\radiant&gt;2. Add a route in the rails_support_example.rb to your example controller: </p>

<p>  define_routes do |map|
<br/>     map.connect &#39;example/:action/:id&#39;, :controller =&gt; &#39;example&#39;
<br/>  end3. Update your controller so that it extends SiteController </p>

<p>4. Add the index action to the example controller </p>

<p>  def index
<br/>    radiant_render 
<br/>  end5. Add a the app\views\example\index.rhtml view file: </p>

<p>  Hi this file is &quot;&quot;</p>

<p>  Please define a snippet called &quot;welcome&quot;, and it will be rendered after this:</p>

<p>   </p>

<p>6. Start up radiant and browse the http://localhost:3000/example</p>
 title : The radiant-rails-support Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Tinymce FilterThis extension provides a TinyMCE filter for the Radiant CMS. It allows you to edit the content of your pages in the TinyMCE editor. </p>

<p>Based on the plugin by Brandalism. </p>

<p>InstallationPut the javascript/extensions/tinymce folder in the public folder of your Radiant installation: svn checkout http://radiant-tinymce-extension.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/javascripts/extensions/tinymce public/javascript/extensions/tiny_mceCopy the tinymce_filter folder to your vendor/extensions folder svn checkout http://radiant-tinymce-extension.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/tinymce_filter vendor/extensions/tinymce_filterBy default, TinyMCE will look for a /stylesheets/content.css file to use in the editor. If you want to add your own styling to the editor, you can create this file. Radiant code will automatically get a class name. Add the following CSS to your content.css file: .mceItemRadiantCode { 
<br />  background: url(&#39;../javascripts/extensions/tiny_mce/plugins/codeprotect/images/radiant-code.png&#39;) no-repeat; 
<br />  height: 18px;
<br />  border: none;
<br />}SettingsIf you want to change the settings of the editor, you can do this by editing the &#39;tiny_mce_settings.js&#39; file. The &#39;codeprotect&#39; plugin is used to protect the Radiant tags from being edited within the editor. </p>

<p>- Edwin Vlieg</p>
