 title : The ragona-as3utils Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ragona-as3utils (com.ragona.utils) is a growing set of tools for use in Flash projects. At this early stage it is only maintained for: </p>

<p>• Actionscript 3.0, Flash 9+. </p>

<p>The following classes are currently included: </p>

<p>Sender(com.ragona.utils.sender.Sender.as): </p>

<p>Sender is a simple set of classes that I use to replace &#39;trace&#39; functionality. The issue with trace is that it only works within the Flash IDE, and once your site is live it&#39;s difficult to debug certain issues. This is a simple set of classes used for for live project debugging. By uploading reciever.swf and changing from trace to sendMessage() you can view your trace output on any computer, within a web browser. In the future I will extend Reciever to include search functionality, file exporting, and other useful features that Trace lacks. This is an early implementation, but even now I refuse to work without it during development, it&#39;s just that useful, especially for projects that involve server-side or JavaScript interaction, and must be run within a browser - where tracing isn&#39;t an option without unreliable browser extensions.   </p>

<p>CoreXML (com.ragona.utils.coreXML.CoreXML.as): </p>

<p>A really simple XML class for easy loading in AS3. It dispatches an &#39;xmlLoaded&#39; event that can be listened for in parent classes, and is generally saves me from writing the same XML code over an over. It was specifically intended to be extended, and works well with subclasses. </p>

<p>XMLPathfinder (com.ragona.utils.coreXML.XMLPathfinder.as): </p>

<p>This is a class I created for use with Flash deeplinking solutions, SWFAddress for example. I wanted a way to take URL string, &quot;/portfolio/web/2041/&quot; for example, and parse through an XML document based on a unique attribute, named &#39;local&#39;. It returns an XML typed object, which in my own projects I use to load data based on user URL input. It can be integrated into any XML document by adding @local attributes to the XML nodes that you need to navigate through, as long the attribute is unique for each level.  </p>

<p>This project is really just for personal use, but if it is useful for anyone you&#39;re welcome to pick it apart and take what you can.</p>
 title : The raid-notification Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>I play WoW, and when I raid, I have to sign up on a forum posting. This script sends emails whenever there is a new posting in the &quot;Line-Ups and Sign-Ups&quot; forum. </p>

<p>From the forumHey guys. I&#39;m not entirely sure whether or not any of you are nerds like me, but if you&#39;re technically inclined, I figured I&#39;d post a little script I just whipped up. </p>

<p>What it does is spit out all of the currently available line-ups for your raid group, and sends you a notification via email when it sees a new line-up posted. </p>

<p>As a disclaimer, I should mention that I have done no testing as to whether or not the script will work for you. In fact, unless you run Mac OS X or some flavor of Linux, you should probably abandon all hope of using this. I can&#39;t support Windows, sorry!  </p>

<p>To Install:Copy/paste the code to a text file and save it (I recommend something like &quot;equil.rb&quot;). Edit the first couple variables to suit your needs. They begin with dollar signs. If you don&#39;t want it to email you, delete the $toList lines. Open a terminal and run ruby /the/location/you/saved/it The program should return however many current line-ups are out. If you set up the email correctly, you will get an email for each. Notes:If you use a Mac, you&#39;ll have to run sudo postfix start for the mail functionality to work. It will prompt you for your password. If you use Linux, a mail application is likely running already. </p>

<p>Feel free to ask any questions or make any modifications.</p>

 summary : <p>Authorization pluginThis plugin provides a flexible way to add authorization to Rails. </p>

<p>The authorization process decides whether a user is allowed access to some feature.  It is distinct from the authentication process, which tries to confirm a user is authentic, not an imposter. There are many authentication systems available for Rails, e.g., acts_as_authenticated and LoginEngine. This authorization system will play nicely with them as long as some simple requirements are met.   </p>

<p>IMPORTANT NOTE : The SVN repository for this project on this site has been hidden.  The SVN repo will no longer be updated as of 10/5/2008.  You are encouraged to take a look instead at the README and our source code repository on GitHub for all code, including plugin installation.  Links to both can be found below: </p>

<p>See the README.rdoc at the git repository for examples and documentation. </p>

<p>The git repository is here.</p>

 title : The rails-erb-trim-mode Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The rails-fast-sessions Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Fast SessionsFastSessions is a sessions class for ActiveRecord sessions store created to work fast (really fast). It uses some techniques which are not so widely known in developers&#39; community and only when they cause huge problems, performance consultants are trying to help with them. </p>

<p>The ProblemOriginal ActiveRecord sessions store is slow. It is fine for some low traffic blogs, but it is too slow to use it on some big/large/huge sites. First of all, it is slow because ActiveRecord is slow. It is powerful ORM framework, but it is overkill for such simple task as a sessions management. </p>

<p>There are other possible solutions like cookie session store (session size is limited, no sensible data in sessions), memcached (too much RAM when you have many sessions + no persistence). </p>

<p>That is why people created SqlSession store. It works with mysql directly with database APIs and works much faster than original AR session store. But it is still slow because: </p>

<p>it creates/updates session on each hit - even dumb bots crawling your sites create thousands of thousands of useless records in your sessions table, 99% of hits do not require any session updates! it uses 32-char string as a key for sessions records - all databases work with string keys MUCH slower that with integers keys, so it would be much better to use integers, but we have so long session ids and all session stores use these session ids as a key. it uses auto_increment primary key, which causes table-level locks in InnoDB for all MySQL versions prior to 5.1.21. These table-level locks with unnecessary inserts cause really weird problems for large sites. The SolutionFastSessions plugin was born as a hack created for Scribd.com (large RoR-based web project), which was suffering from InnoDB auto-increment table-level locks on sessions table.  </p>

<p>So, first of all, we removed id field from the table. Next step was to make lookups faster and we&#39;ve used a following technique: instead of using (session_id) as a lookup key, we started using (CRC32(session_id), session_id) - two-columns key which really helps MySQL to find sessions faster because key cardinality is higher (so, mysql is able to find a record earlier w/o checking a lots of index rows). We&#39;ve benchmarked this approach and it shows 10-15% performance gain on large sessions tables. </p>

<p>And last, but most powerful change we&#39;ve tried to make was to not create database records for empty sessions and to not save sessions data back to database if this data has not been changed during current request processing. With this change we basically reduce inserts number by 50-90% (depends 0n application). </p>

<p>All of these changes were implemented and you can use them automatically after a simple plugin installation. </p>

<p>Controversial DecisionsMany plugin users would never think about one problem we&#39;ve introduced when removed that auto-increment primary key, so I&#39;d like to describe it here. The problem is following. </p>

<p>InnoDB groups all data in tables by primary key. This means that when we create auto-increment primary key and insert records to a table, our sessions records are grouped together and saved sequentially on the disk. But if we&#39;ll make pretty random value (like crc32 of a random session id) a primary key, then every session record will be inserted in its own place and it will generate some random I/O which is not so good for I/O bound servers. </p>

<p>So, we decided to let the user choose what primary key to use in his deployment of our plugin, so if you&#39;re going to use this module with MySQL 5.1.22+, then you&#39;dlike to set  </p>

<p>  CGI::Session::ActiveRecordStore::FastSessions.use_auto_increment = truebecause it will provide you with consecutive data inserts in InnoDB. Another cases when you&#39;d like to use it is when your MySQL server is I/O bound now and you do not want to add random I/O because of randomized primary key. </p>

<p>Working With Old AR Sessions TableIf you do not like to loose old sessions created with default AR sessions plugin, you could set  </p>

<p>  CGI::Session::ActiveRecordStore::FastSessions.fallback_to_old_table = trueand then all session reads will fall back to old sessions table if some session_id was not found in default fast sessions table. Old sessions table name could be set using  </p>

<p>  CGI::Session::ActiveRecordStore::FastSessions.old_table_name variable. </p>

<p>This options make sessions slower so I&#39;d recommend to use it during transition to new sessions table only. In this case you&#39;ll save your new sessions to the new table and will be able to drop old sessions table when your session expiration time will be over (we use 2 month period so in 2 months we&#39;ll be able to drop this old table and turn this option off).  </p>

<p>InstallationThis plugin installation is pretty simple and described in a few steps below: </p>

<p>1) Install this plugin sources in your vendor/plugins directory (it could be ./script/plugin install, or piston import command - it is up to you) from our SVN reposipory. For example: </p>

<p>$  piston import http://rails-fast-sessions.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ vendor/plugins/fast_sessions2) Enable ActiveRecord session store in your config/environment.rb file: </p>

<p>  Rails::Initializer.run do |config|
<br/>    ......
<br/>    config.action_controller.session_store = :active_record_store
<br/>    ......
<br/>  end3) Create migration for your new sessions table: </p>

<p> $ ./script/generate fast_session_migration AddFastSessions4) Open your newly created migration and change table_name and use_auto_increment parameters of the plugin (if you want to). </p>

<p>5) Run your migration: </p>

<p>$  rake db:migrate6) Start your application and try to perform some actions which would definitely save some data to your session. Then check your fast_sessions table (if you did not renamed it) for a records. </p>

<p>DownloadingMost recent version if this plugin could be found on the project&#39;s site:  </p>

<p>  http://code.google.com/p/rails-fast-sessions/or in SVN repository: </p>

<p>  http://rails-fast-sessions.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/AuthorThis plugin has been created by Alexey Kovyrin. Development is sponsored by  Scribd.com.</p>
 summary : <p>A search engine of the rails edge code., </p>
 title : The rails-grep Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The rails-has-file Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rails Plugin: has_file v0.1   </p>

<p>Website:    http://code.google.com/p/rails-has-file                    Author:     John Wulff                             Copyright:  Copyright (c) 2007 John Wulff          License:    MIT   </p>

<p>SETUP  class Node &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
<br/>    has_file :donkey
<br/>  endBEHAVIOUR  &gt;&gt; n = Node.new
<br/>    =&gt; #nil}, @new_record=true&gt;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.donkey = &#39;secret donkey message&#39;
<br/>    =&gt; &#39;secret donkey message&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.donkey_file_path
<br/>    =&gt; &#39;/tmp/node-20123394-donkey&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.donkey
<br/>    =&gt; &#39;secret donkey message&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.save!
<br/>    =&gt; true
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.donkey_file_path
<br/>    =&gt; &#39;/Users/jwulff/Development/rails/resources/node-4-donkey&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.donkey
<br/>    =&gt; &#39;secret donkey message&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; n.destroy
<br/>    =&gt; #&#39;2007-05-08 15:07:47&#39;}&gt;
<br/>  &gt;&gt; File.exists? &#39;/Users/jwulff/Development/rails/resources/node-4-donkey&#39;
<br/>    =&gt; false</p>

 title : The rails-jumpstart Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rails Jumpstart was created because I was tired of setting up my Rails applications with plugins that  I normally used. </p>

<p>I keep a list of my most commonly used plugins or favorites in a text file and would have to copy and paste the url to the repository for each one into my shell when I setup a new project.  </p>

 title : The rails-kb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>&#39;If you need to go global, a Localist may help!&#39; :-) </p>

<p>Localist helps in multilanguage/globalized rails applications. It automatically finds the best match between the locales accepted by your users and the locales supported by your application (per rules defined in RFC2616, section 14.4: HTTP/1.1 - Header Field Definitions - Accept-Language) and maintain it in successive requests. It also offers a nice country-flag menu to allow the users to manually switch to another locale. </p>

<p>Featuresonly 3-5 lines of code required to use it finds, sets and maintains the best locale match in successive requests smart fallback when no match is possible RFC2616 compilant provides a nice flag menu with the active locale indicator allows the user to manually switch the locale includes the flag icons of all the ISO3166-1 alpha-2 countries fully configurable (by variables)  fully customizable (by overriding methods and templates) RequirementsDownload the meta-tools lib form here http://ruby.4pro.net/meta-tools/download/ and install it: </p>

<p> % [sudo] gem install meta-tool-1.0.gem  </p>

<p>Repositoryhttp://rails-localist.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ 
<br/>Quick Startin app/controllers/application.rb: </p>

<p>  before_filter :localistin config/environment.rb: </p>

<p>  Localist.supported_locales = %w[ en-US it-IT es-ES fr-FR ..... ]
<br/>  Localist.callback = lambda{ |client_locale| do_something_with( client_locale ) }in the head container of your layout: </p>

<p>  &#39;all&#39; %&gt;somewhere in the body container of your layout or template: </p>

<p>    Author and CopyrightCopyright (c) 2007 by Domizio Demichelis</p>
 title : The rails-localist Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The rails-mssql-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A set of tools and conventions for using mssql 2005 with RailsInstallationruby script/plugin install http://rails-mssql-tools.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ </p>

<p>UsageThe objective of this plugin is to: </p>

<p>implement a conventional method for migrating mssql procs, views, and triggers. for legacy mssql databases, resolve camel-cased attributes to Rails&#39; conventional underscored names, allowing developers to refer to model object attributes in the conventional manner: - model.user_name vs. model.UserName (camel-case is a common naming convention  
<br/>in the MS dev community) 
<br/>	 </p>

<p>Camel-case resolution assumptions - the legacy db consistently uses camel-casing for column names (not a mix of  
<br/>camel-case and underscore)</p>
 title : The rails-multifielddate-plugin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MultiFieldDateDescriptionThis is a Ruby on Rails plugin for use with tables/models that need to allow incomplete dates (e.g., just the year and month or just the month and day). Requires that the table have four fields: year, month, day, and full date. When the year, month, and day fields are present, the full date field is updated. </p>

<p>There are two ways to use this plugin: </p>

<p>acts_as_multi_field_date multi_field_date </p>

<p>acts_as_multi_field_date only allows one date_field per model. e.g., </p>

<p>class Birth &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
<br/>  acts_as_multi_field_date :date_field =&gt; &#39;birth_date&#39;
<br/>  #assumes year, month, and day fields are &#39;year&#39;, &#39;month&#39;, and &#39;day&#39; by default.
<br/>  #can be changed: 
<br/>  # acts_as_multi_field_date :date_field =&gt; &#39;birth_date&#39;, :day_field =&gt; &#39;bday&#39;
<br/>endmulti_field_date, on the other hand, allows multiple dates in a model, e.g., </p>

<p>class Person &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
<br/>  multi_field_date :birth, :date_field =&gt; &#39;birth_date&#39;, :year_field =&gt; &#39;birth_year&#39;,
<br/>    :month_field =&gt; &#39;birth_month&#39;, :day_field =&gt; &#39;birth_day&#39;
<br/>  multi_field_date :death, :date_field =&gt; &#39;death_date&#39;, :year_field =&gt; &#39;death_year&#39;,
<br/>    :month_field =&gt; &#39;death_month&#39;, :day_field =&gt; &#39;death_day&#39;
<br/>endIt also includes a helper method for displaying a partially completed date, and some helpers for generating arrays for HTML select menus.  Includes rather extensive unit test coverage (requires SQLite3). </p>

<p>Installationscript/plugin install http://rails-multifielddate-plugin.googlecode.com/svn/plugins/multi_field_dateThen run  rake doc:plugins  to generate RDoc documentation.   </p>

<p>See also: README</p>

 title : The rails-plugin-text-area-with-auto-resize Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionOverrides ActionView::Helpers::FormHelper::text_area to provide auto resizing/growing of text areas. </p>

<p>Installscript/plugin install -x http://rails-plugin-text-area-with-auto-resize.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/text_area_with_auto_resize </p>

 title : The rails-plugins Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>coming soon</p>
 title : The rails-plugins-a1kmm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A collection of plugins for Ruby, targeted at rails web apps</p>
 summary : <p>Postman is a simple rails plugin that calculates shipping rates based on data from the database. It is meant for cases where the postal service does not have an API for getting the shipping rates. </p>

<p>What Postman does is to get the values from the tables and calculate it out. The values are found in your database tables. You&#39;d have to add the mailing rates into the tables for it to work. </p>

<p>The plugin is very simple. I&#39;ve included some sql files to help put in the countries and mailing rates(in Singapore). You can use them as a reference. </p>

<p>And here&#39;s the original rates: </p>

<p>http://www.singpost.com.sg/quick_services/quicks_03postal_02overseas01.htm </p>

<p>The blog post is here </p>

<p>http://liangzan.net/?p=31 </p>

<p>Installation </p>

<p>ruby script/plugin install http://rails-postman.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/postman </p>

<p>Before using it </p>

<p>Generate and apply the migration: </p>

<p>ruby script/generate postman_migration  
<br/>rake db:migrate  
<br/>Add values into the tables </p>

<p>countries  destinations  postage_mails  step_rates  step_weights  transit_time  weight_limit  Definition of the tables </p>

<p>destinations </p>

<p>the term for the group of countries. Usually postal services group countries up by distance, and set different rates for each zone.  postage_mails </p>

<p>corresponding rates for the weight  weight_limit </p>

<p>the maximum weight limit for the rates from postage_mails  step_rates </p>

<p>the unit rates for additional weight beyond the weight limit  step_weight </p>

<p>the divisor used to divide up the additional weight  transit_time </p>

<p>the time needed to ship to the destinations  How to use it </p>

<p>Just call </p>

<p>Postman.postageCalculator(&quot;Singapore&quot;, 100) </p>

<p>the first argument is the coutry in text, the second argument is the weight in your base unit(which happens to be grams for me) Testing </p>

<p>Create a database called &#39;plugin_test&#39; </p>

<p>Update the user/password in database.yml </p>

<p>And run &#39;rake test&#39; from the plugin directory</p>

 title : The rails-spaces Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Test Plugin provides several handy facilities.</p>

<p>Fixtures for Code with No Underlying Model</p>

<p>It can be a bear to test code with no underlying model or with a model that is not contained in your primary database. That&#39;s because the fixtures, by default, populate the test database. Enter the brand new command:</p>

<p>no_db_fixtures :foos, :bars</p>

<p>Asserts for Any Predicate</p>

<p>It is more natural to use an assert of the form:</p>

<p>assert_include [&#39;moo&#39;, &#39;goo&#39;, &#39;doo], @foo</p>

<p>-or, more concretely-</p>

<p>assert_include expected_email, email.to</p>

<p>Each of these is automagically created to utilize predicates in the Ruby language or in your own code. First the predicate? form is attempted, then simply predicate without the question mark.</p>

 title : The rails-unobtrusive-date-picker Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>THIS PROJECT IS NO LONGER MAINTAINED -10/15/09The latest release of the Unobtrusive Date-Picker Widget Javascript library makes this plugin unnecessary so I&#39;ve decided to no longer maintain it.  </p>

<p>THIS PAGE IS NO LONGER MAINTAINEDPlease refer to the GitHub Page </p>

<p>This is a helper for creating a date or date-time picker that uses the Unobtrusive Date-Picker Widget to add a clickable calendar image that will bring up a calendar picker if javascript is available. It replicates as much of the API of the Rails date_select, and datetime_select form helpers. </p>

<p>It also uses the 12 Hour Time plugin so that 12 Hour times can be processed by Active Record. </p>

<p>You may want to consider compressing the javascript files with Dean Edward&#39;s Packer  or Douglas Crockford&#39;s JSMin before deploying your application. </p>

<p>Installscript/plugin install git://github.com/brianjlandau/unobtrusive_date_picker.git</p>

 title : The rails4scm Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>基于Ruby on Rail的SCM(软件配置管理）WEB应用。为软件企业、开发团队提供对软件代码、文档、数据等所有配置项的高效管理。 </p>

<p>SCM是比版本控制更高一级的管理工具，比如不同项目之间共享产品，产品之间共享程序模块等。SCM的关键是变更控制：比如一个现场的问题、一个改进建议（Issue,事件）会触发哪些变更， 而这个变更又涉及了哪些程序单元（配置项，一组文件）的哪个版本，影响到了哪些现场项目，其他产品会不会受到影响？这些任务的管理需要由系统来支持，仅靠CVS等版本控制系统是不够的。 </p>

<p>SCM之所以重要，可以从许多公司和团队发生的下列问题来看出： </p>

<p>● 找不到软件：&quot;我知道我写完了，但是不知道把它放在那了&quot;； </p>

<p>● 相互覆盖代码：开发人员对相同的代码做不同的修改，互相覆盖，必然至少有一个人很郁闷； </p>

<p>● 无法返回：新的修改比原来的代码还差劲，不能返回原来的版本； </p>

<p>● 版本混乱：那份程序应该给用户呢；出错了，应该打那个版本的补丁呢； </p>

<p>● 管理和归档意识混乱： </p>

<p>－客户打电话：&quot;出问题了&quot;； </p>

<p>－程序员解决了问题，但是没有进行变更登记； </p>

<p>－在没有修改包含在内的情况下进行联编软件； </p>

<p>－把未修改的软件交付用户； </p>

<p>－客户打电话：&quot;还有问题&quot;； </p>

<p>－操作员：&quot;我的确已经修改了&quot;  等等 </p>

<p>   本SCM系统已经开发完成C/S版本,已经实际应用并产生很好的效果。现在将扩展基于WEB的查询和变更管理功能，并逐步将整个产品移植到rails平台。 </p>

<p>本项目讨论组（论坛）网址: http://groups.google.com/group/rails4scm?hl=zh-CN </p>

<p>讨论组（论坛）的邮件地址: rails4scm@googlegroups.com </p>

<p>为了成为开发成员，你需要用自己的邮箱注册一个googlecode帐号（sign in那里），然后把帐号告诉任意一个project owner，由他将你作为新用户加入到项目成员中（是否项目成员的区别只是能否提交代码和编辑wiki，其他不受影响）。 </p>

<p>源码下载和提交应使用SVN客户端（建议用tortoisewin32svn.msi这个explore插件，或者NETBEANS集成环境）。代码reposity的地址是： </p>

<p># Project members authenticate over HTTPS to allow committing changes. </p>

<p>svn checkout https://rails4scm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ rails4scm --username xxxx@yyyy.com </p>

<p>When prompted, enter your generated googlecode.com password. 这个密码在setting那个菜单里可以看到并可重新生成。 </p>

<p># Non-members may check out a read-only working copy anonymously over HTTP.  </p>

<p>svn checkout http://rails4scm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ rails4scm   </p>

<p>有任何疑问，可以通过邮件或者电话与project owners联系。</p>

 title : The railslivecd Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Rails Live CD project was born on Ezra Zygmuntowicz&#39; blog and realized with help from Brian Ketelsen. It is based on PCLinuxOS which is a great Linux distribution for creating LiveCDs. More information at PCLinusOS.com</p>

<p>To use it, just download, burn and reboot! Or if you have a virtualization or emulation engine like Qemu, Parallels or VMWare it is even easier.</p>

<p>Many people are curious about Ruby on Rails but don&#39;t want to go through the pain of installing it locally. The Rails Live CD solves this problem by allowing you to have a fully operating Ruby on Rails development environment without even touching your hard drive! Others are interested in developing Ruby on Rails applications in Linux but don&#39;t have the skills or the patience to do the installation and compiling required to get Ruby on Rails running on a typical Linux installation. Rails Live CD allows you to install directly to your hard drive and walks you through the process. No compiling or ./configure ./make ./make install dancing required.</p>

<p>RailsLiveCD.org is hosted on RailsPlayground.Net using Typo with a very nice theme created by Amy Hoy of Slash7 fame.</p>

<p>* the idea here is not to create new stuff but to show existing stuff working.</p>

 title : The railswebgame Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The railswhere Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RAILS 2.0 READY!Version 1.2 - released Oct 30, 2007.  ChangeLog </p>

<p>OverviewDo you have a query conditions that look like this? </p>

<p>“(name like ‘tim%’) and (age &lt; 10) and (category=’friends’ or category=’family’)”Do you need a way to easily build these queries, with the ability to add more or less conditions based on user input? </p>

<p>Enter RailsWhere] </p>

<p>Installationscript/plugin install http://railswhere.googlecode.com/svn/tags/railswhere </p>

<p>Example UsageSimple </p>

<p>  User.find(:all, :conditions =&gt; Where{|w|
<br/>    w.and &quot;first_name like ?&quot;, &quot;#{first_name}%&quot; if params[:first_name]
<br/>    w.and &quot;last_name like ?&quot;, &quot;#{last_name}%&quot; if params[:last_name]
<br/>  }Nested conditions </p>

<p>  w = Where.new
<br/>  
<br/>  for field in [:first_name, :last_name, :phone, :email]
<br/>    w.and(&#39;#{field} like ?&#39;, params[:search][field] + &#39;%&#39;) unless params[:search][field].blank?
<br/>  end</p>

<p>  w.and { |sw|
<br/>    for status in params[search][:statuses].split(&#39;,&#39;)
<br/>      sw.or &#39;status=?&#39;, status
<br/>    end
<br/>  }</p>

<p>  User.find(:all, :conditions =&gt; w.to_s)
<br/>  # &#39;(first_name like &#39;tim%&#39;) and (last_name like &#39;harper%&#39;) and ( (status = &#39;new&#39;) or (status = &#39;expired&#39;))&#39;Negate an entire condition conditions </p>

<p>  w = Where.new
<br/>  
<br/>  w.and_not { |ww|
<br/>    ww.or &quot;x=1&quot;
<br/>    ww.or &quot;x=2&quot;
<br/>    ww.or &quot;x=3&quot;
<br/>  }</p>

<p>  User.find(:all, :conditions =&gt; w.to_s)
<br/>  # &#39;not ((x=1) or (x=2) or (x=3))&#39;Combine 2 where clauses together </p>

<p>  w = Where.new(&quot;id=5&quot;)
<br/>  y = Where.new(&quot;first_name=&#39;tim&#39;&quot;)</p>

<p>  User.find(:all, :conditions =&gt; (w | y))
<br/>  # &#39;(id=5) OR (first_name=&#39;tim&#39;)&#39;</p>

<p>  User.find(:all, :conditions =&gt; (w &amp; y))
<br/>  # &#39;(id=5) AND (first_name=&#39;tim&#39;)&#39;HelpNeed help?  Have questions?  Try: </p>

<p>Filing an issue The RailsWhere mailing list </p>

<p>DocsInstall the plugin, go to the plugin folder, run &#39;rdoc&#39; </p>

<p>Author  Tim Harper ( &#39;tim_see_harperATgmail._see_om&#39;.gsub(&#39;_see_&#39;, &#39;c&#39;).gsub(&#39;AT&#39;, &#39;@&#39;) )Other plugins by Tim Harper</p>

<br/>cap railsyard:setup
<br/>cap deploy:setup
<br/>cap deploy</p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>RCompCompile your applications with Rake and Ruby!This project currently targets .NET applications but it could be extended to include various other languages and platforms. Tools like MSBuild and NAnt are great but they work with sometimes cryptic configuration files. If you have a small project and you would like to automate your builds with Rake and Ruby, this project may be for you! </p>

<p>How ToHere&#39;s a simple task that compiles all of the source files in the &quot;src&quot; directory into an executable along with a debug file: </p>

<p>RComp::DotNet::CscTask.new do |t|
<br/>    Dir.glob(&quot;src/*.cs&quot;).each { |input| t.inputs &lt;&lt; input}
<br/>    t.references &lt;&lt; &quot;System.Data.dll&quot;
<br/>    t.target = &quot;winexe&quot;
<br/>    t.out = &quot;bin/MyProgram.exe&quot;
<br/>    t.debug = true
<br/>endCompiler OptionsRComp can easily be customized. You can control compiler options through instance accessors like target but you can also add options using these methods: </p>

<p>add_option(name, value)RComp :DotNet::CscTask.new do |t|
<br/>    t.add_option :platform, &quot;x64&quot;
<br/>endcompiler_optionsRComp :DotNet::CscTask.new do |t|
<br/>    t.compiler_options[:platform] = &quot;/platform:x64&quot;
<br/>end</p>

 summary : <p>Sync your Rails to S3Backup your files Serve static content from S3 (s. Links) rake s3create -&gt; create your bucket
<br/>rake s3commit -&gt; upload files to s3
<br/>rake s3update -&gt; download files from s3put the s3sync.rake into lib/tasks insert your keys / bucketname / sync-folders (will create lib/s3sync) </p>

<p>RequiresS3 Account your s3 keys unique bucket name ruby 1.8.4 or greater $ ruby -vssl lib for ruby $ sudo apt-get install ruby libopenssl-rubyplz report any issue/suggestion, still learning :)LINKS:idea serve public files from s3 s3sync S3 Organizer for FireFox S3Browse TODO:confirmation/summary after commit&amp;update check ruby version -&gt; failure check if openssl is installed -&gt; prompt for install s3enable/s3disable -&gt; change configuration so that s3 links will be used use s3:xxx syntax</p>

 title : The random-bits Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>web项目脚手架rapid-framework是一个以spring为核心的项目脚手架(或者称为胶水框架)，框架将各个零散的框架(struts,strust2,springmvc,hibernate,ibatis,spring_jdbc,flex)搭建好，并内置一个代码生成器，辅助项目开发,可以生成java的hibernat model,dao,manager,struts+struts2 action类,可以生成jsp的增删改查及列表页面 </p>

<p>在线文档 </p>

<p>请加入google-group参与讨论 </p>

<p>rapid-framework官方网站 </p>

<p>项目定位本框架是类似appfuse,springside的框架,但定位与springside及appfuse不同,它们更像是一些代码的最佳实践,而rapid-framework则是应用于实际项目开发的脚手架, 并且代码也将优化至极致.使用脚手架3分钟即可以搭建出一个实际项目. </p>

<p>框架概览Dao: spring_jdbc, hibernate, ibatis2, ibatis3, 可以切换dao组件 Dao Helper: 基于dialect的分页(ibatis2, ibatis3, jdbc),动态sql构造工具rapid-xsqlbuilder Web MVC: struts1, struts2, springmvc, springmvc_rest, 可以切换web组件 Template: (velocity, freemarker, jsp)的模板可以相互继承, velocity及freemarker可以实现模板之间的管道操作 分页组件: extremeTable, rapid-simpletable UI: rapid-validation表单验证, My97DatePicker日期控件 单元测试: spring test+DBunit 底层支撑: 插件体系及代码生成器(rapid-generator) 项目质量完整的单元测试及持续集成,保证代码质量 代码生成器生成的增删改查截图 </p>

<p>后续请查看v2.x路线图: roadmap </p>

<p>bug提交</p>
 title : The rapid-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>rapid-framework简单介绍: </p>

<p>类似ruby on rails的java fullstack web项目脚手架 基于spring,struts(struts2),hibernate大家都熟悉的组合</p>
 title : The rapid-generator Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The rapid-php Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rapid-PHP is an OpenSource MVC framework designed to automate most common tasks. It is aimed to simplify usage of model-driven engineering in the web application development process.</p>

<p>Minimal Rapid-PHP-based application will contain model definition files only, while library takes the task of generating default actions, view, database schema, database migration scripts and ACLs. On the other side, library architecture should allow an easy overriding of these defaults.</p>

<p>Rapid-PHP is inspired by Ruby-on-Rails project and several other PHP frameworks. The difference is more powerful ORM system allowing automatic generation of flexible queries.</p>
 summary : <p>Home | Index </p>

<p>Rapid Tools for SharePoint is a set of developer tools that are dedicated to making SharePoint developers more productive. Rapid tools enables developers to build SharePoint custom applications using the full Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC).  </p>

<p>Traditionally using the SDL with the SharePoint platform has been a painful and awkward process, but with Rapid Tools for SharePoint application developers are now in full control of SharePoint development and deployment in a way that was not possible before. </p>

<p>ComponentsSPDeploy is a client side component that extends MSBuild to include targets that allow you to create a SharePoint solution file (.wsp) from a standard C# class library project inside Visual Studio. In addition, SPDeploy allows you to deploy your compiled wsp file to a remote SharePoint server. This allows you to develop locally and deploy to SharePoint remotely. </p>

<p>Provisioning Framework is set of APIs that allow you provision a SharePoint assets including Site Collections, Sites, Pages and Files. </p>

<p>Exception Display is a component allows you to control the SharePoint&#39;s unhandled exception behavior. </p>

<p>Data Cache allows you to cache data inside the SharePoint content database. This provides high performance data caching in web applications and also non-web applications, including SPtimer Jobs, stsadm command, WinForms applications and console applications.</p>
 title : The rapid-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub

 summary : <p>OverviewRattle (the R Analytical Tool To Learn Easily) provides a simple and logical interface for data mining. It is a new data mining application based on the open source and free statistical language R  using the Gnome  graphical interface. The application runs under GNU/Linux and MS/Windows. The aim is to provide an intuitive interface that takes you through the basic steps of data mining, as well as illustrating the R code that is used to achieve this. Whilst the tool itself may be sufficient for all of a user&#39;s needs, it also provides a stepping stone to more sophisticated processing and modelling in R itself, for sophisticated and unconstrained data mining. </p>

 title : The rb-mp3splt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Mp3splt </p>

<p>A wrapper for the command line tool mp3splt. </p>

<p>Requires the mp3splt binary to be installed. http://mp3splt.sourceforge.net/mp3splt_page/home.php </p>

<p>Install on OSX using macports </p>

<p>sudo port install mp3spltExample </p>

<p>class Track &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
<br/>  file_column :filename, :root_path =&gt; RAILS_ROOT, :web_root =&gt; &quot;&quot;
<br/>  file_column :sample,   :root_path =&gt; UPLOAD_ROOT, :web_root =&gt; UPLOAD_WEB</p>

<p>  def generate_sample
<br/>    sample = Mp3splt.new( :input_file=&gt;self.filename, 
<br/>                            :output_filename=&gt;&quot;sample.mp3&quot;, 
<br/>                            :output_directory=&gt;self.filename_dir)
<br/>    sample.cut!
<br/>    self.update_attributes(:sample =&gt; File.open(sample_temp))
<br/>  rescue
<br/>    logger.error(&quot;Unable to create sample for #{self.id} - #{self.title}&quot;)
<br/>  end
<br/>endCopyright (c) 2008 Blavos - !Indierockmedia, released under the MIT license</p>

 summary : <p>Ruby Social News is a new social news system that is designed entirely within Ruby on Rails, and almost entirely self-contained--only a couple of plugins are used for dealing with user changeable timezones. </p>

<p>rbsocialnews contains a highly customizable user permission system, which is easily modified to work with anyone&#39;s need from a simple web based administration system. It also contains language filters, threaded commenting system and is fully ajax enabled where appropriate for the system. </p>

<p>rbsocialnews is also tightly coded, with full testing framework included and designed to be as optimized as possible to make sure both speed of loading, and load on the server itself is controlled, plus it&#39;s designed to be very scalable across multiple servers.</p>

 title : The rbrito Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>my projects</p>
 summary : <p>RBScoutSubmit is a small set of REALbasic classes that can be used to submit crash data from your REALbasic application to your FogBugz installation. </p>

<p> How To Use  </p>

<p>1) Copy the RBScoutSubmit folder and it&#39;s contents into your REALbasic project. </p>

<p>2) Add RBScoutSubmit class as a property of the main App class. </p>

<p>3) Copy code from RBScoutSubmitExample project&#39;s App.UnhandledException into your own project. </p>

<p>4) Change URL, ScoutProject, ScoutArea and ScoutUserName to reflect your FogBugz install and project for this application. </p>

<p>If you want to use the stack trace functionality in your app, copy the StackCleaner folder into your project, otherwise comment out the code in the UnhandledException example code that uses StackArray. </p>

<p>It is STRONGLY recommended that you try the RBScoutSubmitExample project with your own URL, ScoutProject, ScoutArea and ScoutUserName settings to test that it all works before updating your own project. </p>

<p>Remember, none of this is going to work unless you have a publicly available FogBugz scoutSubmit.asp or scoutSubmit.php page.</p>

 title : The rcf-cpp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Remote Call Framework (RCF) is  a portable C++ middleware framework using native C++ language features to avoid manual code generation. An overview of RCF is available on CodeProject , and a User Guide is also available. </p>

<p>RCF 1.2 is distributed under the GPL license. For RCF-based non-GPL compatible applications, a commercial license is available and can be obtained from the author. </p>

<p>RCF 1.2 has been tested on Windows, Linux, Solaris, FreeBSD and OS X platforms, with the following compilers: </p>

<p>Visual C++ 6 Visual C++ 7.1 Visual C++ 8.0 (32 and 64 bit) Visual C++ 9.0 (32 and 64 bit) gcc 3.2 - 3.4 (32 and 64 bit) gcc 4.x (32 and 64 bit) Borland C++ 5.6 (Borland C++ Builder 6) Borland C++ 5.9 (Borland C++ Builder 2007) Metrowerks CodeWarrior 9.2 Intel C++ 9.0 for Windows  Intel C++ 10.1 Windows In addition, third parties have deployed RCF on QNX and WinCE.</p>

 title : The rcor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>We&#39;re moving!This project is moving to ruby forge.   The content here is being moved over. </p>

<p>What is it?A active specification framework for Ruby. Based largely on Concordion for Java, but was influenced by FIT as well. </p>

<p>What does it do?Paraphrasing the definition of Concordion: </p>

<p>Ruby Concordion is an open source framework for Ruby that lets you turn a plain English description of a requirement into an automated test -- an active specification. </p>

<p>Where can I see what it actually does?See the wiki for more information on ruby-concordion. In particular the following pages provide good starting points for understanding concordion: </p>

<p>Tutorial RCorOverview WhatRcorActuallyDoes ComplexExample   Since Rails is so widely used lately, a lot of people want to know about using RCor and Rails together.  A short demo is available: RailsAndRCor </p>

<p>Where can I get it?Preferred MethodClick here for the preferred installation instructions. </p>

<p>Packaged DistributionsSee the downloads section for gem, tar and zip distributions.  </p>

<p>SourceClick here to browse the source online. </p>

<p>You can checkout a read-only copy of the source using this command: </p>

<p>svn co http://rcor.googlecode.com/svn/rcor/trunk/Where can I get help or complain about this thing?RCor was written by Ben Goodspeed of Goodspeed IT Consulting. If you have questions or comments, please post to ruby-concordion@googlegroups.com.</p>

 title : The rdba Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RDBA is intended to be to Ruby what JDBC is to Java - a cross-DBMS API for data access. RDBA is an adaptation in the sense that it will not strictly conform to the JDBC API. Instead, it will use Ruby conventions (e.g., method naming conventions) whenever possible and use Ruby features (e.g., closures) to the greatest extent possible.</p>

<p>The 0.1 version of RDBA will support Oracle. Future releases will support Postgres, MySQL, and other commercial RDBMS&#39;s.</p>
 title : The rdbc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RDBC is intended to be to Ruby what JDBC is to Java - a universal, cross-DBMS API for data access. RDBC is an adaptation in the sense that it does not follow the JDBC specification exactly. Instead, Ruby conventions (e.g., method naming conventions) will be followed whenever possible and Ruby features (e.g., closures) will be used to the greatest degree possible.</p>

<p>The initial 0.1 version of RDBC will support Oracle. Successive versions will provide support for Postgres, MySQL, and other DBMS&#39;s.</p>

 title : The recipejar Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>WelcomeI wanted to come up with a digital replacement for my Mom&#39;s old-box-of-3x5-cards method of recipe organization, and this is it.  </p>

<p>RecipeJar doesn&#39;t get in your way.  Simple enough for Grandma, but flexible enough for the food loving computer geek in the family.  You can just leave your recipes organized alphabetically, or if you feel like getting fancy, you can add Tags/Labels/Categories (e.g.;whatever you want to call them).  You can even search by Ingredient, if that strikes your fancy.   </p>

<p>Recipes are stored as simple HTML files, you can read them using your favorite browser or even publish the entire folder as a standalone website.  Truly Geeky users can write their own editing commands (useful for inserting HTML formatting), write templates for the index and recipe files, create alternate style sheets, and even teach RecipeJar to recognize new units. </p>

<p>Installation is simple: On OSX just open the dmg and drag to the applications folder, on all other systems just run the jar file. </p>

<p>If you try it out, and want to let me know what you thought of it or want to report a bug, send me an email at: yehoodig {at} gmail {dot} com.</p>
 title : The recipesonrails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>I love cooking, I&#39;m not the greatest bcook in the world but I&#39;m also not the worst.  For years now Ive kept a little folder of recipes and sometimes found my writing really difficult to understand which made for some interesting alternatives to the originals.  Now I am sure there are a million and one things that do exactly the same as this application but none of those are done by me. </p>

<p>So I used this an an excuse to form my little pet project done in Ruby On Rails.  Now if you have read the About page you&#39;ll know that I originally started the project in PHP, then switched to Perl (Catalyst MVC) and eventually moved the whole thing into Ruby because I enjoyed the instant results that I was getting. </p>

<p>Of course I had problems and was using it rreally to learn more about Ruby but I got to a point at the end of 2007 that I got so annoyed I decided to just release it which would spur me on to make it better.  Which it has.  From the start of the year I have already fixed a few things and changed some of the code so that it fits in more with the DRY methodology. </p>

<p>I intend to do some more on the project and you should consult the wiki here for my current plans on whats being thought about, implemented and wwhat I want to change.</p>

 summary : <p>Recless is a type inferring Erlang parse transform.
<br/>Instead of writing these lines:
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

 summary : <p>A web app written in Ruby on Rails which allows you to keep track of recommendations and their justifications</p>
 title : The recommendations Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ActsAsRecommendable </p>

<p>acts_as_recommendable Rails Plugin </p>

<p>This is Woc Project that was held by Openmaru </p>

<p>Project Page : http://winterofcode.grouphub.com/projects/1670122/project/log </p>

<p>Any questions/comments can be addressed to Song Chihyung, Jung Hoon Lee  </p>

<p>Please see &quot;MIT-LICENSE&quot; in the top level directory of this distribution and the notices in the source files for distribution and copyright information. </p>

<p>Copyright (c) 2008 Chihyung, Jung Hun Lee, released under the MIT license </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>INSTALLATION </p>

<p>To install, simply run: </p>

<p>#script/plugin install https://woc.springloops.com/source/recommendation </p>

<p>You&#39;ll then need to make the ratings table.  You should probably make a migration to do so, which you can do with the following command: </p>

<p>script/generate migration add_recommend_user script/generate migration add_recommend_rating script/generate migration add_recommend_item </p>

<p>Then edit the resulting migration source that it puts in db/migrate (it will be named something like 015_add_recommend_user.rb, the number at the beginning of the filename will probably be different in your instance). </p>

<p>The table needed by the plugin needs to be named &quot;users&quot; and have two columns in addition to the primary key. Also, The table named &quot;ratings&quot; have five columns and the table named &quot;item&quot; have five columns </p>

<p>They are: </p>

<p>+ users id          integer name        string </p>

<p>+ ratings id          integer user_id     integer item_id     integer rating      string ts          string </p>

<p>+ items id          integer title       string </p>

<p>You can do this in your migration with the following code: </p>

<p>+user </p>

<p>def self.up </p>

<p>create_table :users do |t| 
<br/>t.column :name, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end </p>

<p>def self.down </p>

<p>drop_table :users 
<br/>end </p>

<p>+rating </p>

<p>def self.up 
<br/>create_table :ratings do |t| 
<br/>t.column :user_id, :integer 
<br/>t.column :item_id, :integer 
<br/>t.column :rating, :string 
<br/>t.column :ts, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end 
<br/>def self.down 
<br/>drop_table :ratings 
<br/>end 
<br/>  </p>

<p>+item </p>

<p>def self.up 
<br/>create_table :items do |t| 
<br/>t.column :title, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end 
<br/>def self.down 
<br/>drop_table :items 
<br/>end 
<br/>  </p>

<p>After saving the migration run the following from the top-level directory of your rails application: $ rake migrate (rake db:migrate) </p>

<p>After that, you should have everything you need setup and ready to go. </p>

<p>It probably wouldn&#39;t hurt to run through the included unit tests quickly, but you don&#39;t have to: </p>

<p>$ rake test:plugins </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>USING THE PLUGIN </p>

<p>Pretty simple, really.  You just need to add &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; or &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommendable&quot; at the top of your ActiveRecord model, and everything should magically become available to you :) </p>

<p>Carefully, &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; be included in ActiveRecord model like &quot;User&quot;, and &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommendable&quot; be included in ActiveRecord model like &quot;Item&quot;. </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>The Basics: </p>

<p>Any model that &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; or &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>has the following methods available to it: 
<br/>          </p>

<p>&quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>similar_users : Find simiar users. Score that evaluatie item is simiar to each others 
<br/>recommend_items : Recommend item. The recommended item is based on similarity among users. </p>

<p>        </p>

<p>&quot;acts_as_itembased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>similar_items : Find simiar items. </p>

<p>Example: 
<br/>ActsAsRecommendable </p>

<p>acts_as_recommendable Rails Plugin </p>

<p>This is Woc Project that was held by Openmaru </p>

<p>Project Page : http://winterofcode.grouphub.com/projects/1670122/project/log </p>

<p>Any questions/comments can be addressed to Song Chihyung, Jung Hoon Lee  </p>

<p>Please see &quot;MIT-LICENSE&quot; in the top level directory of this distribution and the notices in the source files for distribution and copyright information. </p>

<p>Copyright (c) 2008 Chihyung, Jung Hun Lee, released under the MIT license </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>INSTALLATION </p>

<p>To install, simply run: </p>

<p>#script/plugin install https://woc.springloops.com/source/recommendation </p>

<p>You&#39;ll then need to make the ratings table.  You should probably make a migration to do so, which you can do with the following command: </p>

<p>script/generate migration add_recommend_user script/generate migration add_recommend_rating script/generate migration add_recommend_item </p>

<p>Then edit the resulting migration source that it puts in db/migrate (it will be named something like 015_add_recommend_user.rb, the number at the beginning of the filename will probably be different in your instance). </p>

<p>The table needed by the plugin needs to be named &quot;users&quot; and have two columns in addition to the primary key. Also, The table named &quot;ratings&quot; have five columns and the table named &quot;item&quot; have five columns </p>

<p>They are: </p>

<p>+ users id          integer name        string </p>

<p>+ ratings id          integer user_id     integer item_id     integer rating      string ts          string </p>

<p>+ items id          integer title       string </p>

<p>You can do this in your migration with the following code: </p>

<p>+user </p>

<p>def self.up </p>

<p>create_table :users do |t| 
<br/>t.column :name, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end </p>

<p>def self.down </p>

<p>drop_table :users 
<br/>end </p>

<p>+rating </p>

<p>def self.up 
<br/>create_table :ratings do |t| 
<br/>t.column :user_id, :integer 
<br/>t.column :item_id, :integer 
<br/>t.column :rating, :string 
<br/>t.column :ts, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end 
<br/>def self.down 
<br/>drop_table :ratings 
<br/>end 
<br/>  </p>

<p>+item </p>

<p>def self.up 
<br/>create_table :items do |t| 
<br/>t.column :title, :string 
<br/>end 
<br/>end 
<br/>def self.down 
<br/>drop_table :items 
<br/>end 
<br/>  </p>

<p>After saving the migration run the following from the top-level directory of your rails application: $ rake migrate (rake db:migrate) </p>

<p>After that, you should have everything you need setup and ready to go. </p>

<p>It probably wouldn&#39;t hurt to run through the included unit tests quickly, but you don&#39;t have to: </p>

<p>$ rake test:plugins </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>USING THE PLUGIN </p>

<p>Pretty simple, really.  You just need to add &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; or &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommendable&quot; at the top of your ActiveRecord model, and everything should magically become available to you :) </p>

<p>Carefully, &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; be included in ActiveRecord model like &quot;User&quot;, and &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommendable&quot; be included in ActiveRecord model like &quot;Item&quot;. </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>The Basics: </p>

<p>Any model that &quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; or &quot;acts_as_itembased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>has the following methods available to it: 
<br/>          </p>

<p>&quot;acts_as_userbased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>similar_users : Find simiar users. Score that evaluatie item is simiar to each others 
<br/>recommend_items : Recommend item. The recommended item is based on similarity among users. </p>

<p>        </p>

<p>&quot;acts_as_itembased_recommnedable&quot; 
<br/>similar_items : Find simiar items. </p>

<p>Example: </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>class User &lt; ActiveRecord::Base 
<br/>acts_as_userbased_recommendable 
<br/>cts_as_userbased_recommendable :item  =&gt; &quot;item&quot;, :rating =&gt; &quot;ratings&quot;, :rating_value_col =&gt;&quot;rating&quot;  has_many :ratings 
<br/>end </p>

<p>class Item &lt; ActiveRecord::Base 
<br/>acts_as_itembased_recommendable 
<br/>cts_as_itembased_recommendable :item  =&gt; &quot;item&quot;, :rating =&gt; &quot;ratings&quot;, :rating_value_col =&gt;&quot;rating&quot;            has_many :ratings 
<br/>end 
<br/>        </p>

<p>nital record use recommend_data.sql(Mysql version)  or rake pour_sample_data 
<br/>Notice! For exact recommend, It needs so many data set. </p>

<p>ind user at discretion for recommending item. user = User.find(:first)    
<br/>=&gt; # 
<br/>ecommend item that be suitable to the user. default item number is 3 user.recommend_items 
<br/>=&gt; &quot;The Night Listener&quot;, &quot;Superman Returns&quot;, &quot;Lady in the Water&quot;] 
<br/>o setting recommened item number. user.recommend_items(5) 
<br/>=&gt; &quot;The Night Listener&quot;, &quot;Superman Returns&quot;, &quot;Lady in the Water&quot;, &quot;Snakes on a Plane&quot;, &quot;Just My Luck&quot;]        
<br/>ind similar user by similarity. user.similar_users 
<br/>=&gt; 7, 6, 5] 
<br/>ind item at discretion for recommending item. item = Item.find(:first) 
<br/>=&gt; # 
<br/>ind similar item by similarity item.similar_items 
<br/>=&gt; &quot;Snakes on a Plane&quot;, &quot;Superman Returns&quot;, &quot;You, Me and Dupree&quot;] 
<br/>Copyright (c) 2008 Chihyung, Jung Hun Lee, released under the MIT license</p>

 title : The recordselect Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RecordSelect is a Rails widget to help you pick one record out of many. I designed it as a more usable and performant alternative to generating a massive dropdown list. It relies on AJAX for the cooler uses (all the provided view helpers rely on JavaScript) but can also function in a pure-http fashion (although multi-select support is provided in a pure-JavaScript implementation). </p>

<p>Go ahead and check out the demo app to really see how it works! Or go straight to installing the plugin into your own app. </p>

<p>DEPENDENCIESThis depends on the excellent Paginator gem by Bruce Williams. This simple gem is available at http://paginator.rubyforge.org.</p>

 title : The red5phone Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SIP Application for Standalone Red5 Server 0.8.0 and above is http://red5phone.googlecode.com/files/sip_r29.zip. </p>

<p>Unzip and move the sip folder to webapps. </p>

<p> You will need to install Red5 server 0.8.0   Run red5phone application with http://your_red5_server:5080/sip </p>

<p>To checkout SVN use http://red5phone.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/sip/ </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Changelog </p>

<p>R29 </p>

<p>Incoming call failt falt fixed by Marcin Balcer </p>

<p>R28 </p>

<p>Timestamp fix by Rafael on RTPSender Ignore non-audio RTP packets for RTMP audio by Naoki </p>

<p>Transfer feature by  Lior </p>

<p>Blind transfer button to be used as followed: </p>

<p>a. register to your proxy 
<br/>b. make a call or get a call (than the transfer button will show up after call is answered) 
<br/>c. change the text of the dialed number to the number you want to transfer the call too  
<br/>d. press transfer button. 
<br/>Conference feature using transfer by Dele </p>

<p>a. set your conference number 
<br/>b. call person. click on conference button to put caller in conference 
<br/>c. do that for all participants and click on conference icon to join confeence 
<br/>R27 </p>

<p>Dele Olajide Made red5phone compatible with Red5 server 0.8.0 </p>

<p>Lior Herman Added outbound proxy settings in flex object, to solve realm problems. </p>

<p>Fixed DTMF. Tested with UK PSTN and works ok.  Added Nellymoser encoder from Joseph Artsimovich (jart@users.sourceforge.net). </p>

<p>  Mauro Brasil, Rafael and UOL (www.uol.co.br) contributions </p>

<p>Cleaned up the code  </p>

<p>Implemented multi-codec support for Red5phone (PCMU, PCMA, iLBC and G.729). G.729 requires payment of royalities and license rights if used.  </p>

<p>Adjustments to support different packetization were made as well.  </p>

<p>Prabhu Tamilarasan contributions </p>

<p>Normalize function to improve volume  </p>

<p>Lior Herman contributions </p>

<p>Red5phone show busy or rejected message for busy outgoing calls.  </p>

<p>Openlaszlo and Javascript API made compatible with latest chages to Red5phone  Add Dial external command to Flex to dial from a link.  </p>

<p>Used UID (unique identifier) in Flex instead of the username value for binding the sipprovider object in Mjsip. Now you can use same sip account to register from multiple remote locations.  </p>

<p>Changed registration of red5phone using phone@sip_provider.getViaAddress() instead of phone@realm  </p>

<p>Mjsip now uses Outboundproxy = Proxy like that all sip headers using realm, but the message is send to the proxy ip.  </p>

<p>Process of OPTIONS messages in Mjsip some sbc’s using to check call keep alive.  </p>

<p>Fix authentication header for REG and INVITE to use cnounce value when proxy send qop= auth in 401 or 407 message.  </p>

<p>Fix red5phone application close for complete unregister before sipprovider.halt is execute.  </p>

<p>Fix the microphone.init in Flex to not be bind to the REGISTER SUCCESS message as it can be many SUCCESS messages coming during a call and mic need to be init only once.  </p>

<p>Fix Cancel message for Invite (call) that have not been answered yet. When you want hangup a call before the remote user answered Mjsip send wrong Cseq in Cancel message.  Fixed NullException error when application is closed in provider.halt() its try to close a null tcp_socket and get Null exception back. Fix is in org.zoolu.net.TcpServer.java in the end of the file.  </p>

<p>Janny_buh contribution </p>

<p>Patch all sip Register message using same Call-ID header and increment Cseq as recommended by RFC3261.</p>

 title : The redflag Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>About RedFlagWelcome. RedFlag is a next generation Del.icio.us client for Mac OS X that intends to make a simple and yet very capable bookmark manager capable of organizing your bookmarks efficiently and help you able to retrieve them in a fast manner while deeply tapping into all the great technologies Mac OS X has to offer.  </p>

<p>In other words we all have a lot of bookmarks that are both local on the browser and on del.icio.us. While del.icio.us is a great web access for bookmarks I believe we can do much much better as a native client and vastly surpass all other native clients in terms of how we can organize your bookmarks. Most Del.icio.us native clients just show a list of your tags, but what if you want more? RedFlag was created to push the limits what these clients are capable of and let you group tags together, or filter your bookmarks on your terms and help you get to the bookmark your looking for fast in a method that is convenient for you. </p>

<p>What does RedFlag run on?RedFlag will only run on Mac OS X 10.5 Leopard as it takes advantage of recent features in leopard such as Objective-C 2.0, Garbage Collection, NSOperation multithreading and more.  </p>

<p>Why the name RedFlag?Originally this was going to be called Socialist till someone actually came out with a Mac Del.icio.us client with the same name. My first project AssignmentTracker X, had a very serious name to it and so I wanted to use a vastly more casual name to this project. Taking an idea from the FLOSS Weekly podcast where Jeremy Allison was a guest, he made the joke &quot;oh I&#39;m a communist and I want to destroy the software industry...&quot; When I heard that I decided to use the name RedFlag that makes a joke at this stereotype reference.</p>

 title : The redlettr Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>redlettr is a unique tool devoted to the organizing, searching, and studying of the Holy Bible. redlettr is a for you, powered by you.</p>
 summary : <p>BACKGROUND TO THE MUSEUM: &quot;Rising above the ragtag roofs of nearby shacks and concrete-block houses, the imposing Red Location Museum provides a vivid contrast to the bleak landscape of the former black township of New Brighton, South Africa. Located 400 miles east of Cape Town, just outside Port Elizabeth, New Brighton sits in the shadow of factories and a giant power plant and pushes hard against the multiple tracks of a busy railway line. Since the dismantling of apartheid in 1994, the community has struggled to make the transition from a 100-year-old segregated township for underpaid laborers into a real town with previously unthinkable assets, such as decent housing, modern infrastructure, a wide array of businesses, diversified transportation options, and civic institutions. The museum is a vital part of this transformation. </p>

<p>The Red Location Museum emerged from a national competition in 1998 for the design of a civic precinct. Each entrant prepared a master plan that included a museum dedicated to the struggle against apartheid, an arts center and gallery, a market, a library, a community hall, and some housing—in the township’s oldest neighborhood, called Red Location for the color of the corrugated-iron siding used on its oldest houses. </p>

<p>Noero Wolff Architects, a small, Cape Town–based firm with a record of inventive projects in the townships, won the competition with a scheme that was both dignified and lively. The 31,500-square-foot museum, with its adjacent outdoor amphitheater, is the first major building from the master plan to be completed, with the others to be done by 2010. The museum serves as the soul of the new precinct. In the drawn-out struggle against racism and apartheid, the citizens of New Brighton were early and dedicated participants in civil disobedience, boycotts, and even antiapartheid violence, and much of this activity took place in Red Location. The museum honors the people involved in this struggle by telling their stories to visitors from the community and around the world.  </p>

<p>Under apartheid, black and “colored” people were forbidden to visit museums, libraries, and other cultural buildings, except as employees, entering through the back door. As a result, such buildings have little positive resonance with the people of New Brighton. So Jo Noero and Heinrich Wolff had to invent a different kind of architecture, one that would be approachable and meaningful to people with no direct experience of museums. They developed a robust, though refined, industrial aesthetic for the museum, creating a huge, singular volume enclosed by a concrete frame in-filled with concrete block. A sawtooth roof echoes the forms found in the manufacturing zone across the train tracks while also honoring the antiapartheid movement’s history of organizing in factory settings. The resulting architecture is simultaneously familiar and free&quot;. Quote Lisa Finley</p>

 title : The reduxauth Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Redux AuthenticationRedux Auth is a streamlined authentication package for CodeIgniter that can be ready in minutes, even faster if you use our premade application which has all the controllers, models and views set up for you. </p>

<p>Redux has the following features. </p>

<p>Account registration with the option of activation. Login and Logout Forgotten Password Security. Identical passwords will result in different hashes, can&#39;t be cracked using rainbow tables. </p>

<p>User groups. Change password. Email view templates. </p>

<p>You can view an example of Redux at work at www.thepixeldeveloper.com </p>

<p>Websites / Projects Using Redux AuthenticationLinkster Stikked Contact leveldesign.info if you want your project / website listed. </p>

<p>Redux Authentication on WebCodeigniter Redux Authentication: libreria per l’autenticazione Librería de login (inicio de sesión) para CodeIgniter What Code Igniter authentication library is best? reduxauth: librería de login para CodeIgniter</p>

 summary : <p>This contains scripts, Random solvers, and functions! </p>

<p>Thread on SRL:http://www.srl-forums.com/forum/d-include-my-t38044.html Instructions:Download TortoiseSVN: http://tortoisesvn.tigris.org/ After installed, create a folder in your includes folder called &quot;D-Include&quot; Right click the D-Include folder and click &quot;SVN Checkout...&quot;  In the URL of Repository box put: http://reflectioninclude.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ Make sure the Check Out dir is &quot;C:\Program Files\SCAR 3.15\Includes\SRL\D-Include&quot; Click OK! In your scar scripts!: Make sure to add {.include D-Include\DInclude.scar}! TAKE OUT {.include SRL\SRL\Reflection\Smart.scar};! D-Include includes that for you!. And that&#39;s it for setting up my include! </p>

<p>So far in the include:My Mime Random Solver has been added! This is a BETA, so please test and post to the thread on SRL. This will detect the Mime random and attempt to solve it! It has been tested and completed once. If you have any characters in the mime random you would like to donate, please contact me via PM at SRL, or send me an email at drags111@gmail.com! To use this, or any of my reflection randoms to be, just simply call FindReflectionRandoms followed by SRL&#39;s FindNormalRandoms 
<br/>I also have my BETA path walker! It is unique because it waits until the next tile is on the mini-map, then it clicks that tile as soon as it can. This makes it look and act more human. It helps to make the tiles only 3/4 of the maps length away. Don&#39;t try to stretch out the tiles!

 title : The reflectioninclude Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The reflections Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>version 0.9.5 - added  Maven repository, UseCases, javadoc, JavaCodeSerializer, getResources, Vfs </p>

<p>A Java runtime metadata analysis, in the spirit of ScannotationsReflections scans your classpath, indexes the metadata, allows you to query it on runtime and may save and collect that information for many modules within your project. </p>

<p>Using Reflections you can query your metadata such as: </p>

<p>get all subtypes of some type get all types/methods/fields annotated with some annotation, w/o annotation parameters matching get all resources matching matching a regular expression </p>

<p>How to use?a typical use of Reflections would be: </p>

<p>     Reflections reflections = new Reflections(&quot;my.project.prefix&quot;);</p>

<p>     Set&gt; subTypes = reflections.getSubTypesOf(SomeClassOrInterface.class);</p>

<p>     Set&gt; annotated = reflections.getTypesAnnotatedWith(SomeAnnotation.class);</p>

<p>     Set&gt; annotated1 = reflections.getTypesAnnotatedWith(
<br/>          new SomeAnnotation() {public String value() {return &quot;1&quot;;}
<br/>                                public Class annotationType() {return SomeAnnotation.class;}});</p>

<p>     Set propertiesFiles = reflections.getResources(Pattern.compile(&quot;.*\\.properties&quot;)); //depends on ResourcesScanner configured, as on next examplebasically, to use Reflections for scanning and querying, instantiate it with a Configuration, for example </p>

<p>     new Reflections(new ConfigurationBuilder()
<br/>          .filterInputsBy(new FilterBuilder.Include(FilterBuilder.prefix(&quot;my.project.prefix&quot;)))
<br/>          .setUrls(ClasspathHelper.getUrlsForPackagePrefix(&quot;my.project.prefix&quot;))
<br/>          .setScanners(new SubTypesScanner(),
<br/>                       new TypeAnnotationsScanner().filterResultsBy(filter),
<br/>                       new ResourcesScanner()));than use the convenient methods to query the metadata, such as getSubTypesOf, getTypesAnnotatedWith, getMethodsAnnotatedWith and more.  </p>

<p>You can use other scanners defined in Reflections as well, such as: SubTypesScanner, TypeAnnotationsScanner, FieldAnnotationsScanner, MethodAnnotationsScanner, ResourcrsScanner and more. Than use the equivalent query method in the Reflections object. </p>

<p>browse the javadoc for more info </p>

<p>also, browse the tests directory to see some more examples </p>

<p>MavenRepoto use Reflections via a maven repository, configure your pom.xml with </p>

<p>    reflections-repo
<br/>    Reflections Maven2 Repository
<br/>    http://reflections.googlecode.com/svn/repo
<br/>than add a dependency to Reflections in your pom.xml </p>

<p>    org.reflections
<br/>    reflections
<br/>    the latest version...
<br/>UseCasesReflections can also: </p>

<p>save scanned metadata and collect it later on runtime, for quick bootstrap of your application save your model entities metadata - fully qualified name of packages and types, fields and methods - so you can later reference these in a static manner find all resources matching a regular expression (for example find all .properties files or .xml files) </p>

<p>see the UseCases wiki page </p>

<p>Reflections Maven pluginThere is the ReflectionsMojo Maven plugin available for your project. With simple configuration you can save all scanned metadata into xml files upon compiling. Later on, when your project is bootstrapping you can let Reflections collect all those resources and re-create that metadata for you, making it available at runtime without re-scanning the classpath - thus reducing the bootstrapping time. </p>

<p>Use this maven configuration in your pom file: </p>

<p>    
<br/>        
<br/>            
<br/>                org.reflections
<br/>                reflections-maven
<br/>                the latest version...
<br/>                
<br/>                    
<br/>                        
<br/>                            reflections
<br/>                        
<br/>                        process-classes
<br/>                    
<br/>                
<br/>            
<br/>        
<br/>    than, on runtime: </p>

<p>        Reflections reflections =
<br/>                isProduction() ? Reflections.collect() : new Reflections(&quot;your.package.here&quot;);Check out in the ReflectionsMojo wiki page </p>

<p>Extending ReflectionsYou can easily extend Reflections by : </p>

<p>create your specialized scan class, should implement Scanner provide a query method within that scan class next, use that scanner instance to first configure Reflections and than to query </p>

<p>patches and extension are welcomed! </p>

<p>Cheers</p>

Support for Apache DynaClass / DynaBean is included. Current users of beanutils should be able to drop in these utilities and gain the functionality with minimal code changes. </p>

<p>Handles field operations for properties (getters and setters), partial properties (only getter or only setter), and fields. This is configurable to use the fields only, properties only, or the hybrid approach (default). This improves upon the BeanUtils limitation of handlin</p>

 title : The rejuvenate-pc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rejuvenate Pointcut is an open source, research prototype Eclipse plugin that limits the problems associated with fragile pointcuts in AspectJ by assisting developers in rejuvenating pointcuts as the base-code evolves.  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Development of the tool is current in its early stages and we welcome interested participants to join in the development effort by contacting the initial author. It is built as an extension to the AspectJ Development Tools (AJDT) and leverages the JayFX fact extractor plugin, the Drools rules engine, and the JDOM XML parser. Please visit the research web site for more details about the internals of the tool. </p>

<p>NewsThe plugin now works with the latest AJDT version (version 2.0.2). The plugin was rewritten to incorporate significant architectural changes in this new version of AJDT. </p>

<p>DownloadThe latest stable release is Rejuvenate Pointcut 1.2 and has been tested with Eclipse 3.5 SR2 and AJDT 2.0.2. The archive also includes source code used for that particular version. To install, simply unzip the archive into your Eclipse distribution directory. We hope to have an automated update site set up in the near future. Also feel free to check out the latest sources from the SVN repository. </p>

<p>Getting startedTake a look at the GettingStarted page. Also, slides from a recent tool demonstration at the International Conference on Aspect-Oriented Software Development (AOSD &#39;09) are available here. A research poster depicting an earlier version of the tool, presented at AOSD &#39;08, is available here. </p>

<p>Getting helpPlease feel free to post to the General User Discussion list with any comments, questions, or concerns.</p>

 title : The rest-responses Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RestResponses is a couple of useful little methods to clear up your restfull controllers, turning something like this: </p>

<p>def update
<br/> @user = User.find(params[:id])
<br/> @user.update_attributes!(params[:user])
<br/>  respond_to do |wants|
<br/>     wants.html { }
<br/>     wants.xml  { render :xml =&amp;gt; @user.to_xml(:except =&amp;gt; :hashed_password) } 
<br/>  end	 
<br/>rescue ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound
<br/>  render :nothing =&amp;gt; true, :status =&amp;gt; 404
<br/>rescue ActiveRecord::InvalidRecord
<br/>  respond_to do |wants|
<br/>    wants.html { }
<br/>    wants.xml  { render :xml =&amp;gt; @user.errors.to_xml }
<br/>   end
<br/>end	 To this: </p>

<p>before_filter :find_user
<br/>def update
<br/> @user.update_attributes!(params[:user])
<br/>  responds @user
<br/>endTo install: ruby script/plugin install http://rest-responses.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/rest_responses</p>
 title : The restdb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RestDB is a framework, means you can expose any database with a RESTful service. </p>

<p>The main concept of RestDB is CoC (Convention over Configuration), With the framework, you can access your database with a RESTful URI,  </p>

<p>For example, you have a MySQL database, and the database name is Blog, it contains a table named Users, and you suppose to access the data in the users with the following URI: </p>

<p>http://localhost/blog/usersAnd if in a browser, it should return a page to you, and it&#39;s just like the Scaffolding you ever seen in other frameworks like RoR(Ruby on Rails) </p>

<p>You can also work with RestDB in a programmatic way. Read more in our wiki Page. </p>

<p>All in all, with RestDB, you can expose your database as a simple web service.</p>
