 title : The restian Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RESTianThe goal of the RESTian project is multi-faceted and influenced by the immortal words of Alan Kay &quot;We aim to make simple things simple and complex things possible.&quot; Its first goal will be to create a Framework for building RESTful Web Services and its latter goal will be to define a Service Interface Schema for RESTful Web Services. </p>

<p>Initial ImplementationThe initial implementation languages are JavaScript for the client and PHP v4 on MySQL for the server.  The initial target platform for testing and example services is Drupal v5.x.  The initial content types for request and response are &quot;application/x-www-form-urlencoded&quot; and JSON, respectively. </p>

<p>REST FrameworkThe initial goal is to create a framework for both clients and servers optimized for rapid and easy development of fully RESTful Web Services that can be reasonably easily evolved to be fully robust without requiring a change to the externally-facing service interface. RESTian will initially aim to streamline creating CRUD-based operations for SQL databases as well as services using purpose-built functions and will hopefully later look to simplify interface with other back-ends(1). </p>

<p>REST Service Interface SchemaThe longer term goal will be to identify the schema required to drive RESTful web services that can be represented in practically any language and that can easily be transformed between languages formats. The schema will provide necessary information to (almost) any language capable (2) of serving dynamic content via HTTP and a subset of the schema will provide the necessary information to allow clients to make requests of the same RESTful web services thus satisfying the &quot;hypermedia as the engine of application state&quot; requirement.  </p>

<p>The initial implementation format for this schema will be JSON and it will be specified by the developer on a path segment heirarchical basis allowing for inheritance of specification and will hopefully later be available in a variety of formats(3). </p>

<p>FootnotesOther back-ends could include interfaces to CouchDb, Amazon&#39;s SimpleDB and S3, Flickr, YouTube, and more. Server languages to hopefully also include Python, Perl, Ruby, JavaScript, VBScript, [http://www.java.com/en/ Java, C#, VB.NET, Cold Fusion, and more. Formats to hopefully include (X)HTML+Microformats, XML, RSS, AtomPub, YAML, and more.</p>
 summary : <p>RESTful + Admin = Restin </p>

<p>Restin is an admin application for assignmapper and Elixir models. The project is brand new (four days old as of 4/23/2007) and is a bit rough around the edges. Though it is built on Pylons, it should work on any model defined using assignmapper or Elixir Entity classes. </p>

<p>(Very) Quick StartInstallsvn checkout http://restin.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ Restin
<br/>cd Restin
<br/>python setup.py developSet UpBy default, Restin uses SQLite. Change that first in development.ini if necessary, then run: </p>

<p>paster setup-app development.iniLaunchpaster serve --reload development.ini
<br/># This might work, too:
<br/>./development.inPoke AroundFirst, go to http://localhost:5001/applications. Create an application entry containing metadata about an existing Pylons project. (If you don&#39;t have one, you can get super-meta and fill in the details for Restin itself.) </p>

<p>The two important fields are &#39;package name&#39; and &#39;dburi.&#39; Right now, package name refers to a Pylons package name. For example, if you use from myproject.lib.base import * in your project, you&#39;d put &#39;myproject&#39; in the package name field.  </p>

<p>Now, the navigation is somewhat lacking, so once you&#39;ve created an entry for your app, you&#39;ll have to type in the address bar before you can start administering your app&#39;s data: </p>

<p>First, click &#39;Show&#39; for the app you want to admin, then add &#39;/model&#39; to the end of the URL. This will bring up a list of the entities in the model for that app. Select an entity and start administering. </p>

<p>FutureFix the obviously broken stuff, like the things noted above.  Add authorization Deal with any potential Unicode issues Support model classes mapped in the &#39;normal&#39; way (and maybe even Table objects) by generating assignmapper classes (is this possible/feasible?) Generate Pylons (or other) apps from application metadata (!?)</p>
 title : The restin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The restler Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RESTful + Controller = Restler </p>

<p>Restler is a base controller for Pylons projects that provides a set of default RESTful actions that can be overridden as needed. </p>

<p>Quick StartThis document contains info on the bleeding edge version of Restler, 0.5.x. </p>

<p>Install PylonsRestler is developed against Pylons 1.0. </p>

<p>easy_install Pylons==1.0rc1Install Restlereasy_install RestlerOr, if you want to hack on Restler: </p>

<p>hg clone https://restler.googlecode.com/hg/ Restler
<br/>cd Restler
<br/>python setup.py developCreate a new Pylons projectpaster create --template=pylons MyProject
<br/>cd MyProjectSet up database engine, Session, and metadataNot documented here. See Pylons docs. </p>

<p>TODO: Link to appropriate docs and/or show simple example here. </p>

<p>Create a base controller classOpen myproject/lib/base.py and add the following lines below the existing imports: </p>

<p>from restler.controller import Controller as _RestControllerNext, create a new class that implements the get_db_session method: </p>

<p>class RestController(_RestController):</p>

<p>    def get_db_session(self):
<br/>        return myproject.model.meta.SessionWhere you define your database session object/factory is up to you. The example here is based on a model setup suggested by members of the Pylons community. </p>

<p>Note: The default BaseController generated by paster when creating a new Pylons project is used by the default error and template controllers, so it&#39;s probably best to leave it alone and not use it as your RESTful base controller. </p>

<p>Create some mapped entity classesEvery entity class needs member_name, member_title, collection_name, and collection_title class attributes. </p>

<p>To return JSON using the Restler controller&#39;s built-in facilities, entity classes need to define the methods to_simple_object and to_simple_collection. Restler provides an Entity base class with default implementations of these methods. </p>

<p>import restler.entity</p>

<p>class Garage(restler.entity.Entity):</p>

<p>    member_name = &#39;garage&#39;
<br/>    collection_name = &#39;garages&#39;
<br/>    member_title = &#39;Garage&#39;
<br/>    collection_title = &#39;Garages&#39;</p>

<p># TODO: Create a SQLAlchemy `Table` object for the `Garage` class and map the
<br/># class and table.Restler has a helper function that will automagically add member_name, member_title, etc. attributes to the class (only works for words with simple plurals): </p>

<p>import restler.entity</p>

<p>class Garage(restler.entity.Entity):
<br/>    pass</p>

<p># Add `member_name` et al:
<br/>restler.entity.instrument_class(Garage)Create a controller for each Entity class you want to exposefrom myproject.model.entities.oracle.trans import Garage
<br/>from myproject.lib.base import RestController</p>

<p>class GaragesController(RestController):</p>

<p>    entity = GarageMap URLs for resources/entities to controllersIn config/routing.py, add a line like this for each RESTful controller: </p>

<p>map.resource(&#39;garage&#39;, &#39;garages&#39;)EpilogueRestler was originally extracted from the byCycle.org Trip Planner (http://bycycle.org). </p>

<p>Send feedback, corrections, et cetera to wyatt .DOT. lee .DOT. baldwin .AT. gmail .DOT. com or create an issue.</p>

 summary : <p>Rest&#39;N is a REST framework for .NET based on the ASP.NET MVC project with lessons learned from Ruby on Rails and the Resource-Oriented Architecture.Features&quot;Neat&quot; URL&#39;s! Rest&#39;N includes a routing engine that will produce simple URL&#39;s like: http://www.example.com/People/6 http://www.example.com/People/6.xml http://www.example.com/People/6/edit http://www.example.com/People/new Integrated support for &quot;overloaded POST&quot;.  title : The rex-editor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rex Editor is a text editor featuring syntax highlighting, a tabbed interface, and a project browser view. </p>

<p>Rex is written entirely in Ruby and uses the Ruby-Tk library to display the interface. Jamis Buck&#39;s Syntax gem is used for syntax highlighting. </p>

<p>Dependencies are: </p>

<p>Ruby-Tk (part of the Ruby standard library) the &#39;syntax&#39; gem </p>

<p>Current features: </p>

<p>Syntax highlighting for Ruby, YAML &amp; XML files Tabbed file view File browser </p>

<p>Known Bugs: </p>

<p>Syntax croaks on lines that end with a backslash </p>

<p>Keyboard shortcuts &amp; commands: </p>

<p> closes current tab  saves current tab  opens a file open dialog box Double-clicking on a tab toggles tab maximization </p>

<p>Subversion integration, diff view Collapsible tree view Better color selection for syntax highlighting Trac integration Test on Mac &amp; Windows</p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>rextv is an XMLTV generator in Ruby. </p>

<p>XMLTV is a standard for storing Electronic Program Guides (EPGs) in XML. It is used by applications that record and play back TV shows, such as MythTV on Linux, many others on Windows, and even - with some other third party hacks - Microsoft Windows Media Center Edition. </p>

 title : The rextv Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 title : The rfcmail Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RFCMail is a collection of Perl modules which can be used to implement a number of mail-related things, such as SMTP honeypots for spam analysis. Its core business is that of an MTA, so most of the modules relate to SMTP in some way. It does not major in message text handling or message store (mailbox) management. The author has chosen to re-implement the core SMTP functionality, rather than re-use existing implementations, so as to allow much greater flexibility in how SMTP is handled. </p>

<p>At this particular point in time, it has a fully functional SMTP server which is capable of acting as an SMTP honeypot. This may prove of some interest to those conducting anti-spam research. Although much of the existing functionality is clean and well documented, the overall project is still a shambles, undergoing significant restructuring as new and better ways of structuring the code are discovered. It has not settled down into a pattern that can be released and maintained, so it is currently only suitable for ad hoc tasks, not as the basis for long-term software products. </p>

<p>The ultimate project goal is to produce a library of parts capable of implementing a fully functional mail server (MTA) with a very large degree of flexibility. This flexibility should make it possible to experiment with bleeding-edge anti-spam techniques and mail delivery protocols. Perl is well-suited as a base language for this purpose, since it allows rapid development and easy combination of modules to form a useful whole. On the other hand, the project is not expected to suit the needs of those who just need an ordinary, solid MTA that scales well (although the project owner will be quite happy if this end can be met). </p>

<p>This project also aims to set extremely high (to the point of fastidious) standards in code and documentation quality, and standards compliance. </p>

<p>This project has only just been migrated to Google Code (from origins as a private project), and a significant amount of work remains to be done before the project will be accommodating to prospective users and contributors. It also remains to be seen how much time the project owner can dedicate to this task! At the moment, the suggested way to introduce yourself to it is to check out the trunk, then read the documentation in pm/RFCMail/ESMTP/Server.pod. Also, look at bin/honeypot-smtpd.pl for a simple but useful application (which can be launched from inetd or similar if desired). Note that this application requires the well-known Net::DNS module.</p>
